questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman nearing her due date was admitted on presenting with labor pain. The resident doctor examined the patient and told the intern that the head is at +3 station. Where is the exact position of the head?
questions.solution:
The exact position of the head when it is at +3 station is 3 cm below the ischial spine.

The station of the head is described in relation to ischial spines as they are the most prominent bony projections felt on internal examination.

The level of ischial spines is halfway between the pelvic inlet and outlet. This level is known as station zero (0). The levels above and below the spines are designated based on centimeters, 1 cm away from station 0 is either +1 or -1 station. If the presenting part is above the spines, it is stated with a minus sign (such as -1 cm, -2 cm) and if it is below the spines, it is stated with a plus sign (such as +1 cm, +2 cm).

Related Pearl: Functional divisions of labor

Preparatory division Dilatational division Pelvic division
Latent phase + acceleration phases The phase of maximum slope Deceleration phase + the second stage of labor

Little cervical dilatation

The most rapid rate of dilatation

 Cardinal fetal movements of cephalic presentation occur

Sedation and conduction analgesia can arrest this division

 Unaffected by sedation  --

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Borrelia recurrentis is false?

choices.text: Infection is transmitted by the bite of lice

questions.solution:
Borrelia recurrentis causes epidemic relapsing fever. It is transmitted when the lice are crushed and rubbed into abraded skin.

Relapsing fever is an arthropod-borne infection. It is of two types:

  • Epidemic or louse-borne relapsing fever
  • Endemic or tick-borne relapsing fever

Epidemic relapsing fever is caused by Borrelia recurrentis. It is an irregular spiral with one or both ends pointed and is gram-negative. It is transmitted from person to person through body lice Pediculus humanus corporis. The incubation period is 2-10days after which fever occurs. Borreliae are abundant in the patient's blood during this period. Fever subsides in 3-5 days. After an afebrile period of 4-10 days, another bout of fever sets in. The borreliae reappear in blood during the relapses of fever. The disease ultimately subsides after 3-10 relapses. In lice, the borrelia is confined to the hemolymph and is not shed in saliva or excreta. So the infection is transmitted not by the bite of lice but by their being crushed and rubbed into abraded skin.

Endemic relapsing fever is caused by B.duttonii, B.hermsii, B.parkeri. Ornithodorus tholozoni, O.crossi, O.lahorensis, and the fowl tick, Argas persicus acts as vectors. The borrelia persists in the body of infected ticks throughout their life. It is transmitted transovarially so that the ticks act as reservoirs as well as vectors. It is transmitted to humans through the bite of ticks or their discharges.

Borrelia is microaerophilic and the optimum temperature for growth is 28-30°C. It readily undergoes antigenic variations in vivo and is the reason for the occurrence of relapses in the disease.

Tetracyclines, chloramphenicol, penicillin, and erythromycin are used for the treatment.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman comes for a follow-up, 1 week after her first child was born. Her husband reports that his wife appears uninterested in taking care of the baby, has sudden crying outbursts and seems sad for no reason for the last 2 days. Her sleep is disturbed and she feels fatigued. She is able to carry out the daily chores and enjoys watching television like before. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient has mild depressive symptoms within the first week of delivery. So the most likely diagnosis is postpartum blues.

Postpartum blues, also called maternity blues, typically develop within one week of delivery, usually on the fourth or fifth postpartum day. The affected mothers are emotionally labile and the symptoms include changes in mood, sudden crying outbursts, and a lack of interest in the baby. They may also have insomnia, anxiety, poor concentration, and irritability.

These feelings have been ascribed to rapid changes in women's hormonal levels, the stress of childbirth, and the awareness of the increased responsibility that motherhood brings. This usually resolves spontaneously within 10-14 days. 

Management involves reassurance, education, and support. The patient must be followed-up and assessed for the possible development of a major depressive disorder.

Other options:

Option B: Symptoms should persist for >2 weeks to make the diagnosis of post-partum depression. A minimum of 5 symptoms of major depressive disorder i.e. impaired sleep, interest, guilt, energy, concentration, appetite, psychomotor activity, and suicidal ideation must be present. This patient is able to do her daily chores, enjoys watching TV, has a good appetite, and does not have guilt or suicidal ideation. Although this patient has disturbed sleep and fatigue, these are common physiological postpartum findings.

Option C: Post-partum psychosis is a psychiatric emergency and usually has a mean time of onset is 2-3 weeks postpartum. The predominant symptoms are hallucinations, delusions, suicidal thoughts, and thoughts of harming the baby. The onset of psychotic symptoms is usually preceded by signs such as insomnia, restlessness, labile mood, and agitation. Lithium, often in combina­tion with an antidepressant, is the treatment of choice.

Option D: Episodes of delirium in the postpartum period are characterized by a fluctuating level of awareness or attention. In this patient, there is no altered sense of awareness.

Note:  Zuranolone is the first-ever oral drug to be approved specifically for the treatment of postpartum depression. It is a neuroactive steroid that enhances the action of GABA in the brain and regulates mood. 

Related Pearl: Postpartum mood disorders

Disorders and features Incidence and timeline Harmful thoughts Treatment

Postpartum blues:

Depressed affect, tearfulness and fatigue

30-75%

Starts 2-3 days after delivery. Resolves within 10 days.

 No thoughts of harming the baby Support and follow up

Postpartum depression:

Depressed affect, anxiety, and poor concentration

10-15%

Starts within 4 weeks from delivery (DSM 5) or 6 weeks (ICD 11) and persists for ≥ 2 weeks. 

 Thoughts of harming the baby often present CBT and SSRIs 

Postpartum psychosis:

Mood-congruent delusions, hallucinations

0.1-0.2%

Onset within 4 weeks postpartum (DSM 5) or 6 weeks (ICD 11)

 Thoughts of harming the baby or self Hospitalization, atypical antipsychotics and ECT for refractory cases

Note: Zuranolone is the first-ever oral drug to be FDA-approved specifically for the treatment of postpartum depression. It is a neuroactive steroid that enhances the action of GABA in the brain and regulates mood.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida with a history of gestational diabetes mellitus is in active labor. After delivery of the head, a positive turtle sign was noticed. Which of the following maneuvres cannot be used for the management of this case?
questions.solution:
The case of gestational diabetes with a positive turtle sign is suggestive of shoulder dystocia. Pinard's maneuver is not used in the management of shoulder dystocia.

Pinard's maneuver is done for frank breech extraction. The middle and the index fingers are placed in the popliteal fossa to abduct and flex the fetal leg. The fetal ankle is then grasped and breech extraction is accomplished as shown below.

Mc Robert's maneuver, Gaskin's maneuver, Rubin's maneuver are all used in the management of shoulder dystocia. 

Shoulder dystocia occurs when either the anterior or rarely the posterior fetal shoulder gets impacted on the maternal symphysis or on the sacral promontory respectively, following the delivery of the head. A positive turtle sign may be seen which refers to a definite recoil of the head back against the perineum. The incidence of shoulder dystocia increases with increasing birth weight, which can be due to maternal obesity, gestational diabetes, post-term pregnancy, and multiparity. Management of labor in case of shoulder dystocia:

  • Gentle downward traction of the fetal head with suprapubic pressure 
  • Mc.Roberts maneuver: Flexing the legs on the abdomen with concurrent suprapubic pressure. This causes straightening of the sacrum relative to the lumbar vertebrae, rotation of the symphysis pubis toward the maternal head, and a decrease in the angle of pelvic inclination. This tends to free the impacted anterior shoulder. It is shown in the image below.

Woods corkscrew maneuver: Pro­gressive rotation of the posterior shoulder 180 degrees in a cork­ screw fashion releases the impacted anterior shoulder. It is shown in the image below.

  • Rubin's maneuver: The fetal shoulders are rocked from side to side by applying force to the maternal abdomen. If this is not successful, the pelvic hand pushes the most easily accessible fetal shoulder toward the anterior surface of the chest, producing a smaller bisacromial diameter. This permits displacement of the anterior shoulder from behind the symphysis.
  • Gaskin maneuver: (All fours maneuver): The parturient rolls onto her knees and hands and downward traction against the head and neck is applied, with the attempt to free the posterior shoulder.
  • Zavanelli maneuver: It involves the replacement of the fetal head into the pelvis followed by cesarean delivery.
  • Symphysiotomy: The intervening symphyseal carti­lage and ligamentous supports are cut to widen the symphysis pubis.
  • Cleidotomy: Fracture of the clavicle using an instrument to free the anterior shoulder. Usually done for a dead fetus. (shown below)

Related Pearl: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl presents to the gynecology outpatient department with complaints of scanty episodes of bleeding but is regularly timed. This menstrual cycle irregularity is called _____.
questions.solution:
Hypomenorrhea refers to regularly timed but scanty episodes of bleeding.

Menstrual cycle irregularities definitions:

  • Menometrorrhagia refers to excessive, prolonged bleeding that occurs at irregularly timed and frequent intervals.
  • Metrorrhagia refers to irregularly timed episodes of bleeding superimposed on normal cyclical bleeding.
  • Oligomenorrhea denotes infrequent, irregularly timed episodes of bleeding usually occurring at intervals of more than 35 days.
  • Amenorrhea indicates the absence of menstruation. 
  • Polymenorrhea denotes frequent episodes of menstruation, usually occurring at intervals of 21 days or less. 
  • Menorrhagia denotes regularly timed episodes of bleeding that are excessive in amount (>80 mL) and/or duration of flow (>7 days). 
  • Intermenstrual bleeding refers to bleeding (usually not excessive) that occurs between otherwise normal menstrual cycles.
  • Precocious menstruation denotes the occurrence of menstruation before the age of 10 years.
  • Postcoital bleeding denotes vaginal bleeding after sexual intercourse.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is most sensitive to penicillin?
questions.solution:
Among the given organisms, Treponema pallidum is most sensitive to penicillin. Penicillin G remains the drug of choice for the treatment of syphilis.

Staphylococcus, Streptococcus, and Pneumococcus have developed variable resistance to penicillin G and penicillin G is no longer considered the drug of choice for most of the infections caused by them.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with excessive weight gain, easy bruising, striae, and glucose intolerance. After appropriate workup, she is diagnosed with an adrenocortical adenoma. Which of the following layers of the adrenal gland are involved in this disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Cushing's syndrome caused by the adrenocortical adenoma. The layer of the adrenal gland involved in Cushing's syndrome is zona fasciculata. 

Cushing's syndrome is caused by elevated glucocorticoid (cortisol) production. It can be endogenous (intrinsic hormone production) or exogenous (consumption of excessive glucocorticoids). The endogenous causes can also be classified as adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) dependent or independent. 

ACTH is released by the anterior pituitary in response to corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) released by the hypothalamus. It signals the zona fasciculata of the adrenal gland to produce more glucocorticoids by a feedback mechanism. In some instances, ectopic production of cortisol is unresponsive to ACTH released by the pituitary gland. Thus, hypercortisolism can be ACTH-dependent or independent. 

60-70% of cases of endogenous hypercortisolism are caused by ACTH-secreting pituitary adenomas.

5-10% of ACTH secretion is by ectopic tumors, most commonly being small-cell carcinoma of the lung. 

The most common cause of ACTH-independent Cushing's syndrome is primary adrenal neoplasm as seen in this case. 

The adrenal cortex has four layers: 

Layer Hormone Example
Zona glomerulosa Mineralocorticoids Aldosterone
Zona fasciculata Glucocorticoids Cortisol
Zona reticularis Sex steroids Estrogens and androgens
Adrenal medulla Catecholamines Epinephrine

 

Related Pearl: Secretion of Adrenal Hormones by the different Zones of the Adrenal Cortex and Adrenal Medulla

Adrenal Medulla

Aldosterone

Epinephrine

Glucocorticoids

Cortisol

Corticosterone

  • DHEA
  • Androstenedione

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy has received complete immunization against tetanus 6 years ago. Now he presents with a contaminated lacerated wound sustained 6 hours ago. He should be given which of the following?

choices.text: Human tetanus immunoglobulin and single dose of toxoid

questions.solution:
The boy should be given a single dose of tetanus toxoid alone.

He presented with a contaminated wound sustained 6 hours ago and he has received complete immunization against tetanus 6 years back, which comes under Category B of Tetanus Immunization.

According to the recommendations of the CDC:

Vaccination History Clean Minor Wounds All other wounds
Unknown or fewer than 3 doses Tdap/Td Tdap/TD + TIG
3 or more doses Tdap/ Td Only if > 10 years Tdap/TD Only if > 5 years

Tdap - Tetanus, Diptheria, and Pertussis

Td - Tetanus and Diptheria

TIG - Tetanus Immune Globulin

Tdap for children and Td for adults but Tdap is preferred to Td for adults who have never received Tdap.

 Categories of Tetanus immunization:

  • Category A - Taken a complete course of TT/booster within the past 5 years
  • Category B - Taken a complete course of TT/booster within the past > 5 years < 10 years.
  • Category C - Taken a complete course of TT/booster within the past >10 years
  • Category D - Not taken a complete course of TT/booster or immunity status not known.

Related Pearl: Post exposure prophylaxis for tetanus

Prophylaxis is given based on patient category:

A. Full immunization or a booster dose within the past 5 years.

B. Full immunization or a booster dose > 5 years ago but < 10 years.

C. Full immunization or a booster dose > 10 years ago.

D. Unknown or never taken immunization

Category Clean wound Unclean wound
A Only wound care Only wound care
B Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose
C Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose + Human tetanus immunoglobulin 
D Wound care + TT complete course Wound care + TT complete course + Human tetanus immunoglobulin

questions.text:
A 57-year-old male patient with a history of liver cirrhosis presents to the emergency department with massive hematemesis. He is resuscitated and stabilized. Which of the following is the preferred option to prevent rebleeding?

TIPSS- Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt
questions.solution:
The preferred treatment option to prevent rebleeding is endoscopic band ligation.

In this method, a rubber band that can constrict is placed at the base of the varix. This immediately occludes the vessel and stops the bleeding. Rebleeding occurs very rarely with this method. 

Initial management of variceal bleeding involves the following: 

  • Admission to the intensive care unit
  • Placement of two large-bore peripheral cannulae
  • Blood transfusion
  • Correction of coagulopathy with fresh frozen plasma, vitamin K and tranexamic acid
  • Terlipressin, a splanchnic vasoconstrictor
  • Prophylactic antibiotic
  • Endotracheal intubation for airway protection if bleeding is uncontrolled
  • Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy

Other options

Option B - Endoscopic sclerotherapy involves injecting a sclerosant around the bleeding vessel. It is also effective in treating esophageal varices. However, the incidence of rebleeding is higher with this treatment.

Option C - Sengstaken-Blakemore tube is a temporary, stabilizing measure.  It tamponades the bleeding varices. It is not a definitive treatment for variceal bleeding but is very effective to stop the bleed and stabilize the patient.

Option D - TIPSS or transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic stent shunt placement involves the placement of a shunt to redirect blood flow and reduce portal pressure. It is very effective but requires analgesia, sedation, and fluoroscopic guidance. It is done if medical and endoscopic measures fail to control bleeding.

Related Pearl: Common sites of porto-systemic anastomosis in portal hypertension

  • Left gastric vein [portal] to Distal oesophageal [systemic] veins: Presents with oesophageal and gastric variceal bleeding
  • Superior rectal veins to Middle and inferior rectal veins: Presents with rectal varices and lower GI tract bleeding
  • Tributaries of left branch of portal vein in ligamentum teres to Periumbilical branches of epigastric and intercostal veins: Forms caput medusae
  • Tributaries of right branch of portal vein overlying ‘bare area’ of liver to Retroperitoneal veins draining into azygos, hemiazygos, lumbar, intercostal and phrenic veins
  • Omental and colonic veins near hepatic and splenic ﬂexures to Retroperitoneal veins near hepatic and splenic ﬂexures

Related Pearl: Causes of Portal Hypertension

questions.text: A patient is undergoing pulmonary artery catheterization. While introducing Swan-Ganz catheter, its placement in the pulmonary artery is characterized by which of the following pressure tracing?
questions.solution:
Placement of the Swan-Ganz catheter in the pulmonary artery is characterized by a sudden increase in diastolic pressure and a change in waveform morphology. Diastolic pressure initially is higher than that in the right ventricle(RV).

Pulmonary artery catheterization is used to assess hemodynamic variables in sick patients undergoing major surgery. It is used to measure

  • Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP). In the presence of mitral valve pathology or a previous transplant, trans-septal left atrial catheterization is done.
  • Left ventricular end-diastolic pressure (LVEDP)
  • Ventricular volume.
  • Cardiac output
  • Stroke volume
  • Confirm diagnosis of pulmonary artery hypertension
  • Assess severity of mitral stenosis

Absolute contraindications of pulmonary artery catheterization are right-sided endocarditis, tumors of the right heart, and lack of consent. Relative contraindications are left bundle branch block and pulmonary and tricuspid valve disorders.

Technique for pulmonary artery catheterization - Central venous access via the right internal jugular vein is most commonly used and is achieved by using Seldinger's technique. The Swan-Ganz catheter is inserted and waveforms start to appear once the catheter is in the right atrium. Respiratory variations of the waveform confirm intrathoracic placement. Once the catheter is in the right ventricle, transient ectopy due to irritation of the right ventricle by the balloon and catheter tip is common and rarely requires treatment. Continuous ECG monitoring is required.

The normal pulmonary capillary wedge pressure is between 4 to 12 mmHg. Elevated levels of PCWP might indicate severe left ventricular failure or severe mitral stenosis. The waveforms that can be observed are tabulated below:

Location Pressure tracing
Catheter passes via SVC to the right atrium  (Right atrial pressure) Low-pressure waves in systole and diastole. <5 mm Hg
The catheter enters the right ventricle  through the tricuspid valve (Right ventricle pressure) A sudden increase in systolic pressure with the same diastolic pressure 25 mm Hg systolic and 0-5 mm Hg diastolic
Enter the pulmonary artery through the pulmonary valve (Pulmonary artery pressure)

A sudden increase in diastolic pressure (about 10 mm Hg). Systolic pressure remains the same  

Dicrotic notch caused by the closure of the pulmonary valve

 25mmHg systolic and 10-20 mm Hg diastolic pressure
The catheter advances into a branch of the pulmonary artery where it wedges. Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure.  This reflects left atrial pressure Dampened pressure waveform 4-12 mm Hg

 

Complications of pulmonary artery catheterization:

  • Arrhythmias like ventricular fibrillation
  • Right bundle branch block
  • Complete heart block (if preexisting left bundle branch block)
  • Pulmonary artery rupture
  • Pulmonary artery pseudoaneurysm
  • Catheter knots.

Other Options:

Option A: Sudden decrease in diastolic pressure is not the hallmark of entry into the pulmonary artery. After the initial increase in diastolic pressure in the pulmonary artery, during ventricular diastole, the RV diastolic pressure increases and the pulmonary artery diastolic pressure decreases due to the runoff of blood into the lungs. 

Options C and D: The systolic pressures of the pulmonary artery remain the same as those of the right ventricle in normal physiological conditions.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presented with fatigue and intermittent dark-colored urine. Further evaluation revealed positive Donath  Landsteiner antibodies. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Donath Landsteiner antibody is specific for paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria (PCH). PCH is a rare form of autoimmune hemolytic anemia.

The mechanism of this antibody includes:

  • Binding to RBCs at 4°C
  • Complement-mediated lysis at 37°C

This condition presents with intravascular hemolysis and hemoglobinuria. Blood transfusion is required in severe anemia. It is a self-limiting condition.

The differences between PCH and PNH are given below:

Condition Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria (PCH)
Onset Chronic with acute exacerbations Acute
Pathogenesis Complement-mediated destruction of CD59/55(–) RBCs Immune lysis of normal red cells
Diagnosis Flow cytometry to display a CD55/CD59(–) red cell population Test for Donath-Landsteiner antibody
Triggers Infections, alcohol, exercise, stress, or  medications Triggered by viral infection

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding the regulation of cholesterol synthesis?
  1. Insulin and thyroxine decrease HMG CoA reductase activity.
  2. Cortisol and glucagon decrease HMG CoA reductase activity.
  3. Statins inhibit HMG CoA reductase.
  4. Cholesterol increases HMG CoA reductase activity.
  5. Cholesterol represses transcription of HMG CoA reductase mRNA.
questions.solution:
Statements 2, 3, and 5 are true regarding the regulation of cholesterol synthesis.

HMG CoA reductase is the principal enzyme involved in the regulation of cholesterol synthesis. Cholesterol is synthesized from acetyl-CoA mainly in the liver and intestine. This process occurs in the endoplasmic reticulum and cytosol.

HMG-CoA reductase reduces HMG-CoA to mevalonate by NADPH in the pathway of cholesterol synthesis. This principal regulatory step is targeted by statins, which are drugs that efficiently lower cholesterol by inhibiting HMG-CoA reductase.

Activity of HMG-CoA reductase is influenced by the following factors:

  • By-products of the cholesterol synthesis pathway: Mevalonate, the immediate product of the reaction, and cholesterol, the main product of the pathway, inhibit enzyme activity. These metabolites also repress transcription of HMG-CoA reductase mRNA by inhibiting sterol regulatory element-binding protein (SREBP) transcription factor.
  • Hormones: Insulin and thyroid hormones increase enzyme activity, whereas glucagon or glucocorticoids decrease it.
  • Posttranslational modifications: Phosphorylation–dephosphorylation reactions affect enzyme activity. AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) phosphorylates and inactivates the enzyme.
  • Diurnal variation

questions.text: The chemokine that exists in two forms belongs to which of the following groups?
questions.solution:
The chemokine that exists in two forms is Fractalkine which is the only known member of the group CX3C chemokines.

Chemokines are a family of small proteins that act as chemoattractants for specific types of leukocytes. They are classified into four major groups, according to the arrangement of cysteine (C) residues in the proteins:

  • C-X-C chemokines have one amino acid residue separating the first two of the four conserved cysteine residues. They are secreted by activated macrophages, endothelial cells, and other cell types. Their most important inducers are microbial products and other cytokines, mainly IL­1 and TNF. They cause activation and chemotaxis of neutrophils. IL­8 is typical of this group. 
  • C-C chemokines have the first two conserved cysteine residues adjacent to each other. They mainly act on monocytes, eosinophils, basophils, and lymphocytes, and have fewer actions on neutrophils. Important C-C chemokines are monocyte chemoattractant protein, eotaxin, macrophage inflammatory protein-1α, etc.
  • C chemokines lack the first and third of the four conserved cysteines. The C chemokines (e.g., lymphotactin) are relatively specific for lymphocytes.
  • CX3C chemokines contain three amino acids between the two cysteines. The only known member of this class is called fractalkine. It acts as a chemoattractant and promotes strong adhesion of monocytes and T cells.

questions.text: A child in your unit is admitted with alopecia, oligodontia, and features of rickets with elevated serum levels of alkaline phosphatase activity and 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D. What could be the pathology?
questions.solution:
Alopecia and oligodontia (reduced number of teeth) with features of rickets in a child is classically seen in vitamin D-dependant rickets type 2 where the pathology is end-organ resistance (receptor hyposensitivity) to vitamin D.

Rickets causes

  • Nutritional vitamin D deficiency
  • Secondary vitamin D deficiency
    • Vitamin D-dependant rickets, type 1 (defect in 1-alpha hydroxylase)
    • Vitamin D-dependant rickets, type 2 (end organ resistance)
    • Chronic kidney disease
  • Hypophosphatemic rickets
    • X-linked dominant hypophosphatemic rickets (PHEX gene mutation)
    • Autosomal dominant (fibroblast growth factor [FGF] resistance to endopeptidases)
    • Oncogenous rickets (increased FGF 23)

Note:

Vitamin D antibodies are found in most patients of systemic sclerosis.

Related Pearl: Vitamin D activation and Rickets

questions.text: A study was done to assess nutritional status among young children in rural and urban areas. 40 children in rural and 30 children in urban areas were malnourished. Which of the following tests of significance is the most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate test of significance, in this case, is the chi-square test. It is used to compare qualitative data between 2 groups with independent measures.

In this question,

  • Nutritional status (nourished or malnourished) is a qualitative measure.
  • Residence (Urban or rural) is again a qualitative measure.
  • Further, only these two variables are being compared. Therefore, the chi-square test is the most appropriate test of significance.

The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric (non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.

  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

Other options:

Option B: Paired t-test compares paired data or pre-intervention and post-intervention data of the same group. This doesn't apply here as the groups are not paired.

Option C: Standard error of the mean is calculated for quantitative data, with measure of central tendency as mean.

Option D: The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: A male COVID patient who was on oxygen support was discharged and was prescribed an oral anticoagulant acting at the site marked in the image below. Which of the following is the specific reversal agent for the prescribed oral agent?
questions.solution:
The oral agent acting on thrombin (factor IIa) is dabigatran, and idarucizumab is the specific reversal agent for dabigatran (oral direct thrombin inhibitor).

Idarucizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody fragment (Fab) that binds to dabigatran with an affinity 350 times higher than that of thrombin. The irreversible idarucizumab-dabigatran complex is then excreted by the kidneys. Idarucizumab is infused as two intravenous boluses, each of 2.5 g.

Other options:

Option A- Andexanet alfa is a specific reversal agent for oral factor Xa inhibitors. It is a recombinant analog of factor Xa which rapidly reverses the anti-factor Xa action and restores thrombin production.

Option B- Dabigatran is an oral direct thrombin (IIa) inhibitor. It competitively and reversibly binds the active site of thrombin and prevents the conversion of fibrinogen to fibrin. It does not require routine coagulation monitoring. It is mainly used in acute venous thromboembolism after initiating parenteral anticoagulation and in the secondary prevention of venous thromboembolism. It is also considered as the oral anticoagulant of choice in discharged COVID-19 patients. Dabigatran is contraindicated in patients having mechanical heart valves.

Option C- Protamine sulfate given intravenously can be used for the rapid reversal of heparin overdose. It binds tightly to heparin. 1 mg of protamine sulfate neutralizes 100 units of heparin. Protamine binds only long heparin molecules, thereby making it a partial reversal agent for low-molecular-weight heparin.

Specific reversal agents for anticoagulants:

  • Heparin: Protamine sulfate
  • Warfarin: Vitamin K
  • Oral Xa inhibitors: Andexanet alfa
  • Dabigatran: Idarucizumab

questions.text: A boy came to the hospital with complaints of diplopia and progressive headache. Examination of extraocular movements revealed the findings as shown in the image when the patient attempted to look right. At what level of the brainstem does the affected cranial nerve nucleus arise?
questions.solution:
The clinical finding shown in the image is suggestive of lateral rectus palsy of the right eye. This occurs due to the lesion involving the abducens nerve. The abducens nerve nucleus arises at the level of facial colliculus in the pons. 

Facial colliculus is present at the floor of the fourth ventricle at the level of the lower pontine tegmentum. This colliculus contains the abducens nerve nucleus and the fibers of the internal genu of the facial nerve which travels around the abducens nerve nucleus as shown in the image above. The abducens nerve then emerges out of the brainstem between the pons and the medulla and runs through the Dorello's canal. The abducens nerve then enters the superior orbital fissure via the cavernous sinus and innervates the lateral rectus muscle.

Determining the palsy:

The abduction and adduction of the eye are caused by the action of the lateral rectus and medial rectus muscles respectively. The lateral rectus is innervated by the abducens nerve (VI) while the medial rectus is innervated by the oculomotor nerve (III).

Horizontal conjugate movements occur when both eyes move horizontally to look right or left.

  • In right gaze: The right eye abducts and the left eye adducts.
  • In left gaze: The right eye adducts and the left eye abducts.

In the image, when the patient attempted to look right, the left eye adducted normally, while the right eye failed to abduct. This is suggestive of right lateral rectus palsy due to the lesion involving the right abducens nerve.

Note: If the same finding as shown in the image is seen when the patient is looking straight (neutral gaze), then the affected eye is the left eye. In such a case, due to left lateral rectus palsy, the action of the left medial rectus is unopposed causing adduction of the left eye.

Other options:

Option A: The superior colliculus lies in the upper midbrain. At this level, the oculomotor nerve nucleus is present and the nerve emerges out of the midbrain.

Option B: Inferior colliculus lies in the lower midbrain. At this level, the trochlear nerve nucleus is present.

Option D: The inferior olivary nucleus is present in the superior half of the medulla. At this level, the hypoglossal nerve is present.

Related Pearl: Origins of cranial nerves at the base of the brain

Cranial nerve origins as seen in gross anatomy:

  • III cranial nerve: Midbrain at the level of the superior colliculus.  
  • IV cranial nerve: Midbrain at the level of inferior colliculus - the only nerve the exits from the dorsal aspect
  • V cranial nerve: The substance of pons 
  • VI, VII, and VIII cranial nerves:  Pontomedullary junction
  • IX, X, and XI cranial nerves(nucleus ambiguus): Posterolateral sulcus   
  • XII cranial nerve: Anterolateral sulcus (between pyramid and olive)

Related Pearl: Functional components of cranial nerves

Functional components of cranial nerves 
Oculomotor: CN-3
  • Extraocular skeletal muscles – GSE
  • Preganglionic fibres to ciliary ganglion - GVE
Trochlear: CN-4
  • Extraocular skeletal muscle (SO)- GSE
Trigeminal: CN-5
  • Sensation from the face - GSA
  • Motor to 1st arch - Br E (SVE)
Abducent: CN-6
  • Extraocular skeletal muscle (lateral rectus)- GSE
Facial: CN-7
  • General sensory from ear - GSA
  • Special (taste) sensation - Br A
  • Motor to 2nd arch - Br E
  • Parasympathetic to submandibular and pterygopalatine ganglia - GVE
Vestibulocochlear: CN-8
  • Hearing/balance - SSA
Glossopharyngeal: CN-9
  • Sensory from pharynx/tongue – GVA
  • Taste - Br A
  • General sensation from ear – GSA
  • Parasympathetic to otic ganglion - GVE
  • Motor to 3rd arch - Br E
Vagus: CN-10
  • Sensory from ear - GSA
  • Sensory from pharynx/larynx – GVA
  • Taste - Br A
  • Parasympathetic ganglia in thorax/abdomen - GVE
  • Motor to 4th/6th arch - Br E
Accessory: CN-11
  • Motor to 6th arch (through vagus) - Br E
  • Motor to sternocleidomastoid and trapezius - GSE
Hypoglossal: CN-12
  • Motor to lingual muscles – GSE

abbr.

A - afferent , E - efferent , Br - Branchial (word special (derived from branchial arches) can also be used instead of branchial, but due to confusion with special sensory (carrying special senses) its better avoided), V - Visceral, G - General, CN - cranial nerve,  SO - superior oblique muscle.

Related Pearl: Extraocular Muscles and Their Actions

questions.text: Preganglionic fibers originating from the inferior salivatory nucleus will pass through ______.
questions.solution:
Preganglionic fibers originating from the inferior salivatory nucleus will pass through otic ganglion.

The preganglionic fibers of otic ganglion originate in the inferior salivatory nucleus and join the glossopharyngeal nerve and its tympanic branch. They travel via the tympanic plexus, lesser petrosal nerve, and pass through the foramen ovale and synapse in the otic ganglion. Postganglionic fibers give communicating branches to the auriculotemporal nerve, which supplies to the parotid gland. When the lesser petrosal nerve is stimulated, it produces vasodilator and secretomotor effects.


Other options:

Option A: Preganglionic fibers originating from the Edinger–Westphal nucleus will pass through the ciliary ganglion.

Option C and D: Preganglionic fibers originating from the superior salivatory nucleus will pass through the pterygopalatine ganglion and submandibular ganglion.

questions.text: A 66-year-old chronic smoker who was diagnosed with small cell carcinoma of the lung presents to the casualty with nausea, confusion, and dizziness. After the initial workup, he is diagnosed to have syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion (SIADH). This condition is characterized by which of the following findings?

choices.text: Hyponatremia and urine sodium excretion > 20 mEq/L
Hypernatremia and urine sodium excretion > 20 mEq/L
Hyponatremia and urine sodium excretion < 20 mEq/L
Hypernatremia and urine sodium excretion < 20 mEq/L

questions.solution:
The syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion (SIADH) is associated with increased urinary excretion of sodium (urine sodium excretion > 20 mEq/L), and hyponatremia.

Small cell lung cancer is commonly associated with SIADH due to the ectopic release of antidiuretic hormone.

Related Pearl: Causes of SIADH

Neoplasms

Carcinomas

  • Lung
  • Duodenum
  • Pancreas
  • Ovary
  • Bladder, ureter

Other neoplasms

  • Thymoma
  • Mesothelioma
  • Bronchial adenoma
  • Carcinoid
  • Gangliocytoma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma

Head trauma (closed and penetrating)

Infections

  • Pneumonia
  • Abscess
  • Cavitation (aspergillosis)
  • Tuberculosis
  • Meningitis, Encephalitis
  • AIDS

Vascular

  • Cerebrovascular occlusions, haemorrhage
  • Cavernous sinus thrombosis

Neurologic

  • Guillain-Barre syndrome
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Delirium tremens
  • Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
  • Hydrocephalus

  • Serotonin reuptake inhibitors

  • Cyclophosphamide

  • Monoamine oxidase inhibitors

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman was diagnosed with chronic immune thrombocytopenic purpura 12 months back. She was on corticosteroids and now presents with features shown in the image after the glucocorticoids are tapered. Her platelet count is 6000/μL. What is the next appropriate step of management in this case?
questions.solution:
The next appropriate step in the management in this case is splenectomy.

The given image shows petechiae of the oral mucosa. The appearance of such lesions after more than a month of glucocorticoid treatment in an individual who is diagnosed with immune thrombocytopenic purpura suggests a relapse. Splenectomy is used for the treatment of patients who relapse after glucocorticoids are tapered.

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is an acquired disorder characterized by immune-mediated destruction of platelets and possibly inhibition of platelet release from the megakaryocyte. Secondary causes of ITP are:

  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
  • HIV-AIDS
  • Hepatitis C.

ITP usually presents with mucocutaneous bleeding, very low platelet count, and normal peripheral blood cells. Patients usually present either with ecchymoses and petechiae or with thrombocytopenia incidentally found on a routine blood test. Mucocutaneous bleeding, such as oral mucosa, gastrointestinal, or heavy menstrual bleeding, may be present.

Rarely, life-threatening, including the central nervous system, bleeding can occur. Blood blisters in the mouth and retinal haemorrhages may herald life-threatening bleeding.

Management of ITP:

  • In patients with platelet counts >30,000/μL, treatment may be instituted if there are symptoms of life-threatening bleeding.
  • Prednisone at 1 mg/kg is the initial treatment of choice.
  • Rh(D) immune globulin is used only in Rh-positive patients.
  • Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG).
  • Splenectomy is indicated in patients who have relapsed on glucocorticoid therapy. Relapse patients with intermittent or high platelet count can be managed with anti-Rh0(D) immunoglobulin, IVIG, or with a thrombopoietin receptor antagonist.
  • Subcutaneous romiplostim and oral eltrombopag are thrombopoietin receptor agonists used in adults who are at risk of bleeding even after splenectomy.

questions.text: A gynecologist is examining a 38-year-old female patient with a retroverted uterus. What is the lowest part of the cervix palpated by the examining finger in this case?
questions.solution:
In a retroverted uterus, the external os of the cervix is directed downward and forward; therefore, the lowest part of the cervix is either the external os or the posterior lip.

In anteversion, the external os is directed downward and backwards; therefore, on vaginal examination, the lowest part of the cervix felt by the fingers is the anterior lip.

Anteflexion of the uterus is at the level of Internal os. 

Angle of Anteversion Angle of Anteflexion
The angle between the cervix and vagina The angle between cervix and uterus
90o 120o
(Remember: V for version, V for vagina)

questions.text:
Match the following type of porphyrias with the enzyme deficiency involved:
Column A Column B
1. Uroporphyrinogen III synthase A) Acute intermittent porphyria
2. Coproporphyrinogen oxidase B) Porphyria cutanea tarda
3. Ferrochetalase C) Congenital erythropoietic porphyria
4. Uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase D) Erythropoietic protoporphyria
5. Uroporphyrinogen I synthase E) Hereditary coproporphyria
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-C, 2-E, 3-D, 4-B, 5-A.

Porphyrias are a group of metabolic disorders caused due to defects in heme biosynthesis. 

The classification of porphyrias based on their enzyme deficiencies is as shown below:

Enzyme deficiency

 Name of the condition
1. ALA dehydratase ALA dehydratase deficiency
2. Uroporphyrinogen I synthase Acute intermittent porphyria
3. Uroporphyrinogen III synthase Congenital erythropoietin porphyria
4. Uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase Porphyria cutanea tarda
5. Coproporphyrinogen oxidase Hereditary coproporphyria
6. Protoporphyrinogen oxidase Variegate porphyria
7. Ferrochetalase Erythropoietic Protoporphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria
  • Erythropoietic porphyria

Hepatic porphyria is caused due to enzyme deficiency early in the pathway of heme synthesis. There is an accumulation of ALA and PBG. The patient principally presents with neurovisceral symptoms.

Erythropoietic porphyria is caused due to enzyme deficiency late in the pathway of heme synthesis. There is an accumulation of porphyrins which leads to cutaneous photosensitivity.

The following classification is used for the six common porphyrias:

  • Cutaneous disease only:
    • Porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT)
    • Congenital erythropoietic porphyria (CEP)
    • Erythropoietic protoporphyria (EPP)
  • Cutaneous disease and acute attacks:
    • Hereditary coproporphyria (HC)
    • Variegate porphyria (VP)
  • Acute attacks only:
    • Acute intermittent porphyria (AIP)

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

Most porphyrias are autosomal dominant except:
  • ALAD enzyme deficiency porphyria
  • Congenital erythropoietic porphyria
  • Erythropoietic protoporphyria
  • X-linked protoporphyria

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is referred to your centre for evaluation of short stature. The child's parents are found to be first cousins. Further evaluation led to the diagnosis of Laron-type dwarfism. What causes this condition?
questions.solution:
Laron-type dwarfism, also known as GH-insensitivity syndrome, is characterized by GH-receptor anomalies.

Laron-type dwarfism is an autosomal recessive disorder. The primary clinical symptom associated with this condition is short stature. Treatment is by subcutaneous injections of insulin-like growth factor 1 (a growth-promoting hormone), often called IGF-1.

questions.text: While vacationing in Goa, an 18-year-old girl develops small itchy wheals ten minutes after stepping into the sun. They are prominent over her face, neck, and arms. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of solar urticaria. The wheals develop within minutes of sun exposure and are common on sun-exposed areas.

Solar urticaria is a type of induced urticaria that occurs in response to visible or UV radiation and usually fades within 1-2 hours.

Option A: Cholinergic urticaria presents with small wheals that occur due to sweating and a rise in core body temperature. Though it can also occur following sun exposure, it is more pronounced in the covered parts of the body, where the temperature is higher.

Option B: Heat contact urticaria is a rare form of urticaria that develops following localized warming of skin. It lasts for about one hour.

Option C: Polymorphic light eruption, urticarial lesions appear hours later and last for days after exposure to sunlight.

questions.text: A baby is found to have a soft, circumscribed, fluctuant, and incompressible swelling on the scalp following a ventouse-assisted delivery. On examination, mild yellowish discoloration of the skin was observed. Which of the following is false about this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cephalhematoma and ventouse application is not associated with increased incidence of cephalhematoma. 

Cephalhematoma is defined as a collection of blood between the pericranium and periosteum of the skull bone due to the rupture of small emissary veins. It is usually unilateral and occurs over the parietal bone. It may be associated with a fracture of the underlying skull bone. It can present following a normal delivery as well as a forceps delivery.

Characteristic clinical features are well-circumscribed, soft, fluctuant, and incompressible swelling which is limited by the suture lines over the affected area. It is never present at birth and develops gradually after 12-24 hours of birth.

No active treatment is necessary as the swelling resolves by blood absorption in 6–8 weeks. Prevention of infection and avoidance of trauma is important. A head CT is indicated if neurological symptoms are present.

Severe cases presenting with anemia and hyperbilirubinemia requiring blood transfusion.

Important differential diagnoses include -

Caput succedaneum is a diffuse, boggy swelling that occurs due to the stagnation of fluid in the layers of the scalp beneath the girdle of contact. It is not limited by the suture line and disappears spontaneously within 24 hours after birth. 

Meningocele, overlying a suture line or fontanel, presents with an impulse on crying.

Sub-galeal hemorrhage is a large and diffuse collection of blood under the aponeurosis of the scalp which is not restricted by the sutures. It may be complicated by hypovolemic shock. 

Given below is a schematic representation of scalp swellings.

Related Pearl: Caput succedaneum and Cephalohematoma

Indicators Caput Succedaneum Cephalhematoma
Location Presenting part of the head The periosteum of skull bone and bone
Time of appearance  Immediately after birth Several hours after birth
Cause Prolonged labor, causing venous stasis and edema  Instrumental delivery, causes rupture of emissary veins in skull
Extent of movement Both hemispheres; crosses the suture line Individual bones; do not cross the suture lines
Period of absorption 2-4 days 2 weeks to 3 months
Treatment None

Supportive.

It can cause neonatal jaundice

questions.text: A 22-year-old primigravida at 37 weeks of gestation presented to the obstetric emergency room in uncomplicated active labor at 3 pm. She delivered a female baby at 5.30 pm. Which of the following statement is true regarding the diagnosis in this case?

choices.text: Atonic uterus is not a complication
Controlled delivery of the head is tried

questions.solution:
The diagnosis of the given clinical scenario where the first and second stage of labor occurs within 3hrs is precipitate labor The true statement is that controlled delivery of the head is tried.

Precipitate labor:

Labor is called a precipitate when the combined duration of the first and second stages is less than 3 hours. It is common in multiparae. Rapid expulsion is due to the combined effect of hyperactive uterine contractions associated with diminished soft tissue resistance.

Maternal complications:

  • PPH due to uterine atony
  • Uterine rupture.
  • Uterine inversion
  • Infection
  • Amniotic fluid embolism

Fetal complications include Intracranial hemorrhage and brachial plexus injury.

Management includes hospitalization of a patient with a previous history of precipitate labor. During labor, uterine contraction may be suppressed by administering ether or magnesium sulfate during contractions but they are seldom effective. Delivery of the head should be controlled. Episiotomy should be done liberally. Elective induction of labor by low rupture of membranes and conduction of controlled delivery is helpful. Oxytocin augmentation should be avoided.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old male patient presents with a history of fever, headache, ataxia, nausea, and vomiting. On examination, neck rigidity is present, and hip and knee flexion occurs on passive flexion of the neck. The findings of the cerebrospinal fluid analysis are given below. Identify the organism responsible.

Opening pressure - 200 mmH2O

WBCs - 7000/µL, with neutrophil predominance

CSF glucose concentration - 1.2 mmol/L

CSF/serum glucose ratio - 0.2 

CSF protein - 0.7 g/L

Latex agglutination - positive

Limulus lysate test - negative
questions.solution:
The clinical picture and CSF examination findings are suggestive of bacterial meningitis. The causative organism is Streptococcus pneumoniae. 

Although all the other organisms are also causative of bacterial meningitis, the Limulus lysate test is negative. The Limulus amebocyte lysate assay test is positive in gram-negative organisms and Streptococcus pneumoniae is a gram-positive organism. The test has a specificity of 85–100% and a sensitivity approaching 100%.

The classic clinical triad of fever, headache, and neck rigidity is suggestive of meningitis. Other common complaints are nausea, vomiting, and photophobia. Nuchal rigidity (“stiff neck”) is the pathognomonic sign of meningitis. Hip and knee flexion on passive flexion of the neck is called Brudzinsky's sign.

Following are the classical CSF examination features suggestive of bacterial meningitis.

Opening pressure  >180 mmH2O
WBC

10/μL to 10,000/μL; neutrophils predominate
RBC Absent in non-traumatic tap
Glucose

<2.2 mmol/L (<40 mg/dL)
CSF/serum glucose <0.4
Protein

>0.45 g/L (>45 mg/dL)
Latex agglutination

May be positive in 

Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitidis, Haemophilus influenzae type b, Escherichia coli, group B streptococci
Limulus lysate Positive in gram-negative meningitis
Culture Positive in >80%

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with multiple rib fractures after a car accident. On examination, her neck veins are distended, heart sounds are muffled and chest movements are normal. A 2D echocardiography showed the following.  What is the appropriate immediate treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The above scenario with the echocardiography showing a swinging heart is suggestive of pericardial effusion with tamponade. The most appropriate immediate treatment is to perform a needle pericardiocentesis.

Pericardiocentesis, also known as pericardial tap, can be performed with sub-xiphoid, parasternal, or apical approaches. The most common approach is a sub-xiphoid approach under echocardiographic guidance.

This patient has multiple rib fractures which likely have pierced the pericardium and/or the heart muscle. This leads to the accumulation of blood in the pericardial space. This space is non-distensible so fluid can compress the heart and impair contraction leading to decreased cardiac output. It also obstructs venous return which further reduces filling. 

Cardiac tamponade is the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space. It will result in the obstruction of the blood flow into the ventricles.

This manifests as Beck's triad, which consists of the following: 

  • Distended neck veins (due to decreased venous return)
  • Muffled heart sounds (fluid accumulation in the pericardial space)
  • Hypotension

The chest wall movements will be normal. Echocardiography may show the swinging heart sign which suggests pericardial effusion with tamponade. An eFAST is reliable and will show fluid in the pericardial space. A chest X-ray will show an enlarged heart shadow.

Cardiac tamponade can also be treated with open surgery procedures like sternotomy or left thoracotomy. This also allows for the heart to be repaired during the procedure. 

Other options: 

Option A: A pericardial window done via the subxiphoid or trans-diaphragmatic approach is the best way to diagnose and treat cardiac tamponade. It allows for drainage of blood and exploration of the area for the damage. It must be done under general anesthesia. This is the definitive management.

Option C: Chest tube insertion is used in massive hemothorax. Here, the accumulation of blood in the cavity severely restricts lung movements leading to inadequate ventilation. An appropriately placed chest tube can rapidly drain large amounts of blood. 

Option D: Analgesia is administered in cases of flail chest. This is because the pain from the rib fractures will further compromise respiratory movements. This patient's chest movements are normal. It is supplemented with oxygen administration and physiotherapy. 

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: A primigravida came with complaints of lower abdominal pain radiating to the groin at 35 weeks of gestation. However, on examination, there was no dilatation of the cervix. Which of the following features if present would make false labor pain the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
False labor pain is relieved by enema or sedatives. 

False labor pain (also known as spurious labor pain or Braxton Hicks contractions) is seen more in primigravidae than in parous women. It usually appears prior to the onset of true labor pain by 1 or 2 weeks in primigravidae and by a few days in multiparae. It is due to cervical and lower uterine stretching with simultaneous irritation of the neighboring ganglia.

The following table gives the comparison between true and false labor pains:

Property True labor pain False labor pain
Character Painful Dull
Location Front of the abdomen and radiates towards the thighs Lower abdomen and groin
Uterine consistency Progressive hardening No hardening
Intervals Occurs at regular intervals Absent
Contractions Progressive increase in frequency, duration, and intensity Absent
Show Present Absent
Bag of waters Formed Absent
Progressive effacement and dilatation Present Absent
Descent of Presenting part Present  Absent
Relief by enema or sedatives Absent Present

 

With the onset of labor, cervical mucous plug along with blood is expelled which is known as show.

The membranes get detached easily due to the stretch of the lower uterine segment and the lower pole of fetal membranes containing the liquor amnii become unsupported and bulge into the cervical canal in response to the cervical dilatation. This is called a bag of waters.

During uterine contraction, the bag becomes tense and convex in response to the rise in intra-amniotic pressure and after the contractions pass, the bulging disappears completely. This is almost a certain sign of the onset of labor.

questions.text: A young girl is being evaluated for low mood, anhedonia, weight loss, and insomnia since past 1 month. On examination, multiple hesitation marks were seen on her left forearm. She was diagnosed with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) one year back. Which of the following autoantibodies is associated with this presentation?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of depression in a patient with SLE. It is associated with anti-ribosomal P antibodies.

Antiribosomal P antibody is associated with psychosis or depression in SLE.

More common in black & asians than white

This is not a useful clinical test

(includes antiglutamate receptor)		 60 Neuronal & lymphocyte surface antigens In some series, a positive test in CSF correlates with active CNS lupus

questions.text: A victim of a homicide was found in a ditch. The body is sent for forensic examination and the victim is estimated to have been dead for a period of 15-20 hours. Which of the following changes is least likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the victim has been dead for 15-20 hours and hence, adipocere is not likely to be seen. Adipocere is a late sign of death that occurs days to months after death.

Adipocere formation or corpse wax is a late sign of death. A wax-like organic substance is formed by the anaerobic hydrolysis or hydrogenation of fat in tissues. It has a greyish-white appearance with a distinctive offensive or sweetish smell. The usual time for adipocere formation is between 3 to 6 months. But in countries like India, it is accelerated by the warm and humid weather, resulting in the beginning of adipocere formation as early as 3 to 15 days after death. 

Postmortem changes are classified on the basis of time:

  • Immediate signs of death (at the time of somatic or clinical death):
    • Insensibility and loss of voluntary power
    • Cessation of respiration
    • Cessation of circulation
  • Early signs of death (cellular death that is observed in the first 12 to 24 hours of death):
    • Pallor and loss of elasticity of the skin
    • Eye changes
    • Primary flaccidity of muscles
    • Algor mortis/Postmortem cooling
    • Postmortem lividity/Suggillation
    • Rigor mortis
  • Late signs of death:
    • Putrefaction
    • Adipocere
    • Mummification

Other options:

Option A: Suggilation/ Postmortem hypostasis/ Postmortem staining/ Livor mortis refers to purple or reddish-purple discoloration of the skin due to the collection of blood in toneless capillaries in the dependent parts of the body. Fixation of hypostasis occurs 6-12 hours after death and persists until putrefaction sets in. 

Option B: Algor mortis/postmortem cooling is one of the early changes occurring after death. After death, the body loses heat mainly by conduction and convection. For about half to one hour after death, the rectal temperature falls very little, and then a linear rate of cooling occurs for the next 12-16 hours. 

Option D: Rigor mortis refers to the state of stiffening of muscles and is indicative of molecular death. It is useful in estimating the time since death. The mechanism of rigor mortis is due to muscle ATP breakdown below the critical level. It appears 2-3 hours after death.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old female patient presents with a history of fever and cough for 10 days. On examination, the pulse is 96 bpm, BP is 118/70 mmHg, the temperature is 100.4 °F, RR is 15/min and SpO2 is 96%. Laboratory reports are awaited. Chest CT, as shown below, demonstrates ground-glass opacities close to the visceral pleural surfaces and visible intralobular lines. Which CO-RADS category does this patient fall under?

CO-RADS - COVID-19 Reporting and Data System
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation is highly suspicious of COVID-19. The chest CT findings of ground-glass opacities near the visceral pleural line and crazy paving place this patient under CO-RADS 5 (COVID-19 Reporting and Data System).

CO-RADS 5 implies a very high level of suspicion for pulmonary involvement by COVID-19 based on typical CT findings. It requires the presence of at least one confirmatory pattern. 

Typical features for pulmonary involvement by COVID-19:

Obligatory features:

  • Ground-glass opacities, with or without consolidation, in regions close to the visceral pleural lines, including the fissures
  • Multifocal bilateral distribution

Confirmatory patterns:

  • Ground-glass regions
    • Unsharp, rounded shape
    • Sharp demarcation, outlining the shape of multiple adjacent pulmonary lobules
  • Crazy paving 
  • Patterns compatible with organizing pneumonia
  • Thickened vessels within parenchymal abnormalities 

CO-RADS uses a five-point scale to report suspicion for pulmonary involvement of COVID-19 on chest CT. The CO-RADS categories are as follows:

CO-RADS 0: Not interpretable, and technically insufficient to assign a score 

CO-RADS 1: Very low level of suspicion for pulmonary involvement by COVID-19. CT findings are normal or of unequivocal non-infectious etiology; e.g. mild or severe emphysema, perifissural nodules, lung tumors, or fibrosis

CO-RADS 2: Low level of suspicion for pulmonary involvement by COVID-19; includes infectious etiology that is not compatible with COVID-19 such as bronchitis, bronchiolitis, bronchopneumonia, lobar pneumonia, and abscess

CO-RADS 3: Equivocal findings for pulmonary involvement by COVID-19; findings overlap with other infectious etiologies; could include perihilar ground-glass, homogenous extensive ground-glass, with or without sparing of secondary pulmonary lobules

CO-RADS 4: High level of suspicion for pulmonary involvement by COVID-19; findings are similar to those of CO-RADS 5 but are not present in the typical locations; findings may also be superimposed on severe pre-existing pulmonary abnormalities 

CO-RADS 5: Very high level of suspicion for pulmonary involvement by COVID-19 based on typical CT findings mentioned above

CO-RADS 6: Proven COVID-19 by positive RT-PCR test.

questions.text: A male patient is brought to the hospital with generalized weakness and a history of diarrhea. He also gave a history of removal of renal stones 6 months back. Investigations reveals metabolic acidosis and hypokalemia. Urine analysis shows a pH of 5.9, positive urine anion gap, hypocitraturia, and hypercalciuria. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is renal tubular acidosis - type 1 (RTA-1)  or distal renal tubular acidosis. The history of diarrhea and renal stones with metabolic acidosis, urine with pH>5.5, hypokalemia, positive urine anion gap, and hypercalciuria are characteristic findings of RTA-1.

RTA-1 occurs due to defective urinary acidification in the cortical collecting tubule due to ineffective H+ ion secretion by the alpha-intercalated cells. This leads to the formation of urine with pH > 5.5. The decreased H+ secretion also leads to inadequate HCO3- regeneration in the alpha-intercalated cells thus leading to metabolic acidosis. As H+ is usually exchanged with K+ from the lumen in the DCT, decreased H+ secretion is also associated with decreased K+ absorption, resulting in hypokalemia.

Acidosis reduces net proximal fluid reabsorption, which leads to volume contraction and activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). This results in decreased proximal tubular Na+ reabsorption and increased distal delivery of Na+ to the cortical collecting duct. These processes, along with increased aldosterone secretion, leading to increased K+ secretion by activation of ENaC (epithelial sodium channel) channels in the collecting duct thus causing hypokalemia.

Ammonium produced as a result of glutamine metabolism is secreted in the proximal tubule, which normally combines with H+ ions secreted in the alpha-intercalated cells of the distal tubule to form NH4+ ions. Since this process is impaired in RTA-1, the urine anion gap (UAG) is positive due to low urine NH4+ concentration. RTA-1 is associated with hypercalciuria and with persistent alkaline urine it is a risk factor for developing calcium phosphate stones. 

Other options:

Option A- Renal tubular acidosis - type 2 or proximal RTA occurs due to generalized proximal tubule dysfunction. Defective HCO3- resorption is the primary dysfunctional mechanism causing metabolic acidosis and is also associated with glycosuria, aminoaciduria, and phosphaturia.

In the initial stages of the disease or during HCO3- replacement the urine remains alkaline, but as HCO3- losses continue, the urine turns acidic with pH <5.5. There is no defect in the urine concentrating mechanism at the cortical collecting tubule, thus urine NH4+ concentration is normal and UAG is negative. There is no associated hypercalciuria.

Option C- Renal tubular acidosis - type 4 also known as pseudohypoaldosteronism occurs due to end-organ resistance to aldosterone and is characterized by hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis, and a positive UAG.

Option D- Alport syndrome is caused by mutations affecting type IV collagen that result in hematuria with progression to chronic renal failure, sensorineural deafness, and various eye disorders, including lens dislocation, posterior cataracts, and corneal dystrophy.

questions.text: The ophthalmologist performs the following test which reveals the following findings. Which of the following is seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The image shows Marcus Gunn pupil/afferent pupillary defect confirmed by the swinging-flashlight test. The right eye is affected, while the left eye is normal.

The flashlight is swung to and fro and the pupillary response is observed. Normally, both pupils remain constricted. In the presence of RAPD (Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect), both pupils dilate on moving the flashlight from the normal to the abnormal eye. This paradoxical response of the pupil to light is called Marcus Gunn pupil.

Impaired pupillary constriction due to a defect in the afferent pathway of the pupillary light reflex in one eye, causes a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) or a Marcus-Gunn pupil on a swinging flashlight test. 

It is the earliest sign of optic nerve disease. It also occurs in severe retinal disease.

The following image shows the swinging flashlight test as seen in a normal person and in a patient with a right relative afferent pupillary defect.

Other options:

Option B: Argyll Robertson pupils (AR pupils) are bilateral small pupils with light-near dissociation. It is a specific sign in neurosyphilis and is due to a lesion in the pretectal nucleus. When light is shone on the pupils, they do not react. However, they contract on convergence. 

Option C: The tonic pupil of Adie is a dilated pupil with light-near dissociation due to postganglionic parasympathetic pupillomotor damage. The affected pupil is dilated. When light is shone on the pupil, constriction is present but is of low magnitude. It has sluggish reaction to convergenece.

Option D: An absolute afferent pupillary defect (amaurotic pupil) is caused by a complete optic nerve lesion where the involved eye is completely blind. When light is shone on the affected eye, neither pupil constricts. When light is shone on the normal eye, both pupils constrict.

questions.text: A middle-aged man from West Africa developed sudden onset of fever and chills, severe headache, cough, sore throat, muscle, and joint pain. This was followed by abdominal pain and vomiting. The electron microscopy image of the likely causative agent is given below. To which bioterrorism category does it belong?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the electron microscopy image is suggestive of Ebola virus infection. It belongs to category A bioterrorism.

Ebolaviruses are long, thread-like viruses. They belong to the genus Filovirus. Three strains of the Ebola virus have been recognized: the Zaire strain (EBO-Z) with a case fatality rate of 90 percent, the Sudan strain (EBO-S) with a case fatality rate of 50 percent, and the mild Reston strain (EBO-R).

The incubation period is 3 - 25 days. The infected people develop biphasic syndrome with a 1 to 2-day relative remission. The first phase resembles influenza, characterized by sudden onset of fever and chills, severe headaches, cough, myalgia, pharyngitis, arthralgia of the larger joints, and development of a maculopapular rash. The second phase is characterized by abdominal pain with vomiting and/or diarrhea, chest pain, cough, postural hypotension, edema, and confusion, coma, headache. Hemorrhagic manifestations such as subconjunctival injection, epistaxis, hematemesis, hematuria, and melena are typical.

It spreads from person to person through direct contact with body fluids such as blood, urine, sweat, semen, and breast milk. Viral particles can be found in semen up to 61 days after illness onset from recovered cases.

Diagnosis is made through the detection of Ebola virus antigen, RNA, or antibodies in the blood. Treatment includes supportive care with aggressive fluid and electrolyte replacement

Bioterrorism is the deliberate release of an agent by attackers that causes one or more of a variety of different diseases. Category A (High risk) pose a threat to national security and has the ability to cause social disruption. Examples include Ebola, anthrax, botulism, plague, smallpox, and tularemia.

Related Pearl: Bioterrorism Agents
