questions.text: A patient presented with a deformity as shown in the image below. What is this deformity known as?
questions.solution:
In the given image, the midline of the dorsum of the nose is deviated to one side. This type of nose is called the deviated nose. 

Deviated nose 

Deviated nasal septum (DNS) is an important cause of nasal obstruction. It may be due to trauma, developmental errors, racial and hereditary factors.

DNS is associated with the following symptoms:

  • Nasal obstruction- Deviated nasal septum may lead to obstruction of the nasal cavity at different levels based on the type of deviation:
    • Vestibular- due to caudal septal dislocation, synechiae or stenosis
    • At the nasal valve- due to synechiae, usually post rhinoplasty
    • Attic (along the upper part of nasal septum)- due to high septal deviation
    • Turbinal- due to hypertrophic turbinates or concha bullosa
    • Choanal- due to choanal atresia or a choanal polyp
  • Chronic sinusitis- Deviated septum causes obstruction to the ostia of the sinuses. This causes poor ventilation of the sinuses leading to sinusitis.
  • Headache- Deviated septum or the spur may press on the lateral wall of the nose leading to pressure headache. Headache can also be due to sinusitis.
  • Turbinate hypertrophy- Because of chronic sinusitis
  • Middle ear infection
  • Epistaxis- There is drying of the mucosa over the deviated septum due to air currents. This leads to the formation of crusts which, on removal, cause epistaxis.
  • Anosmia- reduced airflow may lead to anosmia
  • External deformity- External deformities of the septum may be seen due to deviation of the cartilaginous or the bony part of the nasal septum. Deformity of the tip or columella may also be seen.

Option B: Crooked nose deformity - The midline of the nose from the frontonasal angle to the tip is curved. The curvature may be C-shaped or S-shaped. 

 

Option C: Hump nose is due to excess of bony or cartilaginous dorsum.

Option D: Saddle nose is depressed nasal dorsum.

questions.text: Paroxysmal AV block is a type of which of the following types of atrioventricular blocks, as represented by their ECG patterns?
questions.solution:
Paroxysmal AV block is a series of non conducted P waves associated with Mobitz type II Second-degree AV block, which is depicted by the ECG pattern shown in image 1.

Paroxysmal AV block occurs in the presence of significant conductive system disease and warrants the use of a pacemaker.

Mobitz type II block is characterized by an intermittent failure of conduction of the p wave without any change in the preceding impulses. Bradyarrhythmias that cause syncope include those due to severe sinus node dysfunction and AV block (Mobitz type II block, complete AV block). Syncope due to bradycardia or asystole is referred to as Stokes-Adams attack.

The dropped QRS is marked in the image below:

Other options: 

Image B: It shows an ECG recording with prolonged PR interval (> 0.2s) and equal RR intervals. This is indicative of First Degree Heart Block.

Image C: It shows an ECG recording with the following findings:

  • Escape rhythm
  • RR equal, PP equal
  • P waves > QRS waves
  • No relationship between P & QRS

This is seen in Third Degree Heart Block/Complete Heart Block

Image D: It shows an ECG recording with progressive PR elongartion leading to an eventual drop of the QRS complex. This may be seen in young athletes and is indicative of Second-degree heart block (Mobitz type 1/ Wenckebach phenomenon)

Related Pearl: Types of Heart block

questions.text: A patient presented with paradoxical respiration. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
Paradoxical respiration occurs due to the damage of the phrenic nerve, which is marked as D, in the given image.

The structures marked in the image are:

A. Right vagus nerve

B. Left vagus nerve

C. Recurrent laryngeal nerve

D. Right phrenic nerve

Paradoxical movements in the chest are as follows:

  • Paradoxical respiration - the abnormal movement of the chest wall or abdominal wall, where they move in during inspiration instead of moving out. It is seen in flail chest. 
  • Paradoxical movement of the diaphragm - normally, the diaphragm moves down during inspiration. However, in cases of phrenic nerve palsy, the affected side of the diaphragm moves upward (paradoxical respiration) due to diaphragmatic paralysis. The gold standard investigation to detect this is the electrical or magnetic stimulation of the phrenic nerve with a recording of the compound muscle action potential and/or the transdiaphragmatic pressure. This can be observed on ultrasound or fluoroscopy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is posted for a hysterosalpingogram, but she is now in the premenstrual phase. All of the following are noted risks associated with hysterosalpingogram done during the premenstrual period except?

choices.text: If by chance pregnancy has occurred, it can dislodge

questions.solution:
All the options are risks associated with a hysterosalpingogram done in the premenstrual period except tubal block. In fact, HSG is done to detect it.

Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is a technique used for visualization of the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes by the injection of a radioopaque dye, and visualization of the dye by fluoroscopy as it passes through the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes.

It is best performed between the end of the menstrual period and ovulation (i.e 9th or 10th day of the cycle).

10-15ml of the dye is injected using a Leech-Wilkinson cannula, Rubin's cannula, or Foley's catheter. If the tubes are patent, the dye will spill out of the tubal Ostia and smear the adjacent bowel.

It is used to detect:

  • Tubal block. This can be due to strictures (fibrotic block), inspissated amorphous material, or spasms. The tubal spasm can occur in an apprehensive woman and this is prevented by premedication with atropine and analgesia.
  • Uterine anomalies
  • Uterine polyps
  • Uterine synechiae
  • The feasibility of tuboplasty, by studying the location and extent of tubal pathology.

Contraindications:

  • Presence of genital tract infection and bleeding
  • Genital tuberculosis, due to the risk of spreading infection.
  • Suspected pregnancy
  • Allergy to the dye
  • Premenstrual phase.
    • If by chance pregnancy has occurred, it may be dislodged.
    • Thick endometrium might prevent the smooth flow of the dye, at the cornual end.
    • There is a risk of embolism and endometriosis if HSG is done during this phase.

Note: Tubal spasms can occur in any phase of the menstrual cycle, including the premenstrual phase. But, the other options are more common in the premenstrual phase as compared to tubal spasm mimicking a tubal block.

The instrument in the given image below is Rubin's cannula and is used in hysterosalpingogram recording.

The instrument in the given image is Leech-Wilkinson canula and is used in hysterosalpingogram recording.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman is diagnosed with metastatic ER-positive breast cancer. Tamoxifen therapy was started but the tumor still showed progression. She has been switched to a new drug that acts on the estrogen receptors and has to be taken only once a month. Which of the following is the new drug administered to her?
questions.solution:
Fulvestrant is the new drug administered in this case. The given clinical scenario is suggestive of (estrogen receptor) ER-positive breast cancer, resistant to tamoxifen therapy. 

Fulvestrant is an estrogen antagonist which is indicated in postmenopausal women with hormone-positive breast cancer, which is progressive even after first-line therapy such as tamoxifen.

It is a pure estrogen antagonist with no agonist action. Fulvestrant is a selective estrogen-receptor down regulator (SERD).

It binds to ERα and ERβ with high affinity but represses transactivation. It causes intracellular proteolytic degradation of ERα while protecting ERβ from degradation. This effect on ERα protein levels is responsible for fulvestrant’s efficacy in tamoxifen-resistant breast cancer.

It is longer acting and is administered once a month (250- 500mg) intramuscularly. It is generally well tolerated. Nausea, asthenia, and headache are common side effects. It is given as initial biweekly loading doses in the 1st month followed by once-monthly injections. Steady-state levels are achieved in the first month.

Other options:

Option A: Letrozole is an aromatase inhibitor that decreases estrogen synthesis and is widely used now in the treatment of breast cancer in postmenopausal women. Estrogen is locally produced from androgen by the action of the aromatase enzyme. Locally synthesized estrogens play an important role in the development of breast cancer because they are estrogen-dependent for proliferation. 

Options B and C: Selec­tive aromatase inhibitors block the conversion of the hormone androstenedione into estrone by inhibiting the aromatase enzyme. They include:

Reversible aromatase inhibitors:

  • Letrozole (Dose: 2.5 mg Once a day per oral)
  • Anastrozole (Dose: 1 mg Once a day per oral)
  • Vorozole

Irreversible aromatase inhibitors:

  • Exemestane (Dose: 25 mg once a day per oral after meals)
  • Formestane

These agents can also be used as the first-line treatment of breast cancer or as second-line drugs after tamoxifen therapy. They are highly efficacious and superior to tamoxifen in adjuvant use for postmenopausal women. They can either be used following tamoxifen therapy for 2–5 years or as initial agents. They do not increase the risk of uterine cancer or venous thromboemboli.

Related Pearl: Hormonal therapy in breast carcinoma given for ER/PR-positive cases

Role:

  • Reduce risk of recurrence
  • Reduce risk of contralateral breast cancer
  • Reduce risk of progression of in situ to invasive carcinoma
Selective estrogen- receptor modulator Aromatase inhibitors Ovarian suppression/ ablation
  • Tamoxifen
  • Raloxifen
  • Arzoxifen
  • Fenoxifen
  • Anastrazole
  • Letrozole
  • Exemestane
  • Oophorectomy
  • GnRH analogues

questions.text: A 46-year-old female patient has been recently diagnosed with breast cancer and is undergoing evaluation. As a new mother who is currently breastfeeding, she is curious about the skin changes over her breast. A representative image has been shown below. What is the mechanism for these skin changes?
questions.solution:
The given image shows peau d'orange appearance seen in breast carcinoma and the mechanism for this appearance is cutaneous lymphatic edema. 

In breast cancer, lymphatic fluid accumulates in the extracellular space. In the skin over the breast, there are multiple sweat ducts. The ducts pull the skin, which restricts the swelling that occurs as a result of lymphatic edema. This results in an 'orange skin' appearance which is termed 'peau d'orange' in French. 

Breast cancer spreads locally, lymphatically, and via the bloodstream. Local infiltration involves the skin, pectoral muscles, and chest wall. Lymphatic metastasis occurs via the axillary and internal mammary lymph nodes and is considered to be a poor prognosis. Breast cancer can metastasize to the vertebrae via the bloodstream and is considered to be an advanced disease. 

Other options

Option A - Infiltration of the skin with carcinoma is seen in cancer-en-cuirasse. It usually occurs as a result of local reoccurrence after mastectomy. Other than palliative treatment, there is no specific treatment for this condition. 

Option B - Infection from a cracked nipple is seen in lactational mastitis. This occurs in breastfeeding mothers. The infecting organism ascends from the nipple and causes mastitis. It is treated with antibiotics. 

Option D - Superficial thrombophlebitis is seen in Mondor's disease. This vein appears as a thrombosed, superficial cord that distorts the breast architecture when the arm is moved. There is no specific treatment as it subsides on its own. 

The below image shows lactational mastitis in a breastfeeding mother.

Related Pearl: Important surgeries for breast cancer

  • Tylectomy: Excision of lump
  • Breast conservation surgery (BCS)/WLE (wide local excision): Tumour removal with a 3D clearance of a 1 mm margin of normal tissue
  • Simple mastectomy: Palpable extent of breast + Nipple–areola complex + overlying skin.
  • Extended simple mastectomy: Simple mastectomy + removal of level I axillary lymph nodes.
  • Skin-sparing mastectomy: Mastectomy with breast envelope preservation and nipple-areola complex removal
  • Skin+ nipple/areola-sparing mastectomy: Mastectomy with breast envelope and nipple-areola complex preservation
  • Total mastectomy: All breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin.
  • Level I oncoplasty (volume displacement surgery): Tumour excision with wide margins followed by defect repair via dual-plane mobilisation of the breast parenchyma to maintain shape and symmetry
  • Level II oncoplasty (volume replacement surgery): Skin excision and glandular mobilisation involving >20% resection of breast volume
  • Modified radical mastectomy:  Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + axillary lymph nodes (levels I + II ± III) dissection
    • Patey’s: Pectoralis minor is removed
    • Scanlon’s: Pectoralis minor incised
    • Auchincloss: Pectoralis minor only retracted
  • Halsted’s radical mastectomy: Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + Levels I + II+ III Axillary lymph nodes + Pectoralis major and minor
  • Extended radical (Urban) - Halsted’s + internal mammary lymph nodes dissection
  • Extended radical (Dahl-Iverson) mastectomy: Halsted’s + internal mammary and supraclavicular lymph nodes dissection
  • Super radical mastectomy: Halsted’s + internal mammary, supraclavicular and mediastinal lymph nodes dissection.

*Dual-plane mobilisation of breast parenchyma: Mobilisation of the dermoglandular plane and plane between breast parenchyma and pectoralis muscle.

Related Pearl: Risk Factors and Protective Factors for Breast Carcinoma

Risk factors:

  • Age: Incidence increases with increasing age.
  • Sex: more common in females.
  • Family history of breast cancer
  • Race, ethnicity (white women have increased risk compared to women of other races)
  • History of radiation exposure
  • Mammographically dense breast
  • Genetic factors:
  • Mutations in tumor suppressor genes:
    • BRCA 1
    • BRCA 2
    • TP53
    • CHEK2
  • Hereditary syndromes:
    • Li Fraumeni syndrome
    • Cowden’s syndrome
    • HNPCC syndrome
    • Peutz-Jegher’s syndrome
    • Ataxia telangiectasia
  • Hormonal factors (hyperestrogenemia is the risk factor):
    • Early menarche
    • Late menopause
    • First full-term pregnancy >30 years
    • Nulliparity
    • Obesity (postmenopausal)
  • Higher socioeconomic status, high fat diet, alcohol intake

Protective factors:

  • Early age at first pregnancy
  • Multiparity
  • Breastfeeding
  • Oophorectomy
  • Exercise
  • Tamoxifen and Aromatase inhibitors

questions.text: A young woman was brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. She opens her eyes to painful stimuli, but her speech is confused. She can localize pain on the right side, but withdraws from pain on the left side. What is her Glasgow Coma Scale score?
questions.solution:
From the given clinical scenario, the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of the patient is 11 and her component score is E2V4M5.

Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is used in the assessment of patients with a head injury. It has three components: eye-opening, verbal, and motor abilities. Each component is assigned a score, and the total score is presented as a sum of three.

  • Eye-opening: To painful stimulus = 2 
  • Verbal response: Confused = 4
  • Motor response: Localize the pain on the right side = 5

In GCS, the best motor response elicited is considered for scoring. As seen in this patient, if she can localize the pain on the right side but withdraws from pain on the left side, then the motor component of the right side would be considered, and the score would be 5. Therefore, her component score would be E2V4M5 and adding 2+4+5 gives a score of 11.

A GCS score of <8 denotes severe brain injury.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: A teenager presents with fever, malaise, skin rash and hepatomegaly. He is diagnosed with a rickettsial infection and the vector implicated in the disease is shown below. The vector can transmit all of the following diseases except:
questions.solution:
The vector shown in the image is a louse. It can transmit all diseases except endemic typhus. The vector for endemic typhus is rat flea. 

The table below shows diseases transmitted by the louse, and the causative agent:

Disease transmitted by louse   Causative agent
Epidemic typhus Rickettssia prowazeki
Relapsing fever Borrelia recurrentis
Trench fever Bartonella quintana
Pediculosis Infestation with the louse

Rickettsial infections are classified based on clinical features and epidemiology as follows:

Group

Zoonotic disease

 Vector
Typhus group  

Epidemic typhus

 Louse

Murine typhus

Flea

Scrub typhus

 Mite
Spotted fever group  

Indian tick typhus

Tick

Rocky Mountain spotted fever

 Tick

Rickettsialpox

 Mite
Others 

Q fever 

 -
Trench fever Louse

Rickettsial infections present with fever, malaise, headache, prostration, hepatosplenomegaly and a skin rash. Q fever does not have skin lesions. Tetracycline is the drug of choice for all rickettsial infections. 

Related Pearl: Lice

  • There are 3 kinds of lice. They are:
    • Head lice (Pediculus capitis)
    • Body lice (Pediculus corporis)
    • Crab louse (pubic louse – Phthirus pubis).
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a pair of antennae, three pairs of legs attached to the thorax, and a segmented abdomen.
  • The stages in their life cycle are eggs (nits), larva (nymph), and the adult, which live for 30 to 50 days.
  • They are spread by direct or indirect contact.
  • They are vectors for epidemic typhus, relapsing fever, trench fever, and pediculosis.
  • Insecticidal control of lice is mainly by malathion in the form of lotion or powder.
  • There are reports of resistance to DDT and HCH.
  • Personal hygiene is of utmost importance to prevent infestation.

Related Pearl: Rat Fleas

  • Rat fleas (Xenopsylla cheopis) belong to the genus Xenopsylla.
  • Their morphology includes a conical head, absent neck, a thorax with 3 segments, and an abdomen with 10 segments. They have three pairs of legs and no wings.
  • The four stages in their life cycle are egg, larva, pupa, and adult.
  • They cannot fly but can leap up to 6 inches horizontally.
  • They transmit diseases by biting, mechanical transmission, and feces.
  • Flea indices that are used in flea surveys are the general flea index, specific flea index, percentage incidence of flea species, and rodent infestation rate.
  • Rat fleas are vectors for endemic typhus (murine typhus), chiggerosis, bubonic plague, and Hymenolepis diminuta.
  • Insecticidal control is mainly by 10% DDT.
  • Resistance to DDT, gamma-HCH, and dieldrin has been recorded.
  • Repellants like diethyltoluamide and benzyl benzoate are efficient.
  • Rodent control also aims to reduce flea infestation.

questions.text: A 53-year-old patient presents with fever and cough, with a history of a visit to China and the consumption of pickled crayfish. He now complains of rusty sputum and cough which is suggestive of Paragonimus westermani infection. What is the infective form of this fluke?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is of Paragonimus westermani (oriental lung fluke) infection. Metacercariae encysted in crab or crayfish is the infective form.

Paragonimus westermani is a trematode. The transmission to humans occurs by eating raw or undercooked crab or crayfish containing metacercariae. The parasite is endemic to Japan, Korea, Taiwan, China, and Southeast Asia. Endemic foci of P. westermani are present in Manipur.

Definitive host: Man, and many other crab-eating mammals and domestic animals

First intermediate host: Freshwater snail

Second intermediate host: Freshwater crab or crayfish.

The adult worms live in the respiratory tract of the definitive host in cystic spaces surrounded by a fibrous capsule formed by the host tissues. Unembryonated eggs escape into the bronchi and are coughed up and voided in sputum or swallowed and passed in feces. 

Clinical features include cough, chest pain, and hemoptysis. There is viscous sputum speckled with golden-brown eggs. Demonstration of the eggs in sputum or feces provides definitive evidence.

Praziquantel (25 mg/ kg TDS for 1-2 days) is the drug of choice.

The following image shows the life cycle of Paragonimus westermani

questions.text: You are examining a 22-year-old college student whose oral cavity appears as below. You would suspect drug abuse and order a 'tox screen' for which of the following substances?
questions.solution:
The image shows a case of suspected meth mouth with a close-up shot of the lower right posterior teeth. Meth mouth is advanced tooth decay which is common in habitual methamphetamine users.

Methamphetamine is also colloquially referred to as 'ice', 'crystal', 'chalk', and 'meth'. It used to be known as 'speed' or 'go'. It can be taken by ingestion, intravenous injection, inhalation, or nasal insufflation. It enhances the release and inhibits the reuptake of catecholamines at the presynaptic terminals.

Advanced tooth decay or meth mouth is commonly seen in habitual meth abusers. It may be multifactorial and due to poor oral hygiene, dry mouth, consumption of high-carbohydrate carbonated beverages, jaw clenching, and tooth grinding.

Amphetamine intoxication is suspected in cases presenting with agitation, mydriasis, diaphoresis, tachycardia, tachypnea, hypertension, and hyperthermia, similar to cocaine intoxication. Mental status may be normal or severely agitated and paranoid.

Other options:

Option A: Chronic use of LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) can cause a flashback phenomenon. When the person re-lives the experience under the influence of a substance periodically in the absence of drug intake for months or years it is known as the flashback phenomenon.

Option B: Phencyclidine is taken orally, smoked, injected, or inhaled. It may lead to acute psychosis and violence.

Option D: Chronic use of cannabis may lead to amotivational syndrome with lethargy, and lack of interest in day-to-day activities. Run amok is a psychic disturbance resulting from continued use or sudden consumption of cannabis and is characterized by a peculiar homicidal mania. The person is not held responsible for his acts since ‘run amok’ is considered a disorder of mind and not intoxication.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old girl was admitted with a large wound on her thigh for the past 3 months. Cultures from the wound margin revealed an MRSA infection. She was given an antibiotic that binds to the subunit of the ribosome marked by the red cross and inhibits bacterial protein synthesis. Identify the drug given to this patient.

MRSA- Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus
questions.solution:
The drug given in this case is Linezolid which binds to the P site of the 50s ribosomal subunit and inhibits bacterial protein synthesis. It is an oxazolidinone that is active against various resistant organisms including methicillin-resistant staphylococci, vancomycin-resistant staphylococci. Linezolid is well absorbed orally and the bioavailability approaches 100%.

Linezolid and tedizolid are FDA approved for the treatment of skin and soft tissue infections caused by streptococci and staphylococcus aureus (MSSA and MRSA). Linezolid is also approved for the treatment of community-acquired pneumonia due to S. pneumoniae and nosocomial pneumonia due to S. aureus.

Adverse efffects of linezolid:

  • Myelosuppression (anemia, leukopenia, pancytopenia)
  • Thrombocytopenia (most common side effect) 
  • Serotonin syndrome if given along with serotonergic drugs due to monoamine oxidase (MAO) inhibition
  • Mitochondrial toxicities like peripheral neuropathy, optic neuropathy, lactic acidosis

Clinical correlate- Intravenous and oral doses for linezolid are the same because of 100% bioavailability.

Other options:

Option A - Chloramphenicol primarily binds reversibly to the 50S ribosomal subunit. It blocks the amino acid–containing end of the aminoacyl tRNA from binding to the acceptor site on the 50S ribosomal subunit. This prevents the peptide bond formation by breaking the interaction between peptidyl transferase and its amino acid substrate. One of the most important adverse effects of chloramphenicol is grey baby syndrome.

Option C - Vancomycin is a glycopeptide. It inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding with D-alanyl-D-alanine. It is used in the treatment of MRSA, clostridium difficile, and enterococci. Redman syndrome, ototoxicity, and nephrotoxicity are the most important adverse effects.

Option D - Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside. Aminoglycoside antibiotics act by binding to the 30s ribosome and interfere with the initiation of protein synthesis. Their ability to cause misreading of DNA template and the formation of aberrant proteins that get incorporated into bacterial cell membrane makes them bactericidal agents. Their antimicrobial activity reduces in an anaerobic environment. Ototoxicity, nephrotoxicity, and neuromuscular blockade are the most important adverse effects.

Related Pearl: Protein synthesis inhibitors: Primary subunit of ribosome binding

Mnemonic: 50 CELLS arranged into 30 TEAM

50s subunit binding:

  • C: Chloramphenicol, Clindamycin
  • E: Erythromycin (macrolides)
  • L: Lincosamides
  • L: Linezolid
  • S: Streptogramins

30s subunit binding

  • Te: Tetracyclines
  • Am: Aminoglycosides

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 9 weeks of gestation comes to the clinic. You do a bimanual examination by placing 2 fingers of one hand in the anterior fornix of the vagina and fingers of the other hand, over the abdomen and behind the uterus. The abdominal and vaginal fingers seem to appose below the body of the uterus. This is called :
questions.solution:
The scenario described in the question is the demonstration of Hegar's sign.

Hegar's sign: the examiner performs a bimanual examination. Two fingers of one hand are placed in the anterior fornix of the vagina and fingers of the other hand are placed, over the abdomen and behind the uterus. The abdominal fingers and the vaginal fingers appear to oppose each other below the body of the uterus. This can be elicited between 6-10 weeks.

This sign is based on the fact that the lower part of the body of the uterus is empty and extremely soft, and the upper part is enlarged by the growing fetus.

Other options :

Option A - Palmer's sign is regular rhythmic uterine contraction during the bimanual examination. It is seen as early as 4-8 weeks.

Option C - Osiander's sign is increased pulsation felt through lateral fornix by 8 weeks.

Option D - Goodell's sign is softening of the cervix by the 6th week.

Related Pearl: Uterine Signs in Pregnancy

questions.text:
A middle-aged male patient comes with complaints of generalized weakness and palpitations. ECG showed ST depression and QT prolongation. He was diagnosed to have hypokalaemia and started on potassium supplementation. However, the patient's symptoms persisted. What is the most likely cause of treatment failure?

ECG - Electrocardiography
questions.solution:
In a patient with hypokalemia, the most likely cause of treatment failure is hypomagnesemia. 

Hypomagnesemia leads to reduced cellular uptake as well as increased renal secretion of potassium by the distal nephron, causing treatment refractoriness.

Hypokalemia occurs when the plasma concentration of potassium is less than 3.5 mM. It can occur due to:

  • Metabolic alkalosis
  • Beta-2 agonistic drugs
  • Insulin
  • Thyrotoxic periodic paralysis
  • Total parenteral nutrition
  • Hypothermia
  • Magnesium deficiency
  • Diuretics (except potassium-sparing agents)
  • Mineralocorticoid excess
  • Renal tubular syndromes (Gitelmen's, Bartter's, and Liddle's syndrome)

Hypokalemia causes life-threatening cardiac arrhythmias. ECG shows broad flat T waves, ST depression, and QT prolongation that is most marked when serum K+ <2.7 mmol/L (shown below). 

It also causes weakness and paralysis. Paralysis of intestinal smooth muscles can cause intestinal ileus. Sodium chloride and bicarbonate retention lead to metabolic alkalosis. Other functional effects include polyuria, phosphaturia, and hypocitraturia.

Oral potassium supplementation is the mainstay of treatment (IV supplementation is reserved for severe complications such as paralysis and arrhythmias). Hypomagnesemia should also be looked for and treated. 

Other options:

Option B- The clinical features of hyponatremia are predominantly neurological as a result of the development of cerebral edema. Patients usually present with nausea, headache, vomiting, seizure, brainstem herniation, and coma.

Option C- The most notable clinical features of hypermagnesemia are vasodilation and neuromuscular blockade. Early signs include hypotension refractory to vasopressors and volume expansion.

Option D-  The clinical features of hypernatremia are neurological. The most frequent manifestation is altered mental status that ranges from confusion and lethargy to deep coma.

questions.text:
A homeless man is caught peeping into the women's public restroom and attaining sexual gratification. This act is punishable under which section of the BNS?

BNS - Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita

IPC - Indian Penal Code
questions.solution:
The scenario is suggestive of voyeurism and is punishable under BNS Section 77 (IPC 354-C).

Voyeurism refers to an individual having an intense desire to observe unsuspecting people undress or naked, take a bath, see genitalia, or watch intercourse to attain sexual excitement or gratification. The individual is called a voyeur or a peeping tom.

The punishment for this offence is imprisonment for not less than 1 year which may extend to 3 years and a fine. If the voyeur repeats the offense, they can be punished with imprisonment of 3-7 years.

BNS Section 74 (IPC 354) deals with assault or use of force on a woman to insult her modesty. Such acts are punishable with imprisonment of 1-5 years and a fine.

The other related offenses are given below:

BNS Section IPC Section Offense 
75 354-A Sexual harassment and punishment for sexual harassment. This involves physical contact, advances, demanding sexual favors, making sexual remarks, and showing the victim pornography
76 354-B Assaulting or forcing a woman to disrobe 
77 354-C Voyeurism
78 354-D Stalking or following a woman to force interaction or monitoring using the internet, email, or any electronic communication.

 

Related Pearl: Paraphilic disorders

DSM-5 includes eight specific paraphilic disorders:

Disorder Description
Exhibitionistic disorder Sexual arousal from exposing their genitals to a stranger
Pedophilic disorder Sexual arousal to a prepubescent individual, generally 13 years of age or younger
Voyeuristic disorder Sexual arousal from observing other's sexual activities
Sexual sadism disorder Sexual arousal upon inflicting suffering or humiliation  
Frotteuristic disorder Sexual arousal by touching or rubbing against a non-consenting person
Fetishistic disorder Sexual arousal from the use of inert objects, such as female
undergarments
Transvestic disorder Sexual arousal from cross-dressing
Sexual masochism Sexual arousal from being humiliated, beaten, bound, or made to suffer

As per ICD-11, the first five are included under paraphilic disorders. Two other subclasses in addition to this are:

  • Other paraphilic disorders involving non-consenting individuals (e.g., arousal patterns involving corpses or animals)
  • Paraphilic disorders involving solitary behaviour or consenting individuals (e.g., asphyxophilia, fetishism, fetishistic transvestism).

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in the lag phase of the bacterial growth curve?
questions.solution:
Maximum cell size is seen in the lag phase of the bacterial growth curve.

Phases of bacterial growth curve:

  • Lag phase: Occurs immediately after the seeding of a culture media. There is no increase in cell number but cell size increases and maximum cell size (option C) is obtained towards the end of this phase. This initial period is the time required for adaptation to a new environment, during which the necessary enzymes and metabolic intermediates are built up in adequate quantities for multiplication to proceed.
  • Log phase or exponential phase: In this phase, cells start dividing and their numbers increase exponentially or by geometric progression with time. Cells are smaller and stain uniformly. 
  • Stationary phase: Cell division stops due to depletion of nutrients and accumulation of toxic products. It is a state of equilibrium, where the number of new cells formed equals the number of cells that die. Sporulation (option A) occurs during this phase. Many bacteria produce secondary metabolic products such as exotoxins (option B) and antibiotics.
  • Phase of decline: In this phase, the population decreases due to cell death from nutritional exhaustion, toxin accumulation, and the action of autolytic enzymes. Involution forms (option D) are common.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old teacher visited the OPD for an annual checkup. On examination, prominent tortuous, dilated subcutaneous veins are present on the medial side of her lower leg with the CEAP classification C2a Ep As Pn. She is aware of her varicose veins and is asymptomatic. She is wondering if treatment is required at this stage. What is the next step in management?

CEAP - Clinical - Etiology - Anatomy - Pathophysiology classification of varicose veins
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of mild asymptomatic varicose veins according to the CEAP classification. Therefore, the next step in management is compression stockings.

In addition, she has no venous complications like pigmentation, eczema, or venous ulcers. Thus, she can be initially managed with compression stockings. 

Compression stockings provide external pressure to the limb which compresses the veins and improves venous return. There are two lengths available - knee or thigh length. However, knee-length stockings are commonly prescribed as they have better compliance. 

They are useful for the initial management of varicose veins as they relieve symptoms and are a conservative approach. If the varicose veins become symptomatic or become visually distressing then non-conservative approaches described below can be considered. 

Other options: 

Option A: Radiofrequency ablation uses electromagnetic currents to destroy the vein without damaging the other structures. It can only treat junctional and truncal incompetence and not varicosities. 

Option B: Saphenopopliteal ligation is a surgical procedure where the saphenopopliteal junction is dissected with flush ligation. Alternatively, the small saphenous vein can also be ligated as proximally as possible. Sural nerve neuropraxia and common peroneal nerve injury are possible complications. 

Option C: Saphenofemoral ligation is a surgical procedure made where the great saphenous vein is ligated and stripped. There are complications associated with this procedure such as saphenous nerve injury and neovascularization due to trauma leading to reoccurrence. 

Related Pearl: CEAP Classification of Chronic Lower Extremity Venous Disease

CEAP (Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology)

Clinical classification (C)*

C0

No visible or palpable signs of venous disease

C1

Telangiectases or reticular veins

C2

C2r

Varicose veins

Recurrent varicose veins

C3

Edema

C4

Changes in skin and subcutaneous tissue secondary

to chronic venous disease

C4a-Pigmentation or eczema

questions.text: An elderly man presents with severe, worsening abdominal pain since the previous day. He had undergone angioplasty for coronary artery disease 2 years back. The patient was hemodynamically stable. On examination, a pulsatile mass was palpated in the abdomen. Ultrasound revealed an intact abdominal aortic aneurysm of diameter 4.5 cm. What should be the management plan for this patient?

choices.text: Follow-up every 6 months; operate if diameter is >5.5 cm
Follow-up every 2 months; operate if diameter is >5 cm
Immediate surgical repair of the aneurysm
Follow-up every 3 months; operate if diameter is >5.5 cm

questions.solution:
The management of a patient with a symptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm is immediate surgical repair of the aneurysm.

Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is the most common type of large vessel aneurysm. The most important risk factor to develop AAA is atherosclerosis. In the majority of cases, it occurs below the renal arteries.

Risk factors for AAA are age, male sex, atherosclerosis, smoking history, hypertension, and connective tissue disorders like Marfan syndrome or Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.

The patients may be asymptomatic or may present with symptoms of abdominal pain or back pain. They might have a pulsatile abdominal mass on palpation. The patients are hemodynamically stable in case of an intact aneurysm. A ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm should be suspected in a patient with the triad of severe abdominal/back pain, hypotension, and a pulsatile abdominal mass.

Abdominal ultrasound can be used, but only a CT scan is useful in the diagnosis of an aneurysm.

Treatment:

Surgical repair of AAA is indicated in

  • Symptomatic patients/ patients with a ruptured aneurysm
  • Asymptomatic patients if the diameter is >5.5 cm
  • Rapidly enlarging AAA, increasing in diameter by >0.5 cm within 6 months
  • Those associated with peripheral artery aneurysms undergoing repair

Surgical options for the repair of aortic aneurysms are endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) and open aneurysm repair. EVAR is preferred over open aneurysm repair in current practice.

The other options are incorrect. The frequency for follow-up is every 6 months if the AAA has a diameter of <5.5 cm. 

Related Pearl: Indications for operative repair of thoracic aortic aneurysm

Clinical scenario Indication for operative repair
Symptomatic aneurysm Any size
Asymptomatic ascending thoracic aortic diameter > 5.5 cm
When the diameter of an ascending aortic aneurysm has increased > 0.5 cm per year
Asymptomatic descending thoracic aortic diameter or > 6 cm
When the diameter of descending  aortic aneurysm has increased  > 1 cm per year
Asymptomatic ascending thoracic aortic diameter in patients with Marfan’s syndrome or bicuspid aortic valve 4-5cm

questions.text: A karyotyping image is given below. What are the clinical features most likely to be expected in such patients?
questions.solution:
The given karyotyping image shows trisomy of 21 which is seen in Down syndrome. Flat occiput is seen in Down syndrome.

Clinical features: 

  • Intellectual disability/Incurved or short fifth finger with clinodactyly
  • Congenital heart disease
  • Acute leukemia/Alzheimer's disease/Atlantoaxial instability/Atresia of the duodenum
  • Protruding tongue
  • Flat face
  • Occiput flat/Open wide fontanelle/Open mouth
  • Brachycephaly/Brushfield's spots (speckled irises)
  • Low (depressed) nasal bridge
  • Epicanthal fold/Dysplastic ears
  • Mongoloid slant (oblique palpebral fissure)
  • Simian palmar crease and a wider gap between first and second toes

 The following images show Simian's crease and Brushfield's spots respectively.

Other options:

Option B - Webbing of the neck and lymphedema can be seen in Turner’s syndrome (45 XO). The image below shows the webbing of the neck.

Option C - Short stature with polydactyly is most commonly seen in Patau syndrome or trisomy 13.

Option D - Disproportionately long arms and legs and gynecomastia can be seen in Klinefelter syndrome. Classically karyotype is 47, XXY. Other variants can have 48 XXXY; rarely, 49 XXXXY; or mosaics with some cells containing normal 46, XY and others 47, XXY. This results from the meiotic nondisjunction of sex chromosomes (mostly during 1st meiotic division).

The following image shows characteristic features of Klinefelter syndrome

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presented with pain and swelling in the small joints of the hand. Her radiograph is as given below. The presence of all of the following radiographic features would point towards a diagnosis of Osteoarthritis except?
questions.solution:
Central/subchondral bone erosions are seen in osteoarthritis. Marginal bone erosions are not a typical feature of osteoarthritis. 

In OA of the hand, the joints involved are the distal and proximal interphalangeal joints(DIP, PIP), and the first carpometacarpal joint (base of the thumb).

The nodules palpable in the DIP are called Heberden’s nodes, while those palpable in the PIP are called Bouchard’s nodes.

Radiographic features of osteoarthritis 

  • Localized joint space narrowing
  • Subchondral cysts and sclerosis
  • Marginal osteophytes
  • Loose bodies and chondrocalcinosis
  • Central or subchondral erosions give rise to the seagull wing appearance.

Related Pearl: Joint Involvement in Various Arthritis

 Joint Disorders Joints Commonly Involved

Joints Commonly Spared

 Osteoarthritis

Cervical and lumbosacral spine, PIP, DIP, 1st CMC, hip, knee, 1st MTP, 

 Elbow, Wrist, Ankle, MCP 
Rheumatoid Arthritis Shoulder, Wrist, MCP, PIP, Knee, MTP  DIP 
Ankylosing Spondylitis Sacroiliac joint, intervertebral joints  
Psoriatic Arthritis PIP, DIP Ray distribution* 

*Ray distribution: Joint involvement tends to follow a pattern with all of the joints of one finger involved sparing the adjacent finger completely.

questions.text: A 78-year-old man with a history of recurrent urinary tract infection presents with fever, tachypnea, tachycardia, mental obtundation, and reduced blood pressure. Which of the following coagulation factors is activated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of septic shock as a result of gram-negative sepsis originating from a urinary tract infection and the coagulation factor activated in this condition is factor XII.

Factors involved in the pathophysiology of septic shock:

Inflammatory and counter-inflammatory responses - 

Microbial products such as pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs) and damage-associated molecular patterns (DAMPs) lead to increased expression of genes encoding inflammatory mediators. These include cytokines such as tumor necrosis factor (TNF), interleukin 1 (IL-1), IL-12, IL-18, and interferon-γ (IFN-γ). C-reactive protein and procalcitonin are also elevated. Reactive oxygen species, prostaglandins, and platelet-activating factors are also increased. Activation of the complement pathway also occurs. The coagulation cascade is activated directly through factor XII and indirectly through altered endothelial function. Both hyperinflammatory and immunosuppressed states are triggered simultaneously.

Endothelial activation and injury:

There is widespread vascular leakage and tissue edema as a result of the pro-inflammatory state and endothelial cell activation leading to the accumulation of protein-rich edema fluid throughout the body. Systemic hypotension is a direct consequence of vascular smooth muscle relaxation due to upregulation of NO, C3a, C5a, and PAF production. These changes cause a mismatch in oxygen needs and oxygen delivery.

Induction of a procoagulant state:

Pro-inflammatory cytokines decrease the production of endothelial anticoagulant factors and decreases fibrinolysis. There is stasis of blood in small vessels and capillaries due to vascular leaks and tissue edema. This leads to systemic activation of thrombin and the deposition of fibrin-rich thrombi in small vessels, further compromising tissue perfusion, and causing DIC.

Metabolic abnormalities:

Insulin resistance and hyperglycemia are seen in patients with sepsis as cytokines such as TNF and IL-1, stress-induced hormones such as glucagon, growth hormone, and glucocorticoids and catecholamines increase the process of gluconeogenesis. Neutrophil function is markedly decreased which leads to a reduction in bactericidal activity.

Organ dysfunction:

All these factors compromise the delivery of oxygen and nutrients to the tissues causing cellular hypoxia and end-organ damage.

questions.text:
The binding groove and effector cells associated with HLA class 1 molecules are:

HLA : Human Leukocyte Antigen

choices.text: Beta I and Alpha I, CD4 T cells
Beta II and Alpha I, CD4 T cells
Alpha I and Alpha II, CD8 T cells
Alpha II and Beta II, CD8 T cells

questions.solution:
The binding groove associated with human leukocyte antigen I (HLA I) is between its alpha 1 and alpha 2 domains, and the effector cells involved are CD8 T cells.

The human major histocompatibility complex (MHC) is called the HLA complex. MHC is a cluster of genes whose products are responsible for antigen presentation to T cells, transplant rejection, etc.

HLA complex of genes is present on the short arm of chromosome 6. It consists of three separate clusters of genes, labeled as class I, II, and III.

HLA class I molecules are present on all nucleated cells. They consist of a heavy peptide chain called the alpha chain that is linked to β-2 microglobulin, which is called the beta chain. The alpha chain further consists of three domains called alpha 1, 2 and 3 that protrude from the cell membrane, as shown in the image below.

There exists a groove between the alpha 1 and alpha 2 domains, where small peptides formed subsequent to protein antigens being processed by macrophages or dendritic cells, bind for presentation to CD8 T cells.

Following this, the CD8 cytotoxic killer cell destroys the target cell. However, the T cell can recognise the antigen only when presented as a complex with the MHC class I molecule and this is called MHC restriction.

HLA class I antigens are involved in graft rejections and cell-mediated cytolysis and are also components of hormone receptors.

HLA class II molecules are present on macrophages, dendritic cells, activated T cells and B cells. They too consist of an alpha and beta chain, each having a proximal and distal domain, as shown in the image below.

The antigen-binding site comprises the two distal domains, which are alpha 1 and beta 1 domains. Antigens are bound for recognition by CD4 T cells. They are principally involved in graft-versus-host-disease and mixed leukocyte reactions.

HLA class III molecules include complement components linked to the formation of C3 convertases, heat shock proteins and tumour necrosis factors.

 

Related Pearl: MHC Classes I and II

MHC Class I

MHC Class II

Expressed on all nucleated cells (except sperms) and platelets

Expressed on antigen-presenting cells: macrophages, B lymphocytes, dendritic cells

Consist of a polymorphic α, heavy-chain, linked non-covalently to β2-microglobulin

Heterodimer consisting of non-covalently associated α and β chains, both of which are polymorphic.

α chains are encoded by three genes- HLA-A, HLA-B, and HLA-C

Encoded by HLA-D, with subregions: HLA-DP, HLA-DQ, and HLA-DR.

Display antigenic peptides that are derived from viral and tumor proteins

Present antigens that are internalized into vesicles, and derived from extracellular microbes 

Class I complexes are recognized by CD8+ T cells

 

Class II complexes are recognized by CD4+ T cells

Endogenous peptide is the type of antigen presented to CD8+ T cells

 Exogenous antigen is the type of antigen presented to CD4+ T cells 

Presents antigen via the cytosolic pathway

 Presents antigen via the endocytic pathway 

Antigen binding site is present between α1/α2 groove

 Antigen binding site is present between α1/β1 groove 

α3 binds to CD8 molecules on cytotoxic T cells

 β2 binds to CD4 on helper T cells

questions.text: A group of third MBBS students are on an industrial visit to the nearby milk factory. Their community medicine professor is quizzing them on the Holder method of milk pasteurization. What are the duration and the temperature at which the milk is heated in this method?
questions.solution:
In the Holder method of pasteurization, the milk is heated at 63°C for 30 minutes, followed by cooling quickly to 13°C or lower.

In the flash process of pasteurization, the milk is heated at 72°C for 15-20 seconds followed by cooling quickly to 13°C or lower.

These processes destroy all non-sporing pathogens such as Mycobacteria, Brucellae, and Salmonellae. Coxiella burnetii which is the causative organism of Q fever, is relatively heat-resistant and may survive the Holder method.

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman is found in her bed with a scarf tied around her neck. Her face is cyanotic and congested with conjunctival petechiae. Removal of the scarf revealed a ligature mark on her neck. Which of the following is not a feature of antemortem ligature marks?

choices.text: The ligature mark reflects the ligature material used.
The ligature mark is usually below the laryngeal prominence.
The ligature mark does not have to go fully around the neck.
Vital reaction is present around the ligature mark.

questions.solution:
Option B is not a feature of antemortem ligature marks. Antemortem ligature marks are usually present above the laryngeal prominence. 

Ligature marks are seen in ligature strangulation or hanging. In strangulation, a constricting band is placed around the neck, which results in congestion, cyanosis, and petechiae. The ligature marks due to hanging have a suspension point, whereas those from manual strangulation do not. 

If the strangulation is homicidal in nature, there may also be scratches or bruises around the mark. They may be defensive wounds from the victim or previous attempts at manual strangulation. 

When pressure on the neck is applied, the following changes take place in any order, depending on the site of pressure and force used:  

  • Impaired venous return due to obstruction of jugular veins: This causes cyanosis, congestion, and petechiae.
  • Cerebral ischemia due to obstruction of the carotid arteries
  • Vagal inhibition of the heart due to stimulation of baroreceptor nerve endings in the carotid sinus
  • Closing the airway at the level of the pharynx due to elevation of the larynx and tongue

Other options: 

Option A - Ligature marks can reflect the ligature material. The mark is an important piece of evidence. It can tell us about the size and material even if the ligature has been removed from the scene. 

Option C - Ligature marks do not have to go fully around the neck. Most marks do, but the mark can be interrupted by clothing or hair. In addition, some marks may only be present on the front of the neck. Here, pressure has been applied from the back to compress the larynx.

Option D - Ligature marks may have a vital reaction on either side of the mark. This appears as a red flare on either side of the mark. This is seen in antemortem ligature marks.

questions.text:
The drug 'X' is a GHRH analogue that is FDA-approved for the treatment of HIV-associated lipodystrophy and not used for Growth hormone deficiency. Identify the drug 'X'.

GHRH- Growth Hormone Releasing Hormone
questions.solution:
Tesamorelin is approved for use in HIV-associated lipodystrophy but not for GH deficiency. It is a synthetic N-terminal modified form of human GHRH. It does not get degraded by dipeptidyl peptidase 4 and therefore has a longer duration of action.

It increases the levels of growth hormone (GH) and insulin-like growth factor (IGF-1) but reduces visceral fat accumulation.

Tesamorelin is approved for use in HIV-associated lipodystrophy but not for GH deficiency. 

Other options:

Option A: Octreotide is a somatostatin analogue that decreases growth hormone levels. It is used in the treatment of acromegaly, variceal bleeding, diarrhoea due to adenomas secreting VIP (vasoactive intestinal peptide), and sulfonylurea toxicity. One of its adverse effects is gallstone formation.

Option B: Somatropin is a growth hormone analogue. It is used in growth hormone deficiency and other short-stature conditions like Turner's syndrome, Noonan syndrome, and Prader-Willi syndrome. Their use is contraindicated in acute critical illness, active malignancy, and proliferative retinopathy.

Option D: Mecasermin is a recombinant human IGF-1. It is used in IGF-1 deficiency, growth hormone receptor defects, and antibodies against growth hormone receptors. Adverse effects include hypoglycemia and lipohypertrophy. Another recombinant human IGF-1 with its IGFBP-3, mecasermin rinfabate has been FDA-approved for HIV-associated adipose redistribution syndrome.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old female patient with Sjogren's syndrome presents to your clinic with complaints of severe fatigue and generalized pruritus. Laboratory examination reveals elevated GGT, ALP, IgM, and the presence of anti-mitochondrial antibodies. A liver biopsy was performed, which shows the following histopathological findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?

GGT - Gamma-glutamyltransferase

ALP - Alkaline phosphatase
questions.solution:
The histopathological findings demonstrate chronic non-suppurative destructive cholangitis. Lymphocyte (arrow) and plasma cell (bold arrow) infiltration into the bile duct along with clinical history, is strongly suggestive of primary biliary cirrhosis (PBC).

Primary biliary cirrhosis is an autoimmune destructive condition of the small and medium-sized intrahepatic bile ducts. It is most commonly seen in women who are 40-50 years of age. It is also found in association with other autoimmune diseases such as-

  • Sjogren syndrome
  • Thyroiditis
  • Scleroderma 
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Raynaud phenomenon
  • Celiac disease.

Clinical features of PBC include: 

  • Fatigue is out of proportion to liver disease
  • Debilitating pruritis
  • Jaundice
  • Hyperpigmentation of the trunk and arms in areas of repeated scratching
  • Xanthelasma and Xanthoma

Investigations reveal elevated liver enzymes such as GGT and ALP are significantly elevated with only mild elevation of AST and ALT enzymes. About 90% of the patients will have anti-mitochondrial antibodies. Biopsy of the liver may confirm the diagnosis and shows a florid duct lesion (as given in the image). This is due to the destruction of interlobular bile ducts with lymphoplasmacytic inflammation with or without granuloma formation. In PBC bile accumulation is seen in peri-portal areas, unlike drug-induced or obstructive cholestasis, where bile is accumulated in the centrizonal areas. Mallory–Denk bodies may also be seen. Cirrhosis usually develops in long-standing diseases.

Ursodeoxycholic acid when started in the early phase of the disease, improves both biochemical and histological features. If there is marked cirrhosis, then liver transplantation is the only definitive treatment. Anti-histamines, narcotic receptor antagonists (naltrexone), and rifampin may be used to manage pruritis. 

 Other options:

Option A - Acute cholangitis (as well as suppurative cholangitis or ascending cholangitis) is a disorder associated with recurrent fever, abdominal pain, and jaundice. This clinical combination has been traditionally known as Charcot’s triad. Acute cholangitis is primarily an infectious disease characterized by the proliferation of bacteria within the bile ducts and with the secondary blockage of biliary tracts. The Reynolds' pentad is defined as the occurrence of confusion and shock along with Charcot’s triad. Lab investigations reveal elevated liver enzymes and pro-inflammatory markers. 

Option B - Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is defined as the presence of hepatic steatosis in individuals who do not consume alcohol or do so in small quantities. Histopathological diagnosis requires steatosis (≥5% of hepatocytes), lobular inflammation, and ballooned hepatocytes. Serum AST and ALT are elevated in most patients with NASH. 

Option D - Primary sclerosing cholangitis presents with fatigue, pruritus, steatorrhea similar to PBC. It is more common in men in the 3-5th decade. It is characterized by diffuse inflammation and fibrosis involving the entire biliary tree. The perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (p-ANCA), is positive and anti-mitochondrial antibodies aren't seen. Diagnosis is usually done by magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) and definitive management is by liver transplantation.

Related Pearl: Differences between primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) and primary biliary cholangitis (PBC)

p-ANCA-positive

Gender predominance Females Males
Site Intrahepatic bile ducts only Intra- and extrahepatic bile ducts

questions.text: During the routine ward rounds, a neonatologist demonstrates a reflex as shown below. Which of the following is true regarding the elicited reflex?

choices.text: The onset is at 37 weeks of gestation
It disappears one month after birth
It disappears by 3-6 months of birth

questions.solution:
The reflex elicited is the Moro reflex. It disappears by 3-6 months of birth. 

Moro reflex is a primitive neonatal reflex. The infant's head is held in a semi-erect position and then allowed to fall backward onto the examiner's hand. As a response to this, there is initial extension and abduction of fingers and upper extremities. This is followed by flexion of the upper extremities and an audible cry. 

The reflex begins to develop at 28-32 weeks of gestation and is fully developed at 37 weeks. It may be present until 6 months after birth.

An asymmetric reflex can point to a fractured clavicle, brachial plexus injury, or hemiparesis. Absent Moro reflex is suggestive of central nervous system dysfunction as seen in hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy and kernicterus.

According to Ghai Essential Paediatrics, 9th edition, tonic neck reflex disappears by 4 months of age. According to Nelson Paediatrics, 21st edition, tonic neck reflex disappears by 6 months of age. Hence, the answer depends on the reference chosen by the examiner.

questions.text: A drug that induces apoptosis in a kidney cell is being studied. Shown below is the mechanism of cell death in this case. Which of the following proteins does not belong to the group marked as "X" in the image given?
questions.solution:
In the given image, "X" represents anti-apoptotic factors. BAK is a pro-apoptotic factor and does not belong to this group.

In order for apoptosis to occur permeabilization of the mitochondrial membrane is necessary. This is facilitated by pro-apoptotic proteins, BAX, and BAK (represented by the group "Y" in the image). This action is inhibited by anti-apoptotic proteins (represented by the group "X" in the image). 

Apoptosis is a pathway of cell death that is induced by a closely regulated suicide program in which cells destined to die activate intrinsic enzymes (caspases) that degrade the cell nuclear and cytoplasmic proteins. 

Mechanism of apoptosis: There are two distinct pathways that can lead to caspase activation and cause apoptosis of the cell.

  • The mitochondrial or intrinsic pathway
  • The death receptor or extrinsic pathway

The mitochondrial (intrinsic) pathway of apoptosis:

  • There are several proteins in the mitochondria that can induce apoptosis. These include cytochrome c and some proteins that neutralize the endogenous inhibitors of apoptosis.
  • The permeability of the mitochondria is controlled by the BCL-2 family of proteins, which act as sensors.
  • These sensors are activated when the cells are deprived of growth factors and other survival signals are exposed to agents that damage the DNA or accumulate a large number of misfolded proteins.
  • These activated sensors, in turn, activate the proapoptotic molecules, like BAX and BAK, which form channels in the mitochondrial membrane, through which cytochrome c and other mitochondrial proteins escape into the cytosol and cause activation of caspase-9, which in turn leads to the activation of the caspase cascade and, eventually, apoptosis of the cell.
  • On the other hand, if all the growth factors and other survival signals are present, then they produce more antiapoptotic members of the BH1-4 family like the BCL2, MCL 1, and BCL-XL. These proteins limit the escape of proapoptotic mitochondrial proteins.

The death-receptor (extrinsic) pathway of apoptosis:

  • Death receptors are surface molecules that are members of the tumor necrosis factor (TNF) receptor family like the TNF 1 and Fas (CD 95).
  • These receptors are expressed on the surface of many cells and can trigger apoptosis. In the cytoplasmic region, these receptors have a death domain.
  • Fas ligand (FasL) is a membrane protein expressed mainly on activated T-lymphocytes. Fas-FasL interactions are required for thymic medullary negative selection. Defective interactions also cause autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome. 
  • When these T-cells recognize Fas-expressing targets, Fas molecules are cross-linked by FasL, their cytoplasmic death domains form a binding site for an adaptor protein called Fas-associated death domain (FADD).
  • These, in turn, recruit and activate caspase-8 and -10.
  • In many cell types, caspase-8 and -10 may cleave and activate a pro-apoptotic member of the Bcl-2 family called Bid, thus feeding into the mitochondrial pathway.
  • The combined activation of both pathways delivers a lethal blow to the cell.
  • Cellular proteins, notably, a caspase antagonist called FLIP, block the activation of caspases downstream of the death receptors. Interestingly, some viruses produce homologs of FLIP, and it is suggested that this is a mechanism that viruses use to keep infected cells alive.
  • The death receptor pathway is involved in the elimination of self-reactive lymphocytes and in the killing of target cells by some cytotoxic T-lymphocytes.

The following image shows a diagrammatic representation of the mechanisms of apoptosis: 

Related Pearl: Apoptotic genes

Group Members Details
Anti-apoptotlc BCL2,
BCL-XL

MCL1		 Present in outer mitochondrial membrane
Prevent leakage of cytochrome-c and
other death lnducing proteins into
cytosol.

BAK		 On activation, they increase mitochondrial membrane permeability.

BIM,
BID,

between the other two groups

questions.text:
A patient in the ICU, who was in a comatose condition, was shifted onto the ventilator for assisted ventilation. Which of the following circuits will be used in this condition?

Fresh gas flow - Blue 

Adjustable pressure-limiting (APL) valve - Red
questions.solution:
The patient in the given case scenario would be put on controlled ventilation. The most appropriate circuit to be used in this case is the Mapleson D circuit which is depicted in image 2, since it is one of the most efficacious circuits for controlled ventilation. Modification of Mapleson D is known as the Bain circuit.

The order of efficiency for controlled ventilation amongst Mapleson circuits is DFE>BC>A.

Image 2 is identified as the Mapleson D circuit due to the following observations:

  • Fresh gas flow (blue) is near the patient's mouth
  • APL valve(red) is away from the patient's mouth
  • Presence of a reservoir bag distal to APL valve.

The Mapleson D circuit is efficient during controlled ventilation since it has a very low requirement of fresh gas flow in terms of minute ventilation (only 1-2 times the minute ventilation). In this circuit, the fresh gas flow forces alveolar air away from the patient and toward the APL valve. 

The Bain circuit is a coaxial version of the Mapleson D system that incorporates the fresh gas inlet tubing inside the breathing tube. This modification decreases the circuit’s bulk and retains heat and humidity better than a conventional Mapleson D circuit as a result of partial warming of the inspiratory gas by countercurrent exchange with the warmer expired gases.

The order of efficiency for spontaneous ventilation amongst Mapleson circuits is A>DFE> CB.

Other options: 

Option B - Image 1 is identified as Mapleson A. It is the most efficacious for use in spontaneous ventilation.

Option C - Image 4 is identified as Mapleson B. This circuit is less efficacious than Mapleson D in controlled ventilation.

Option D - Image 3 is identified as Mapleson F. This circuit is less efficacious than Mapleson D in controlled ventilation.

Related Pearl: Mapleson Classification

Mapleson circuit   Other name  Fresh gas flow rate
Spontaneous ventilation  Controlled ventilation
A Magills 1 minute ventilation (MV) i.e. 80 ml/kg/min Very high and difficult to predict
B - 2-3× (MV) 2-2.5 × (MV)
C Water’s to and fro 2-3 × (MV) 2-2.5 × (MV)
D Bain circuit 2-3 × (MV) 1-2 × (MV)
E Ayre’s t-piece 2-3 × (MV) 3 × (MV)
F Jackson rees modification 2-3 × (MV) 2 × (MV)

 

Note:

The efficiency of Mapleson circuits in spontaneous ventilation is  A > DFE > CB (A Dog Can Bite - Usually a spontaneous event)

The efficiency of Mapleson circuits in controlled ventilation is DFE > BC > A (Dead Babies can't assist - controlled)

questions.text: A 24-year-old lady in her third week postpartum complains of pain in her left breast. She also complains of mild fever, headache, and nausea. Examination reveals a tender, non-fluctuant swelling in the lower inner quadrant of her left breast. The overlying skin is red, hot, and flushed as shown in the image below. There is no discharge. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture of a lactating mother presenting with breast pain, fever, headache, nausea, tender swelling in a quadrant of the breast with red, hot, and flushed overlying skin points towards a diagnosis of acute mastitis.

The most common organism involved in acute mastitis is Staphylococcus aureus. Other organisms involved are Staphylococcus epidermidis, and Streptococci viridans. The source of organisms is the infant’s nose and throat. It usually occurs during the first 2–4 weeks postpartum.

Clinical features:

  • Generalized malaise
  • Headache
  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Fever with chills
  • Severe pain and tender swelling in one quadrant of the breast
  • The overlying skin is red, hot, and flushed, and feels tense and tender

Microscopic examination of breast milk shows leucocytes >106/mL and bacterial count >103/mL. It might lead to the formation of a breast abscess.

Management:

  • Breast support
  • Plenty of oral fluids
  • Breastfeeding is continued with good attachment
  • The infected side is emptied manually with each feed
  • Dicloxacillin 500 mg every 6 hours orally is the drug of choice
  • Erythromycin is given to patients who are allergic to penicillin
  • Analgesics.

Other options:

Option A - Breast engorgement occurs due to exaggerated normal venous and lymphatic engorgement of the breasts which precedes lactation, which in turn causes prevents the escape of milk from the lacteal system. This is more common in primiparous women. It usually manifests after the milk secretion starts in the third or fourth day postpartum and presents as considerable pain and feeling of tenseness or heaviness in both the breasts, generalized malaise and painful breastfeeding. Management includes breast support with a binder or brassiere, frequent suckling, manual expression of any remaining milk after each feed, analgesics for pain, and frequent feeding.

Option B - Galactocele are the most common benign breast lesions in lactating women. It is a cystic enlargement of the mammary gland containing milk. They are mostly detected during lactation or in the third trimester of pregnancy but rarely, may also present after stopping breastfeeding. Clinically, the mass is usually firm and non-tender and presents as a solid tumour-like lesion on physical examination. The patient usually notes the lesion during lactation or some period after lactation. Needle aspiration, followed by excision should it recur, is the standard method of treating galactocele. Breast engorgement can lead to the formation of a galactocele and is managed as given above.

Option C - Breast abscess is usually suspected when there is no response to treatment for mastitis in 48-72 hours. It is also characterised by brawny oedema over the affected area, the onset of fluctuation, and swinging temperature. Management includes incision and drainage of the abscess under general anaesthesia with the incision along Langer's lines. Newer modalities include sonography guided needle aspiration under local anaesthesia. Antibiotics and pumping of the affected breast are also done.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the ophthalmology OPD with complaints of watering eyes and inability to keep eyes opened in a bright room. On ocular examination, the following finding is noted. The finding is a defect in which of the following layers of the cornea?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with photophobia and excessive watering and image showing Haab striae is suggestive of congenital glaucoma. Haab striae are curvilinear healed breaks in the descemet membrane.

Primary congenital glaucoma refers to abnormally high intraocular pressure (IOP) which occurs as a result of a developmental anomaly of the angle of the anterior chamber. It is not associated with any other ocular or systemic anomaly. It can be classified as follows:

  • True congenital glaucoma (40%) in which intraocular pressure (IOP) is elevated during intrauterine life.
  • Infantile glaucoma (55%), which manifests prior to age 3.
  • Juvenile glaucoma, the least common, in which IOP rises between 3 and 16 years of age.

Diagnosis:

  • Corneal haze is due to diffuse edema secondary to raised IOP.
  • Buphthalmos is a large eye as a result of stretching due to elevated IOP prior to the age of 3 years.
  • Haab striae are curvilinear healed breaks in Descemet's membrane.
  • Corneal scarring

Below image shows hazy cornea.


Evaluation under general anesthesia is generally required; IV ketamine lowers IOP to levels lower than those achieved with other agents.

Treatment:

  • Management is essentially surgical.
  • Goniotomy
  • Trabeculotomy
  • Other procedures when angle surgery fails include trabeculectomy, tube shunt implantation, and ciliary body ablative procedures.

questions.text:
A patient with shortness of breath is diagnosed to have acute pulmonary edema. His chest X-ray, on PA view, revealed lines in the periphery of the lungs that are perpendicular to the pleural surface. What are these lines?

PA view- Postero-anterior view
questions.solution:
Lines in the periphery of the lungs that are perpendicular to the pleural surface in a patient with pulmonary edema are suggestive of Kerley B lines.

Kerley lines are septal lines that are seen when the interlobular septa in the pulmonary interstitium become prominent. It can be due to lymphatic engorgement or edema of the connective tissues of the interlobular septa. These are usually seen when the pulmonary capillary wedge pressure reaches 20-25 mmHg.

Types of Kerley lines: 

Kerley A lines- They extend radially from the hilum to the upper lobes and cross the normal vascular markings. These are oblique lines that are <1 mm thick, 2-6cm long, and course towards the hila. They represent thickened interlobular septa that contain lymphatic connections between the perivenous and bronchoarterial lymphatics in the lung parenchyma. The best modality for the demonstration of Kerley A-lines is HRCT.

Kerley B-lines - These are seen in the periphery of the lungs and are seen perpendicular to the pleural surface. These are thin 1-2 cm long lines. These are usually seen at the lung bases and represent thickened subpleural interlobular septa.

Kerley C-lines - These are short lines that do not reach the pleura (i.e. not B or D lines) and do not course radially away from the hila (i.e. not A-lines).

Kerley D-lines - These are the same as Kerley B lines, except that they are seen on lateral chest radiographs in the retrosternal air gap (the lucent area behind the sternum).

questions.text: As the medical officer of the primary health center (PHC), you are tasked with setting up a camp to promote the vaccination of children. The nurse from the PHC transports the vaccines in ice. The test shown in the image is performed for which of the given vaccines?
questions.solution:
The image shown is shake test that is used for the pentavalent vaccine, which is a freeze-sensitive vaccine.

The "Shake Test" is used to check whether freeze-sensitive vaccines have been damaged by exposure to temperatures below 0°C.  Once it has been thawed, the vial of freeze-damage vaccine no longer has the appearance of a cloudy liquid but tends to form flakes that settle down at the bottom of the vial.

  • A frozen vaccine is used as a control vial and the vial suspected to be damaged by freezing is taken as the test vial.
  • Both are shaken after thawing and the rate of sedimentation is compared.
  • If the rate of sedimentation in the test vial is slower than the control vial, then it is usable and has not been damaged.

Freeze-sensitive vaccines:

  • Hepatitis B
  • Pentavalent
  • IPV (Inactivated poliovirus)
  • DPT
  • TT
  • PCV

 Measles, Oral poliovirus vaccine, and Bacille Calmette-Guerin vaccine are not damaged by freezing.
