questions.text: The finding in the below-given image is seen in a case of:
questions.solution:
The image findings show Hollenhorst plaques are seen in central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO).

They are the cholesterol emboli seen in retinal arterioles. The most common cause of CRAO (Central retinal artery occlusion) is embolism.

The outer retina is supplied by the ciliary arteries while the inner retina is supplied by the central retinal artery (CRA). Both sets of arteries are branches of the ophthalmic artery. Arterial occlusion can occur due to atherosclerosis (most cases), inflammation, vasospasm, and hypotension.

The ophthalmic artery is the first branch of the internal carotid artery, so any emboli from the carotid arteries can lead to CRAO. 

The emboli that are refractile, yellow-white in color, and made of cholesterol are called Hollenhorst plaques. Emboli can also be greyish, elongated fibrin-platelet aggregates, or non-scintillating white calcific particles. 

The goal of treatment is to restore blood flow. Antiplatelet therapy, decreasing intraocular pressure with timolol, acetazolamide and mannitol, and thrombolytic can be used. Rebreathing into a paper bag will help increase CO2 and consequently arterial vasodilation. 

Other options: 

Option B - Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) would have fundoscopy features of deep blot and flame-shaped hemorrhages in the posterior and peripheral retina and cotton wool spots.

The below image shows flame-shaped hemorrhages in CRVO.

 Option C - Cystoid macular edema occurs when there is fluid accumulation in the outer plexiform and inner nuclear layers of the retina with cyst-like cavities. It would have fundoscopy features of loss of foveal depression, thickening of the retina, and multiple cystoid areas in the sensory retina. There may be optic disc swelling and a lamellar hole. 

Option D - Central serous retinopathy is characterized by localized serous detachment of the retina at the macula due to leakage from the choriocapillaris. Detachment would be visible on fundoscopy with clear or turbid subretinal fluid, depigment retinal pigment epithelium, and atrophic damage.

questions.text:
Identify the false statements.
  1. CK-MB isoenzyme is estimated in myocardial infarction(MI).
  2. Troponin I is detectable within 8 hours and peaks at 72 hours in MI.
  3. In MI, levels of LDH-2 are greater than LDH-1 in blood.
  4. Very high levels of alkaline phosphatase are seen in alcoholic hepatitis.
  5. PSA value above 10 μg/L is indicative of prostate cancer.

CK: Creatine kinase 
LDH: Lactate dehydrogenase
PSA: Prostate-specific antigen
questions.solution:
Statements 2, 3, and 4 are false. 

Functional enzymes are those enzymes that have a specific function in the plasma. Ex: coagulation factors, pseudocholinesterase, lipoprotein lipase.

Nonfunctional enzymes have no specific function in the plasma.

  • They are released from the cells as a result of normal wear and tear. Their level is very low in serum.
  • They serve as biomarkers whose levels in the plasma can assist in the diagnosis and prognosis of diseases affecting specific tissues.
  • Ex: Lactate dehydrogenase, creatine kinase, alkaline phosphatase.

Creatine kinase (CK): Normal serum value for CK is 15-100 U/L for males and 10-80 U/L for females. CK value in serum is increased in myocardial infarction. The CK level starts to rise within 3-6 hours of infarction, hence useful to detect early cases.  They are highly elevated in muscle injuries and dystrophies as well. Estimation of total CK is employed in muscular dystrophies and MB iso-enzyme is very specific to myocardial infarction.

Cardiac troponins: They are reliable markers for myocardial infarction. The troponin complex consists of Troponin C, Troponin I, and Troponin T. Troponin I and Troponin T are mainly located in the myofibrils. Trop-I is released into the blood within 4 hours after the onset of symptoms of myocardial ischemia; peaks at 14-24 hours and remains elevated for 3-5 days post-infarction.

Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH): Normal value of LDH in serum is 100-200 U/L. Normally LDH-2 concentration in blood is greater than LDH-1, but this pattern is reversed in myocardial infarction; this is called the flipped pattern.

Alkaline phosphatase (ALP): It is produced by osteoblasts of bone, and is associated with the calcification process. The normal serum value of ALP is 40-125 U/L. 

  • Moderate (2-3 times) increase in ALP level is seen in infective hepatitis, alcoholic hepatitis. 
  • Very high levels of ALP (10-12 times of upper limit) may be noticed in extrahepatic obstruction (obstructive jaundice) caused by gallstones or CA head of the pancreas. 
  • Drastically high levels of ALP (10-25 times of upper limit) are seen in bone diseases like Paget's disease. 

Prostate-specific antigen (PSA): It is produced from the secretory epithelium of the prostate gland. The normal value is 1-5 microgram/L. Values above 10 microgram/ L are indicative of prostate cancer.

Related Pearl: Principal Serum Enzymes Used in Clinical Diagnosis

 Serum Enzyme Major Diagnostic Use/Location

Alanine aminotransferase (ALT/SGPT) Viral hepatitis
Creatine kinase

CK-BB Brain, Brain injury, meningitis, abnormal cell growth, severe shock, stroke, hypothermia, or restricted blood flow to the bowel.
CK-MB Heart and skeletal muscle, Myocardial Infarction, Muscular dystrophy
Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)
HHHH (I1)/LDH-1 Heart & RBC;Myocardial infarction
HHHM(I2)/LDH-2 Reticuloendothelial system
HHMM(I3)/LDH-3 Lungs
HMMM(I4)/LDH-4 Liver & Skeletal Muscles
MMMM(I5)/LDH-5 Liver & Skeletal Muscles; Liver diseases
Others
Amylase, Lipase and Acid Phosphatase Acute pancreatitis
Ceruloplasmin Hepatolenticular degeneration (Wilson disease)
γ-Glutamyl transferase Liver diseases (Alcoholic Liver Disease)

questions.text: Identify the following instrument used in Ilizarov ring fixator.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Kirschner wire (K-wire).

Kirschner wire or K-wire has multiple uses. Insertion is stress-free, associated with less soft tissue damage, and allows for early exercises after removal. The diameter of the K-wire is 1 to 3 mm. The wire is pointed at both ends for both antegrade and retrograde insertion. The shape of the tips could be trocar or diamond or threaded.

Uses of K-wire:

  • To fix fractures in children
  • To give traction e.g. for olecranon fracture
  • To fix small bone fractures
  • In llizarov ring fixator

Other options:

Steinman pin - It is a stout, straight steel rod used to provide skeletal traction. Its diameter ranges from 3 to 6 mm. The common sites where it is used include the upper end of the tibia, supracondylar region of the femur, and the calcaneum. 

Cortical screw: They are threaded throughout the entire length and function as a positional screw or a lag screw for interfragmentary compression.

Cancellous screw - It has larger threads and therefore has more purchase in soft cancellous bones. 

Related Pearl: Orthopedic Instruments

questions.text: A patient presented with fever, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. She has a history of recent intensive care unit admission for sepsis which required prolonged antibiotic therapy. Sigmoidoscopy findings are given below. Choose the false statement regarding the given condition.

choices.text: Subtotal colectomy with end ileostomy is done in fulminant disease
IV vancomycin is used for treatment of recurrent disease
Fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) is an emerging treatment option
Stool sample is used for PCR detection of toxins

questions.solution:
A history of diarrhea associated with prolonged antibiotic treatment and characteristic adherent pseudomembranes in the colon is highly suggestive of pseudomembranous colitis. Oral Fidaxomicin is commonly used in recurrent pseudomembranous colitis.

The causative antibiotic agent must be discontinued and infection control measures must be taken for all patients. 

  • Initial episode - non severe: WBC ≤15,000/mm3, Creatinine < 1.5 mg/dL
    • Oral Fidaxomicin(drug of choice) or Vancomycin 
    • Oral Metronidazole can be given if Vancomycin/Fidaxomycin is not available
  • Initial episode - severe: >15,000/mm3, Creatinine >1.5 mg/dL
    • Oral Fidaxomicin or Vancomycin
    • Consider fecal microbiota transplantation
  • Initial episode - fulminant
    • Hypotension, ileus or megacolon
      • Oral vancomycin and IV metronidazole
      • Rectal Vancomycin can be used if ileus present 
    • Overwhelming sepsis, colonic perforation, or peritonitis
      • Subtotal colectomy with end ileostomy
  • First recurrence
    • Repeat course of antibiotics for another 10-20 days
    • Oral Fidaxomicin(drug of choice) or Vancomycin can be used.
  • Repeated recurrence
    • Consider fecal microbiota transplantation

Option A: Subtotal colectomy with end ileostomy is the procedure of choice for patients requiring surgery for severe colitis or toxic megacolon. It allows for disease control, stabilization, and preservation of reconstruction options for the future. Segmental colectomy, ileostomy, or colostomy alone does not address the pancolonic nature of the disease. 

Option C: Fecal microbiota transplan­tation (FMT) is emerging as a promising treatment option for recurrent and recalcitrant C. difficile infection. Using FMT, donor stool is administered to the patient through one of a variety of described routes (nasogastric tube, colonoscopic lavage, or upper endoscopy) to restore colonic flora.

Option D: Pseudomembranous colitis is caused by Clostridium difficile which is a gram-positive, spore-forming anaerobic microor­ganism. The pathogenesis is mediated by the enterotoxins - toxin A and toxin B. They can be detected in the stool using PCR

Harrison's 20th edition recommends using vancomycin over metronidazole in the treatment of initial episodes that are mild to moderate in severity. Fidaxomicin is also preferred because of its safety profile and higher beneficial effects. Metronidazole is now reserved for non-severe infections in settings where access to first-line drugs is limited or cost is an issue.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic criteria for Clostridium difficile infection

 

The diagnosis of CDI is based on a combination of clinical criteria:

1.Diarrhea (≥3 unformed stools per 24 h for ≥2 days) with no other recognized cause      

2.Detection of toxins A or B in the stool by PCR or culture

               or               

 Detection of pseudomembranes in the colon

questions.text: A 56-year-old HIV patient presents with productive cough with blood-stained sputum, evening rise of temperature, and weight loss for 3 weeks. His chest X-ray is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most frequent extrapulmonary presentation of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the gross image is suggestive of primary tuberculosis. Lymphadenitis is the most frequent presentation of extrapulmonary tuberculosis. It usually occurs in the cervical region and is termed scrofula.

Primary tuberculosis:

Primary tuberculosis almost always begins in the lungs. Inhaled bacilli are implanted in the distal airspaces (not proximal) of the lower part of the upper lobe or the upper part of the lower lobe, usually close to the pleura. An area of gray-white inflammation with consolidation develops which is 1-1.5 cms in size known as the Ghon focus. The center of this focus usually undergoes caseous necrosis.

Bacilli either free or within phagocytes drain to regional lymph nodes where caseous necrosis is noted as well. The presence of parenchymal disease and nodal involvement is termed Ghon's complex. This undergoes progressive fibrosis as a result of the cell-mediated immune response, often followed by calcifications that are radiologically visible.

Hematogenous and lymphatic spread is present in the first few weeks of infection which is controlled by cell-mediated immunity in 95% of the cases. Sites of active involvement are marked by a characteristic granulomatous inflammatory reaction that forms both caseating and noncaseating tubercles. A fibroblastic rim punctuated by lymphocytes encloses the granulomas. Multinucleated giant cells are present in the granulomas.

Isolated tuberculosis - This appears in any of the organs or tissues seeded hematogenously and may be the presenting manifestation. Organs commonly involved are:

  • Meninges (tuberculous meningitis)
  • Kidneys (renal tuberculosis)
  • Adrenals (formerly an important cause of Addison disease),
  • Bones (osteomyelitis)
  • Fallopian tubes (salpingitis)
  • Vertebrae (Pott disease).  Paraspinal “cold” abscesses in these patients may track along tissue planes and present as an abdominal or pelvic mass.

Lymphadenitis is the most frequent presentation of extrapulmonary tuberculosis. It usually occurs in the cervical region and is termed scrofula.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented to the emergency room with difficulty breathing and chest pain. On examination, tachycardia, edema of the lower limbs, and elevated jugular venous pressure were noted. He was given an intravenous infusion of a natriuretic peptide that acts on membrane-bound guanylyl cyclase. Identify the drug administered.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of heart failure and the drug administered is nesiritide.  

Nesiritide is a recombinant natriuretic peptide acting on membrane-bound guanylyl cyclase. It is used in the management of heart failure. 

Natriuretic peptides: 

  • Atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP): released from atrial storage granules in response to increase in intravascular volume. It reduces blood pressure.  
  • Brain natriuretic peptide (BNP): released from ventricular tissue in response to volume overload. It reduces blood pressure and is also known to reduce cardiac hypertrophy and fibrosis.  
  • C- type natriuretic peptide (CNP): synthesized in the brain and endothelial tissues and stimulates the growth of long bones. 

The other drugs mentioned are also used in the management of heart failure. Furosemide is a loop diuretic that acts on the thick ascending loop of Henle, inhibiting the Na+K+Cl- channel. Sodium nitroprusside and nitroglycerine are vasodilators that act by releasing nitric oxide (NO). NO acts on soluble guanylyl cyclase leading to vasodilation. 

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Action of Hormones

Vitamins A

TSH, GHRH
FSH, LH, hCG
Vasopressin (V2 receptors)
Catecholamines (β receptors)
Somatostatin
Glucagon
Secretin
Parathyroid hormone

Acetylcholine (M2, M4)
Somatostatin

Gq: second messenger is phospholipase C or cGMP

GnRH, GHRH, TRH

Vasopressin (V1 receptor)

Notes:
1. Even though the cytoplasmic receptors are present in the cytoplasm, once the hormone-receptor complex is formed it moves to the nucleus for its actions.

2. Vitamin D is a cytoplasmic receptor. All intracellular receptors are inherently nuclear receptors as they bind and get activated at the nucleus as mentioned above but they have two sites of primary action- cytoplasm and nucleus. 

3. While receptor tyrosine kinases have intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity, non-receptor tyrosine kinases have an external tyrosine kinase component that interacts with the receptor as and when required.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient diagnosed with benign prostatic hyperplasia is posted for laser ablation surgery. Which of the following lasers is commonly used for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Holmium YAG laser is commonly used for laser ablative surgery of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).

Surgical management involves the use of the transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP), which involves electrocautery. Laser ablative techniques use holmium YAG commonly. Laser treatment post-surgery is useful in maintaining the hemostasis of small vessels. KTP laser is used to vaporize prostatic tissue. 

BPH is characterized by symptoms of urinary frequency, urgency, nocturia, incontinence, slow urinary stream, straining to void, urinary intermittency (stream starting and stopping during micturition), or hesitancy, splitting of the voiding stream, and terminal dribbling. Physical examination reveals a smooth enlarged and non-tender prostate. Lab investigations reveal a normal PSA (prostate-specific antigen). Diagnosis is made based on clinical presentation and a lack of lab findings suggestive of malignancy (elevated PSA). A biopsy is rarely indicated.

Medical management includes alpha-adrenergic blocking agents that inhibit the contraction of smooth muscle that is found in the prostate. The other class of drugs is the 5α-reductase inhibitors, which inhibit the conversion of testosterone to DHT, the most active form of androgen. These drugs result in a 25% shrinkage of the prostate gland.

Indications for surgical management:

  • Lower urinary tract symptoms that are refractory to medical therapy
  • Refractory urinary retention
  • Recurrent urinary tract infection (UTI)
  • Recurrent gross hematuria
  • Recurrent bladder stones
  • Bilateral hydronephrosis with renal functional impairment

Related Pearl: Lasers used in various specialities

  • Iridotomy

questions.text:
A 6-year-old girl presents with high-grade fever, diarrhea, and abdominal pain that is unresponsive to medication for the past 4 days. She recently recovered from COVID-19 and there is no other history of illness. On examination, the following findings were observed. Which of the following drugs is used in managing the condition?

General physical examination shows a generalized rash all over her body

HR: 70/min

BP: 100/72 mmHg

RR: 18/min

C-Reactive protein: 12 mg/L

ESR: 62 mm/hr
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the lab values point towards the diagnosis of Multisystemic Inflammatory Syndrome in Children (MIS-C). Since the patient is hemodynamically stable she is classified as MIS-C without shock and IV methylprednisolone 1-2 mg/kg/day is used in the management of this subtype.

Diagnostic criteria for MIS-C:

  1. Children and adolescents 0–18 years of age with fever ≥3 days
  2. And any two of these:
  • Rash or bilateral non-purulent conjunctivitis or mucocutaneous inflammation signs (palmoplantar erythema, lip hyperemia, periorbital erythema and edema, strawberry tongue, and malar erythema).
  • Hypotension or shock
  • Features of myocardial dysfunction, pericarditis, valvulitis, or coronary abnormalities (including ECHO findings or elevated Troponin/ NT-proBNP)
  • Evidence of coagulopathy (PT, PTT, elevated D-Dimers)
  • Acute gastrointestinal problems (diarrhea, vomiting, or abdominal pain)

    3. And elevated ESR >40 mm, C-reactive protein >5 mg/L, or procalcitonin.

    4. And no other obvious microbial cause of inflammation including bacterial sepsis, staphylococcal or streptococcal shock syndromes.

    5. And evidence of COVID-19 (RT-PCR, antigen test, or serology positive), or likely contact with patients with COVID-19.

Other options:

Option A:  IV immunoglobulin 2 mg/kg alone is not used in the management of MIS-C. 

Option C: IV immunoglobulin 2 gm/kg + IV methylprednisolone 1-2 mg/kg/day is used in the Kawasaki phenotype of MIS-C. The absence of fever for more than 5 days without conjunctival findings, cervical lymphadenopathy, strawberry tongue, and swollen hands and feet rule out the possibility of Kawasaki's disease and Kawasaki phenotype of MIS-C.

Option D: Although prednisone has almost similar anti-inflammatory action as methylprednisolone, the latest Ministry of Health & Family Welfare, Govt. of India guidelines prescribe the use of IV methylprednisolone 1-2 mg/kg/day in the management of MIS-C.

questions.text: A mother brings her 8-year-old daughter with precocious puberty and bony pain to the clinic. The finding shown in the image below was found on examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis based on the clinical features and image showing cafe-au-lait spots is McCune-Albright syndrome.

McCune Albright syndrome presents as a triad of cafe-au-lait spots (cutaneous pigmentation), polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, and precocious puberty. Cutaneous pigmentation is more prominent on the side with severe bone involvement. Fibrous dysplasia is the fibrous replacement of cancellous bone as shown below. It can result in bony pain, repeated fractures, and cranial nerve compression.

The condition arises due to activating mutations of the GNAS1 gene and results in polyendocrinopathy. Precocious puberty is more commonly seen in females with the age of onset between 3-6 years. Neonates can present with Cushing's syndrome due to adrenocortical hyperplasia. Hyperthyroidism, hepatic and cardiovascular involvement are other features.

Cafe-au-lait spots are also seen in neurofibromatosis and Legius syndrome.

Other options 

Option B: Cowden syndrome also known as multiple hamartoma syndrome arises due to a mutation in the PTEN gene. Clinical features include macrocephaly, developmental delay, and breast or thyroid malignancies. It is also associated with the development of gastrointestinal polyps. The image below shows facial trichilemmomas.

Option C: Leopard syndrome/ multiple lentigines syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition that presents with a generalized symmetric distribution of lentigines. Lentigines are small, dark-brown, and round macules as shown below. Other features include ocular hypertelorism, pulmonary stenosis, and sensorineural deafness. 

Option D: Bloom syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder with genomic instability. The clinical features are short stature, photosensitivity, and telangiectatic erythema. It predisposes to the development of childhood leukemia. 

The image below shows the facial appearance seen in the condition.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman hailing from China has been diagnosed with Keshan's disease. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding her condition?

choices.text: Glutathione peroxidase has the involved element
Deficient element is a component of  the 22nd amino acid

questions.solution:
Keshan's disease occurs due to selenium deficiency which is a component of the 21st amino acid - Selenocysteine. 

Keshan disease is endemic cardiomyopathy found in children and young women residing in regions of China where the dietary intake of selenium is low. Mainly dilated cardiomyopathy (Option D) is the characteristic feature, but it may also result in congestive cardiac failure, cardiomegaly, and fulminant cardiogenic shock. It is associated with tumorigenesis and atherosclerosis (Option C).

Selenium is an important trace element that is a part of Selenocysteine. Selenocysteine is the 21st amino acid coded by the UGA codon, which is normally a stop codon. It is formed by co-translational modification. The protein synthetic apparatus can identify a selenocysteine-encoding UGA by the presence of the selenocysteine insertion sequence (SECIS) in the untranslated region of mRNA. There are many selenium-containing enzymes such as :

  • Glutathione peroxidase (Option A)
  • De-iodinase
  • Thioredoxin reductase

Selenium is also an intracellular antioxidant that complements the role of Vitamin E. Dietary sources of selenium include seafood, muscle meat, and some cereals.

questions.text: Which of the following actions is examined and what is the defect observed in a patient with abducens nerve palsy?
questions.solution:
Abducens nerve innervates the lateral rectus muscle. The action produced by this muscle is abduction. The sixth cranial nerve palsy results in an esotropia/convergent squint.

The outward movement (abduction) of the affected eye is impaired, and the face will be turned towards the same side. When the patient looks at the paralyzed side, they will experience homonymous diplopia. 

Esotropia can be revealed using the cover-uncover test. 

First, the patient has to fix their gaze by looking at a distant object. One of the eyes is covered while simultaneously observing the other eye. If the other eye moves away from the nose, then esotropia is present. This procedure should be repeated on the other eye. 

 

The occulomotor nerve supplies all extraocular muscles except:

  • Lateral rectus, which is supplied by the 6th nerve
  • Superior oblique, which is supplied by the 4th nerve 

The following image shows the actions of all extraocular muscles:

questions.text: The induction agent of choice in a child with croup is:
questions.solution:
The induction agent of choice in a child with croup is sevoflurane.

Viral croup (laryngotracheobronchitis) is responsible for the majority of cases of acute stridor in children. It occurs due to infection with parainfluenza viruses commonly, but it may also be caused by influenza viruses type A or B, respiratory syncytial virus, or rhinovirus. Children aged 6 months to 3 years are commonly affected. Infection results in subglottic and tracheal swelling causing stridor and other signs of respiratory obstruction.

In infants and young children, the upper and lower airways are small, prone to occlusion by secretions, and susceptible to edema and swelling. As a result, the resistance to laminar airflow increases in inverse proportion to the fourth power of the radius (Poiseuille's law). Therefore, a small decrease in the radius of the airway results in a marked increase in resistance to airflow and the work of breathing. Children are more reliant on the diaphragm for inspiration, due to the relative immaturity of the intercostal muscles and accessory muscles.

Treatment includes humidification of respiratory gases, oxygen, steroids, and nebulized epinephrine. Steroids reduce symptoms and improve croup scores 6–24 h after initial dosing, thereby reducing the need for intubation or shortening the time to extubation.

Severe respiratory obstruction, as indicated by a persistently high croup score of >7, despite ongoing medical treatment, is an indication for tracheal intubation. Oxygen should be given by mask if required. Historically, halothane was the agent of choice for induction and maintenance of anesthesia in upper airway obstruction however, sevoflurane is safe and effective in this situation. 

Halothane has largely been replaced by sevoflurane, particularly for induction. Studies show that the incidence of complications in children with mild upper respiratory tract infection was similar between sevoflurane and halothane but that sevoflurane provided a more rapid recovery profile. Other studies, however, suggest that sevoflurane results in fewer complications than halothane, particularly when sevoflurane is used for both induction and maintenance. 

Other options:

Option A - Nitrous oxide is odorless. It is also commonly used for inhalational induction in cooperative children but is not the agent of choice for induction in children with croup.

Option C - Isoflurane has a relatively more noxious smell than sevoflurane, which makes an inhalational induction with it unacceptable for most children.

Option D - Desflurane is not suitable for inhalational induction in children because of its pungent odor and the associated effects of laryngospasm. 

Related Pearl: Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC)

Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) is the minimum concentration of an inhaled anesthetic at 1 atm of pressure that prevents skeletal muscle movement in response to a surgical incision in 50% of patients. 

MAC of inhaled anesthetics

Anesthetic Agents

MAC (Potency)

Blood-gas coefficient (Solubility)
Halothane 0.75  2.4
Isoflurane 1.2 1.4 
Enflurane 1.7 1.9 
Sevoflurane 2 0.65 
Desflurane 6 0.42 
Nitrous oxide 104 0.47 

MAC is an indicator of potency. The lower the MAC, the higher is the potency.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with complaints of dysphagia. She also says that her hands and feet turn cold and blue when she goes to visit her daughter who lives in a hill station. Her examination findings are as given in the image. What is the earliest cutaneous manifestation that can be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of systemic sclerosis. The earliest cutaneous manifestations in systemic sclerosis are non-pitting edema and puffiness of the fingers, hands, and face. 

The image shows a woman with mask-like facies with stretched, shiny skin, and loss of normal facial lines, microstomia, and resorption of distal phalanges of the fingers. The clinical history describes Raynaud's phenomenon (hands and feet turn cold and blue in cold climate) and hence, the probable diagnosis is systemic sclerosis.

Systemic sclerosis is an autoimmune rheumatic disease in which there is a 4: 1 female predominance.

Cutaneous features:

  • Hands and feet - Raynaud's phenomenon, non-pitting edema, painful ulcerations which heal with pitted scars, sclerodactyly, contractures, loss of sweat glands, bone resorption.
  • Face - periorbital edema, mask-like facies, telangiectasia, and diffuse hyperpigmentation.
  • Trunk - firm, shiny, and thickened skin.
  • Reduced hair growth is seen.

Systemic features:

  • GIT- dysphagia, GERD, diminished peristalsis, malabsorption
  • Lungs- pulmonary fibrosis and alveolitis
  • Heart- cardiac conduction defects, heart failure
  • Kidney- uremia, malignant hypertension
  • Musculoskeletal- weakness, carpal tunnel syndrome.

Using modified Rodnan skin score (MRSS). the degree of skin sclerosis is scored from 0 to 3 by manual palpation at 17 different body sites. The maximum score that can be attained is 51. This method has been shown to correlate with skin biopsy thickness, disease severity, and long‐term outcome of the disease.

The scoring of each skin region is determined by skin thickness and tethering:
0 = Normal
1 = Possible thickening
2 = Unable to pinch the skin
3 = Unable to move the skin (which is fixed to deeper tissues)

This modified score does not include the assessment of the neck and back. If these areas are included, the maximum attainable score increases to 57.

questions.text: A woman has a luteinizing hormone surge due to the positive feedback mechanism. Which of the following will additionally be associated with this?
questions.solution:
Increased FSH (follicle-stimulating hormone) levels in the peripheral circulation are associated with LH (luteinizing hormone) surge.

Phases

Hormone

Type of feedback

Site

FSH and LH secretion

Follicular

Estrogen

Negative

Anterior pituitary

Both suppressed

Midcycle

Estrogen

Positive

Anterior pituitary

Increased LH surge and FSH levels

Luteal

Estrogen

Progesterone

Negative

Negative

Anterior pituitary

Anterior pituitary

Both are decreased

During the follicular phase, inhibin B is low and FSH is moderately elevated inducing follicular growth. LH secretion is limited due to the negative feedback of rising plasma levels of estrogen.

36-48 hours before ovulation, the estrogen gives positive feedback to the hypothalamus and pituitary resulting in LH surge. FSH secretion also peaks at his time due to increased gonadotropes stimulation by GnRH (gonadotropin-releasing hormone) despite a small rise in inhibin.

During the luteal phase, LH and FSH levels are low due to the negative feedback effect of elevated levels of estrogen, progesterone, and inhibin.

Related Pearl: Hormonal Regulation of Menstrual Cycle

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with anorexia nervosa. All of the following lab findings can be associated except :
questions.solution:
Hypocholestrolemia is not seen in anorexia nervosa.

Anorexia Nervosa is a syndrome characterized by significant self-induced starvation, a morbid fear of weight gain, and the presence of medical signs and symptoms of starvation.

Investigations in anorexia nervosa:

  • Complete blood count: Leukopenia with a relative lymphocytosis
  • Serum electrolyte: Hypokalemic alkalosis (purging)
  • Fasting serum glucose: Often low (emaciated phase)
  • Serum salivary amylase: Often elevated (if the patient is vomiting)
  • ECG: ST-segment and T-wave changes (secondary to electrolyte disturbances)
  • Hypotension and bradycardia
  • High serum cholesterol level
  • Endocrine changes (caused by the underweight):
    • Amenorrhea
    • Hypothyroidism
    • Hypersecretion of corticotrophin-releasing hormone

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman presented to the emergency room with sudden pain in the right upper quadrant of her abdomen. Initial ultrasound evaluation showed free fluid in the peritoneum. The ascitic fluid is aspirated for investigations. Which of the following laboratory findings will point to a diagnosis of early-onset Budd-Chiari syndrome?

SAAG - Serum-ascites albumin gradient
questions.solution:
A laboratory finding of Serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) >1.1g/dL and ascitic protein >2.5g/dL will point to a diagnosis of early-onset Budd-Chiari syndrome.

A SAAG is used to differentiate between the portal and nonportal hypertensive ascites. It represents the pressure within the hepatic sinusoids and correlates with the hepatic venous pressure gradient.

It is given by the formula: SAAG = Serum albumin - ascitic fluid albumin.

Interpretation of SAAG:

  • SAAG ≥1.1 g/dL indicates that the ascites is due to increased pressure in the hepatic sinusoids. It reflects the presence of portal hypertension.
  • SAAG <1.1 g/dL indicates that the ascites is not related to portal hypertension. It may be due to infection or malignancy.

In cases with high-SAAG (≥1.1), ascitic protein level analysis further helps in identifying the etiology:

  • ≥2.5 g/dL indicates that the hepatic sinusoids are normal and are allowing the passage of protein into the ascites. eg. early Budd-Chiari syndrome.
  • <2.5 g/dL indicates that the hepatic sinusoids have been damaged and scarred and no longer allow passage of protein. Eg. late Budd-Chiari syndrome.

Budd-Chiari syndrome (BCS) is a form of congestive hepatopathy caused due to blockage of the hepatic venous outflow anywhere along the venous course between the hepatic venules to the junction of the inferior vena cava (IVC) to the right atrium. Hypercoagulable states due to primary myeloproliferative diseases are the leading cause of the disease.

Investigations for BCS include: 

  • Elevated bilirubin, liver enzymes with decreased albumin is usually seen.
  • Doppler ultrasonography of the liver: highly sensitive, specific, initial investigation of choice. Hepatic veins without flow signal, with spider-web appearance, collateral hepatic venous circulation and stagnant, reversed or turbulent flow are indicative of BCS
  • Magnetic resonance imaging
  • Hepatic venography: a spider-web pattern confirms BCS
  • Liver biopsy 
  • Echocardiography
  • Diagnosis of the underlying cause of thrombosis is important.

Management strategy includes:

  • Anticoagulation
  • Treatment of identified prothrombotic risk factors
  • Percutaneous revascularization, transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic stent shunt (TIPSS): to re-establish hepatic venous drainage
  • Liver transplantation in unresponsive patients.
 
5-year prognosis is >90% while the long-term outcome is influenced by any underlying haematological condition and development of hepatocellular carcinoma.

High serum levels of brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) can be used to identify heart failure as the cause of high-SAAG ascites.

Low ascitic glucose level <50 mg/dL and high ascitic LDH level are indicative of ascites due to secondary peritonitis.

Ascitic amylase level >1000 mg/dL is indicative of pancreatic ascites.

Tuberculous peritonitis is typically associated with ascitic fluid lymphocytosis and elevated adenosine deaminase levels.

Other options: 

Option D: SAAG >1.1g/dl and ascitic protein <2.5g/dl is seen in liver cirrhosis, late Budd-Chiari syndrome, and massive liver metastases.

Options A and B are not possible. 

Related Pearl: Serum Ascites Albumin Gradient (SAAG)

The serum ascites albumin gradient is calculated as follows:

SAAG = Serum albumin - Ascitic fluid albumin

It can be used to determine the cause of ascites following ascitic fluid analysis.

questions.text: A young boy is brought to the clinic with complaints of abdominal pain, diarrhea, and painful straining for 4 months. The symptoms were accompanied by rectal prolapse. Stool examination showed the following finding. Infection with which of the following helminths is most likely?
questions.solution:
The image shows a barrel-shaped ovum, which along with rectal prolapse is characteristic of trichuris trichiura. 

Trichuriasis is caused by T. trichiura (whipworm), which inhabits the cecum and ascending colon. They bury their thin heads into the intestinal lining causing edema, loosening the elastic epithelium, and weakening the surrounding muscles. This leads to loss of supports and rectal prolapse. Other clinical features include chronic dysentery, anemia, poor growth, and developmental defects.

Diagnosis is done by fecal smears showing the barrel-shaped ovum of T. trichiura.

The image below shows the barrel-shaped ovum of Trichuris trichiura.

Albendazole is the drug of choice (400 mg, orally, for 3 days; for all ages).

questions.text: A 25-year-old man with a fever and chronic cough is administered 0.1 mL of a liquid containing 5 TU(tuberculin units) of purified protein derivative (PPD) into the top layers of skin of the forearm. After a few hours, the reaction at the injection site is as seen below.  This mechanism behind this reaction is observed in the etiopathogenesis of all the following diseases except?
questions.solution:
A positive tuberculin test is an example of Type IV or cell-mediated hypersensitivity reaction. All the diseases in the given options are T-cell mediated except for systemic lupus erythematosus which is an immune complex-mediated disease or Type III hypersensitivity reaction.

Tuberculin reaction

  • The classic example of delayed-type hypersensitivity is the tuberculin reaction, which is produced by the intracutaneous injection of purified protein derivative (PPD, also called tuberculin), a protein-containing antigen of the tubercle bacillus.
  • In a previously sensitized individual, reddening and induration of the site appear in 8 to 12 hours, reach a peak in 24 to 72 hours, and thereafter slowly subside.
  • Morphologically, delayed-type hypersensitivity is characterized by the accumulation of mononuclear cells, mainly CD4+ T cells and macrophages, around venules.
  • The cell-mediated type of hypersensitivity is caused by inflammation resulting from cytokines produced by CD4+ T cells and cell killing by CD8+ T cells.

Mechanisms of T-cell-mediated hypersensitivity reactions

  • It includes the delayed-type hypersensitivity reactions mediated by CD4+ T cells and direct cell cytotoxicity mediated by CD8+ T cells

Cytokine-mediated inflammation:

  • CD4+ T cells are activated by exposure to a protein antigen and differentiate into TH1 and TH17 effector cells.
  • IL-12 is produced by macrophages and dendritic cells and is critical in the pathogenesis of delayed hypersensitivity because it induces the TH1 response.
  • Subsequent exposure to the antigen results in the secretion of cytokines.
  • IFN-γ activates macrophages to produce substances that cause tissue damage and promote fibrosis, and IL-17 and other cytokines recruit leukocytes, thus promoting inflammation.

T cell-mediated cytotoxicity

  • CD8+ cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs) specific for an antigen recognize cells expressing the target antigen and kill these cells. CD8+ T cells also secrete IFN-γ.

Two mechanisms

  • Perforin granzyme dependent killing: The mediators present in the lysosomal granules of the CTLs like perforin cause pore formation and the granzyme activates apoptosis on entering the cells via these pores.
  • Fas–Fas ligand-dependent killing

T Cell-Mediated Disease :

  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Type 1 diabetes mellitus
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Psoriasis

Related Pearl: Examples of Type IV Hypersensitivity

Type IV Hypersensitivity Reactions 

  • Tuberculin reaction
  • Lepromin test
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Chronic graft rejection
  • Contact dermatitis
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Primary biliary cirrhosis
  • Type I lepra reaction
  • Crohn’s disease
  • Psoriasis

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is admitted to the hospital with a hearing defect. An MRI examination reveals that she has development defects in the auditory tube and middle ear cavity. Which of the following marked embryonal structures is most likely to be developed abnormally?

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman came to a gynecology OPD. She is worried about the post-menopausal symptoms and requests hormone replacement therapy (HRT) as prophylaxis.  Which among the following is not a contraindication for prescribing HRT?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, history of smoking is not a contraindication for prescribing HRT.

Hypertension, diabetes, and smoking are not contraindications, provided they are regularly monitored. In fact, cardiac disease, stroke, and smoking may be the indications for estrogen therapy to derive benefit and improve their health from estrogen deficiency.

HRT is not required for all women and it might cause complications. However, it is logical to prescribe HRT and not withhold it when one needs it in the minimal effective dose for the shortest needed duration under the supervision. Initially, every menopausal woman was advised HRT as soon as menopause set in. Recent researches reveal that a few women need prophylactic and therapeutic HRT and 70–85% of women remain healthy and need only good nutrition and a healthy lifestyle.

Indications of HRT:

  • Therapeutic
    • Symptomatic women who suffer from estrogen deficiency
    • Gonadal dysgenesis in adolescents
  • Prophylactic
    • High-risk cases for menopausal complications such as cardiovascular disease, osteoporosis, stroke, Alzheimer’s disease, and colonic cancer
    • Premature menopause, spontaneous or following surgery 
    • Menopause caused by radiotherapy and chemotherapy for cancer, especially alkylating agents 
    • Women demanding HRT as prophylaxis

Contraindications of HRT:

  • Undiagnosed abnormal genital bleeding
  • Known, suspected, or history of breast cancer
  • Known or suspected estrogen-dependent neoplasia
  • Active or prior venous thromboembolism
  • Active or recent (e.g., within the past year) arterial thromboembolic disease
  • Liver dysfunction or gall bladder disease
  • Known hypersensitivity to the ingredients of the estrogen preparation
  • Known or suspected pregnancy
  • Uterine fibroids as the fibroids may enlarge in size.

Uses of HRT:

  • Short term-hot flushes, vasomotor symptoms
  • Dyspareunia, libido
  • Urethral syndrome
  • Long term-osteoporosis
  • Cardiovascular disease
  • Alzheimer’s disease

Risks of HRT:

  • Endometrial cancer
  • Breast cancer
  • Ovarian cancer
  • Thromboembolism
  • Lipid profile dysfunction
  • Gall stones, liver dysfunction

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents to the outpatient department with fever, epigastric discomfort, progressive weight loss, arthralgia, and foul-smelling diarrhea for the past 6 months. There is no relation between the abdominal pain and his bowel movements. He was started on a restrictive diet, which showed no improvement. His biopsy is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is whipple disease which is caused by a gram-positive actinomycete, named Tropheryma whipplei.

Whipple's disease is a chronic multisystem disorder caused by a gram-positive bacteria Tropheryma whipplei. It presents as 

  • Diarrhea
  • Steatorrhea due to malabsorption caused by impaired lymphatic transport.
  • Weight loss
  • Arthralgia
  • Central nervous system problems
  • Cardiac problems

The morphologic hallmark of whipple disease is a dense accumulation of distended, foamy macrophages in the small intestinal lamina propria. Macrophages contain periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive, diastase-resistant granules that represent lysosomes stuffed with partially digested bacteria.

Other options:

Option A: Irritable bowel syndrome presents with recurrent abdominal pain that may be - 

  • related to defecation
  • associated with a change in frequency 
  • associated with a change in appearance

Despite having these symptoms, the endoscopy and microscopic examination are normal in patients with irritable bowel syndrome.

Option C: Cystic fibrosis is a congenital disorder due to a mutation in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene located on chromosome 7. It leads to abnormal transport of chloride and bicarbonate ions in the lungs, gastrointestinal tract, pancreas and reproductive tract. It presents as

  • Lungs - recurrent respiratory infections. 
  • Pancreas - exocrine pancreatic insufficiency causing fat malabsorption and steatorrhoea. 
  • Reproductive tract - infertility due to absent vas deferens.

Option D: Celiac disease is an autoimmune gluten-induced enteropathy where there is an excessive inflammatory response to gluten and its breakdown product, gliadin. This leads to inflammatory infiltration of the lamina propria which subsequently impairs various nutrient absorption.

Clinically, it presents as a malabsorption syndrome with diarrhea, abdominal pain, and marked weight loss. Microscopic findings show

  • Villi atrophy
  • Villi flattening
  • Crypt hyperplasia
  • Increased intraepithelial T lymphocytes

Symptoms usually subside with a gluten restricted diet.

Image: Microscopic image of celiac disease

Related Pearl: Investigations in Malabsorption Syndrome

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents with severe abdominal pain. It began in the periumbilical area 10 hours ago and later migrated to the right lower quadrant of the abdomen. She has had intermittent nausea, vomiting, and low-grade fever since the pain began. Her last menstrual period was 28 days ago. Examination reveals tachycardia and positive Rovsing's sign. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is acute appendicitis. 

The symptom of migrating abdominal pain from the periumbilical area to the right iliac fossa is classic for appendicitis. It begins as generalized visceral irritation and then changes to localized somatic pain in the right iliac fossa. In addition, this patient has a positive Rovsing's sign, which is pain in the right iliac fossa when left iliac fossa is deeply palpated.

The abdominal pain also causes nausea and vomiting as is seen in this patient. Other nonspecific signs of appendicitis include low-grade fever, abdominal tenderness, guarding, and rebound tenderness. McBurney's point depicting the area of maximal tenderness will also support a diagnosis of appendicitis. 

The Alvarado (MANTRELS) Score
Symptoms Score
Migratory right iliac fossa pain 1
Anorexia 1
Nausea and vomiting 1
Signs  
Tenderness (right iliac fossa) 2
Rebound tenderness 1
Elevated temperature 1
Laboratory  
Leucocytosis 2
Shift to the left 1
Total 10

A score of more than 7 is strongly predictive of acute appendicitis. If the score is 5-6, then an ultrasound or contrast-enhanced CT should be performed to confirm. 

Other options: 

Option B - Ruptured ectopic pregnancy would have pain that begins on one side and does not migrate. There would also have a history of a missed menstrual period while this patient is due for her period soon. A urine pregnancy test and an ultrasound would confirm the diagnosis. 

Option C - Acute diverticulitis is more common in patients over the age of 60. In addition, diverticulitis is more likely to happen on the left side as it usually occurs in the sigmoid area. A CT scan would help in diagnosis. 

Option D - Torsion ovary presents with severe pain and a tender palpable mass in the hypogastrium arising from the pelvis. Pelvic ultrasound should be done.

Related Pearl: Oshner Sherren Regimen

Principle :

  • The inflammatory process is already localised and that inadvertent surgery is difficult and may be dangerous.
  • It may be impossible to find the appendix and, occasionally, a faecal fistula may form.
  • Antibiotic therapy should be given after performing CECT abdomen
  • Abscess if present can be drained radiologically.

Outcome :

  • Improvement in 24–48 h
  • 90% cases resolve
  • Failure should raise suspicion of Crohn’s disease and carcinoma. 

Criteria for stopping conservative treatment of Appendicular mass:

  • Rising pulse rate
  • Increasing or spreading abdominal pain
  • Increasing size of the mass

questions.text: A 4-year-old child with excoriation of anal skin was brought by his mother to the pediatric OPD. She states her son scratches his anal area frequently during nighttime. The life cycle of the causative organism is given below. Which of the following is not a feature of the egg of this organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of frequent anal area scratching during nighttime, excoriation of the skin around the anus, and the given life cycle of humans acquiring infection by ingestion of embryonated eggs, which are released by the gravid female over the perianal skin are suggestive of pinworm or Enterobius vermicularis infection. The eggs of pinworms are not bile-stained.

The pinworm eggs have a characteristic plano-convex shape. They are colorless and not bile-stained. They have a thick, double-layered, transparent eggshell. The eggs also float in a saturated salt solution. Inside lies a tadpole-shaped coiled embryo. The eggs are highly infectious, and reinfection should be prevented by regular washing of bed linens, towels, and clothing in hot water.

Enterobius vermicularis completes its entire life cycle in the human host. Infection is acquired by ingesting embryonated eggs containing larva through contaminated fingers and by autoinfection. At night, the gravid female worm comes out through the anus, crawls around on the perianal and perineal skin, and lays its eggs. This leads to pruritus, and the patient scratches the affected perianal area. The worm can crawl into the vulva and vagina, causing irritation and a mucoid discharge. It can also cause chronic salpingitis, cervicitis, peritonitis, recurrent urinary tract infections, and appendicitis.

A faecal examination is not useful for diagnosis as the eggs are not usually released in faeces. The eggs can be demonstrated by swabbing the perianal and perineal skin where they are deposited. The adult worms may sometimes be noticed on the surface of stools, can be found crawling out of the anus, or may be detected in stools collected after an enema.

The NIH swab (National Institutes of Health, USA) is used to collect specimens for diagnosis. In the NIH swab, the perianal area is swabbed by rolling the cellophane part over it. After detaching the cellophane part, it is spread over a glass slide and examined microscopically. The image given below shows the NIH swab.

Another method is the scotch tape method, where the tape is firmly pressed against the anal margin, covering all sides. The tape is transferred to a glass slide with the sticky side down. Then, a drop of toluene is added for clearing and examined under the microscope.

Treatment involves a single dose of Pyrantel pamoate 11 mg/kg, albendazole 400mg, or mebendazole 100mg. Piperazine is given once daily for a week.

questions.text: A postoperative patient on a ventilator was shifted to the intensive care unit for monitoring. When he woke up, he was unaware of his location, date, and time. He started to move violently on the bed and threw medicines at the nurses. Which of the following drugs having selective α2 agonist property can be used to sedate the patient?
questions.solution:
Dexmedetomidine can be used to sedate this patient.

Dexmedetomidine is a directly acting α2 -selective sympathomimetic drug. Activation of the α2A adrenergic receptor by dexmedetomidine produces both sedation and analgesia.

It is usually used in short-term sedation (<24 hours) of intubated patients and aids in easy awakening from the postoperative state without any respiratory depression. It is administered as an IV infusion. Side effects are hypotension, bradycardia, and dry mouth. 

Sympathomimetics are drugs that mimic the stimulation of the sympathetic nervous system. These are classified as:

  • Direct-acting (adrenergic receptor agonists) -  
    • Non-selective - epinephrine (α1, α2, β1, β2, and β3), noradrenaline (α1, α2, and β1), droxidopa (α and β)
    • Selective - 
      • α1-agonists such as phenylephrine and midodrine
      • α2-agonists such as apraclonidine, brimonidine, clonidine, guanabenz, α-methyl dopa, lofexidine, and tizanidine
      • β2-agonist such as terbutaline 
  • Indirect-acting (release epinephrine or noradrenaline to stimulate adrenergic receptors) - amphetamine, tyramine, etc
  • Mixed-acting - ephedrine

The various uses of α-agonists are:

  • Glaucoma - apraclonidine and brimonidine. They cause CNS depression and apnea in neonates, therefore contraindicated in children <2 years of age
  • Postural hypotension - prodrugs like midodrine and droxidopa 
  • Hypertension - centrally acting anti-hypertensives such as clonidine, guanabenz, and α-methyl dopa 
  • Opioid withdrawal - lofexidine
  • Muscle-relaxant - tizanidine 
 

Related Pearl: Antiglaucoma drugs: Mechanism of lowering intraocular pressure (IOP) at a glance

Drugs that increase trabecular outflow

  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Bimatoprost
  • Rho-kinase inhibitor (Netarsudil)

Drugs that increase uveoscleral outflow

  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine

  • Apraclonidine

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presented to a dermatologist with hyperpigmented macules on her face (image given below). She says that the macules exacerbated after her honeymoon at Bali. Which among the given options is the first-line treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
Hyperpigmented macules in the face that exacerbate with sun exposure depict melasma. Among the given options, tretinoin is the most appropriate first-line treatment. 

Melasma

It is the most common cause of facial melanosis that manifests as hyperpigmented macules on the face. It is related to sun exposure and oral contraceptive pills. The condition is more common in females. 

Melasma presents as hyper melanosis of the upper lip, malar regions, forehead, and chin. There may also be darkening of the nipples, linea alba, and groin. The lesions are usually bilateral and symmetrical. 

In a pregnant woman, melasma is called chloasma (also known as mask of pregnancy). Chloasma is very common in the 3rd trimester of pregnancy.

Wood's lamp examination is useful to differentiate the level of pigmentation and treatment response:  

  • Epidermal melasma- shows enhanced color contrast 
  • Dermal melasma- shows less color contrast (more resistant to treatment)
  • Mixed melasma.

Treatment 

  • First-line - Sun protection, changing oral contraceptives, and triple therapy with topical hydroquinone, tretinoin, and corticosteroid cream.
  • Second-line - Chemical peels, Azelaic acid alone or in combination with tretinoin.
  • Third line - Laser therapy, light therapy, dermabrasion, topical liquiritin, topical rucinol, kojic acid, and hydroquinone.

Related Pearl: Key Chart to help differentiate lesions on face

questions.text: A 60-year-old man was brought to the emergency with complaints of palpitations. On examination, he was tachycardic with an irregularly irregular rhythm. He is a known case of long-standing emphysema. His ECG is given below. Which of the following modalities is ineffective in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the ECG showing different p-wave morphologies and the irregular interval between p-waves are suggestive of multifocal atrial tachycardia. Electric cardioversion is an ineffective treatment modality.

Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) is a supraventricular arrhythmia characterised by:

  • Heart rate >100-150bpm
  • At least 3 different non-sinus p-wave morphology
  • Clear but irregular isoelectric intervals between p waves

The most common etiology is any underlying pulmonary disease - COPD (chronic obstructive pulmonary disease). Other causes include hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia, the postoperative period after major surgery, drugs like aminophylline and theophylline and pulmonary artery hypertension.

MAT is typically seen in elderly patients. Most patients are hemodynamically stable and generally present with tachycardia and irregularly irregular rhythm. Diagnosis is done based on the electrocardiogram features mentioned above.

MAT is characterised by at least 3 distinct P-wave morphologies as shown by arrows in the image below.

Treatment of underlying disease is the mainstay of the management of MAT. If patients are symptomatic treatment should begin with the correction of hypokalemia to maintain >4 mEq/L and hypomagnesemia to maintain >2 mEq/L. 

In the absence of pulmonary disease, beta-blockers are the first-line treatment. In the presence of pulmonary disease, a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker such as verapamil or diltiazem is the first line. Ablation of the AV node is usually done when patients do not respond to or cannot tolerate pharmacologic therapy. Electric cardioversion is ineffective.

Differential diagnoses of MAT include:

Sinus tachycardia with frequent premature atrial contractions - this would have regular PP intervals.

Atrial flutter shows flutter waves as given in the below ECG.

Atrial fibrillation would not have discrete P-wave morphologies.

Related Pearl: Supraventricular tachycardias

  • Narrow QRS with regular RR interval

  • Narrow QRS with irregular RR interval

Atrial flutter/tachycardia with variable block ECG features of heart block are seen.

questions.text: A normal healthy adult participated in a respiratory study that was conducted to understand the respiratory functions. In the upright position, an increase in all of the following parameters can be seen with respect to the base of the lungs except?
questions.solution:
In the upright position, an increase in the ventilation-perfusion ratio (V/Q ratio) is not seen with respect to the base of the lungs. At the base of the lung, the V/Q ratio is decreased. 

V/Q ratio is the ratio of alveolar ventilation (V) to pulmonary blood flow (Q) for the lungs at rest. The average value of the V/Q ratio throughout the lungs is 0.8. When this ratio is mismatched, it can cause CO2 retention (when solely, ventilation is impaired) or lowered arterial O2 (when perfusion is impaired). 

Normally, in the upright position, the V/Q ratio in the normal lungs markedly undergoes changes from the apex to the base due to the effect of gravity as shown below - 

At the base of the lung:

Both ventilation and perfusion increase since the flow is towards gravity.

Increased ventilation is due to the increase in intrapleural pressure compared to the apex, thereby making the intrapulmonary intrapleural pressure difference less at the base. Thus, due to this low-pressure difference, the lung is less expanded compared to the apex. This makes the ventilation per unit volume rise as the lung expansion is relatively small. 

The alveolar pressure also decreases thus reducing the compression of the vessels and increasing the pulmonary blood flow at the base. An increase in perfusion is more than an increase in ventilation, i.e., denominator increases. Hence, the ratio decreases.

At the apex (against gravity):

Both ventilation and perfusion decrease since the flow is against gravity.

The reason for decreased ventilation is that at the start of inspiration, intrapleural pressure is more negative thus making the intrapulmonary intrapleural pressure difference increase at the apex. The apex is above the level of the heart and capillary pressure at the apex is close to atmospheric pressure thus decreasing the blood flow. But, a decrease in perfusion is higher than a decrease in ventilation. Hence, the ratio increases.

questions.text: Oligohydramnios is defined as the single deepest vertical pocket of less than ____
questions.solution:
Oligohydramnios is defined as the single deepest vertical pocket of less than 2 cm.

Oligohydramnios is defined as:

  • Amniotic fluid volume<200ml
  • AFI<5cm
  • Single deepest vertical pocket <2cm

Causes include post-term pregnancy, renal agenesis, posterior urethral valve, persistent cloaca, sirenomelia (mermaid syndrome or single fused lower extremity that occupies the midline), amnion nodosum (failure of secretion by the cells of the amnion covering the placenta), etc.

Polyhydramnios is defined as:

  • Amniotic fluid volume>2L
  • AFI >24cm
  • Single deepest vertical pocket>8cm

Causes include diabetes, anencephaly, facial clefts, esophageal or duodenal atresia, Barter syndrome, ureteropelvic junction obstruction, aneuploidy, chorioangioma of the placenta, etc.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man living in Nellore, Andhra Pradesh, comes to the OPD with difficulty in walking. Oral examination reveals the following. Crippling permanent disability occurs when the concentration of the offending agent exceeds _____.
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the image given above are indicative of fluorosis. Permanent disability/crippling fluorosis occurs when the concentration exceeds 10 mg/L.

Fluorosis occurs when drinking water contains excess amounts of fluorine, in the range of 3–5 mg/L. It is endemic in parts of India- Andhra Pradesh, Punjab, Haryana, Karnataka, Kerala, Tamil Nadu. 

Symptoms correspond to levels of fluoride intake:

  • Dental fluorosis: (1.5 mg/L) Occurs if excess fluoride is ingested during the period of tooth calcification, i.e. in the first 7 years of life. It causes mottling on dental enamel, the appearance of chalky-white patches on the teeth, and loss of shine in the early stages. The white spots progressively turn yellow and can even become brown-black. The loss of enamel gives a corroded appearance. 
  • Skeletal fluorosis: (3-6 mg/L) Occurs due to the heavy deposition of fluoride in the skeleton. Fluorosis stimulates osteoblastic activity, fluorapatite crystals are laid down in bone and these are usually resistant to secondary osteoclastic resorption. This leads to calcium retention, osteosclerosis, and osteophytosis. Ossification of ligaments and fascial attachments is characteristic.
  • Crippling fluorosis: (>10 mg/L) Can lead to permanent disability. 

Genu valgum and osteoporosis of the lower limb are seen in a newer form of fluorosis. It is seen in people consuming jowar (sorghum), as it promotes greater retention of ingested fluoride.

Interventions for Fluorosis: 

  • Change the drinking water source with a lower fluoride content (0.5 to 0.8 mg/L). 
  • Nalgonda technique is used for the defluoridation of water; it involves the addition of lime and alum followed by flocculation, sedimentation, and filtration.
  • Fluoride supplements should not be prescribed for children who drink fluoridated water.
  • The use of fluoride toothpaste in areas of endemic fluorosis is not recommended for children up to 6 years of age.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old assigned female at birth is currently receiving hormonal injections for gender transition into a man. The patient has had feelings of maleness for years that caused significant distress. During a routine health check-up of this patient, which of the following will be done?
  1. Monitoring hematocrit/hemoglobin levels
  2. Monitoring serum prolactin levels
  3. Monitoring of lipid profile
  4. Monitoring of liver function tests
  5. Consider a 'Bottom surgery' consisting of vaginoplasty
questions.solution:
For a patient whose sex was assigned female at birth, who is undergoing hormonal treatment for gender transition, monitoring of hematocrit/hemoglobin levels, liver function tests, and lipid profile should be done in a routine checkup. The hormonal injections for transition are most probably testosterone injections. 

Monitoring of patients on testosterone therapy is essential to the treatment. Monitoring includes hemoglobin/hematocrit levels, as testosterone may cause an increase in red blood cell counts leading to stroke. Like all steroid hormones, testosterone is processed in the liver, so routine liver function tests should be obtained. Clinicians also want to monitor cholesterol and screen for diabetes, as testosterone treatment may lead to lipid abnormalities and diabetes.

Gender dysphoria refers to any distress that occurs due to the incongruence between an individual's assigned gender and the experienced or expressed gender. 

Management of gender dysphoria in adults includes mental health treatment and psychotherapy, hormonal treatment, and surgical treatment. 

Hormonal treatment:

In transgender men, testosterone treatment is given by injections every week or every alternate week. Initial changes include increased acne, muscle mass, and libido. Menses usually stop within the first few months. Permanent changes include deepening of the voice, increased body hair, and enlargement of the clitoris. Hemoglobin/hematocrit levels, liver function tests, cholesterol, and diabetes screening should be done.

In trans women, hormonal treatment with estrogen, testosterone-blockers, or progesterone cause softening of the skin, redistribution of fat, and breast growth. There is no change in voice, as testosterone has permanently altered the vocal cords, hence, many seek voice coaching. Those on estrogen should avoid cigarette smoking, due to an increased risk of blood clots. Blood pressure, liver function, and cholesterol should be monitored. In addition, providers routinely test prolactin as this hormone can increase in patients on estrogen therapy.

Counseling on fertility should be done for both.

Surgical treatment: Transgender men can undergo 'bottom surgeries' like metoidioplasty, scrotoplasty, or phalloplasty and 'top surgery' for a male contoured chest. Trans women can go for breast augmentation (top surgery) and vaginoplasty (bottom surgery), commonly known as Sex Reassignment Surgery.

questions.text: A carpenter sustained a hit to his thumb by a hammer while working. Following this, he developed a poorly localised dull aching pain.  What is the type of nerve fibre carrying this pain?
questions.solution:
The poorly localised dull aching pain experienced after a hit by a heavy object like a hammer is carried by C fibres.

C-dorsal root fibres are unmyelinated fibres found mainly in the deep somatic structures such as the muscles and joints. They are activated by thermal, mechanical or chemical stimuli that result in poor localization and slow, dull pain. The conducting rate of these fibres is 0.5 to 2 m/s.

Another type of nerve fibre responsible for pain sensation is Aδ fibres. They are myelinated fibres responsible for first pain also called fast pain (conduction velocity 6 to 30 m/s). These fibres get activated under thermal or mechanical stimuli and cause a short-lasting pricking type of pain that can be localized. They are mainly found in superficial structures such as the skin.

Other Options:

Option A: Aα fibre conducts proprioception and somatic motor at a rate of 70–120m/s.

Option B: Aβ fibre conducts touch and pressure at a rate of 30-70 m/s.

Option C: B fibres are preganglionic autonomic fibres conducting at the rate of 3–15m/s.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with a well-circumscribed, soft mass in the upper outer quadrant of the breast. On examination, the axillary lymph nodes are enlarged. Her paternal aunt and sister also had a history of breast carcinoma in the same age group. Molecular examination revealed the tumor to be triple-negative. Biopsy shows the following image. What is the most likely diagnosis in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and histopathological findings are suggestive of medullary carcinoma of the breast which is associated with intense lymphocyte proliferation. The histopathology shows sheets of highly pleomorphic cells with mitotic figures, lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate, and pushing border.

Medullary carcinoma is a less common type of breast carcinoma and is a common type seen in BRCA1 mutation. The majority of the tumors are triple-negative. It is softer than other carcinomas due to minimal desmoplasia. The tumor can enlarge rapidly due to necrosis and hemorrhage.

ER-negative and HER2-negative (triple-negative or “basal-like”) carcinomas can be characterized by genomic instability (denoted by multiple chromosomal changes), a high proliferative rate, and expression of many proteins typical of myoepithelial cells (like basal keratins).

Histopathology consists of:

  • A dense lymphoreticular infiltration composed predominantly of lymphocytes and plasma cells
  • A sheet-like growth pattern of anaplastic cells with absent ductal or lobular differentiation
  • Solid, syncytium-like sheets of large cells with pleomorphic nuclei, and prominent nucleoli, which compose more than 75% of the tumor mass
  • Frequent mitotic figures
  • A pushing (non infiltrative) border

Therefore, the lymph node enlargement can be due to reactive hyperplasia rather than the spread of the cancer cells to the lymph nodes. 

It has a better survival rate than invasive ductal or invasive lobular carcinoma.

Other options:

Option B: Papillary carcinoma consists of true papillae with a leaf-like arrangement of fibrovascular tissue, lined by the tumor cells.

 

Option C: Lobular carcinoma of the breast : The histopathological image shows discohesive infiltrating tumor cells, signet-ring cells containing intracytoplasmic mucin droplets. Tubule formation is absent in this subtype. Single line of cells are seen lining the normal duct (bottom right of the image) which is the characteristic Indian file/ Single file appearance.

Lobular Carcinoma:

  • Usually bilateral
  • Multicentric and presents as hard irregular masses
  • It can have a diffuse infiltrative pattern with minimal desmoplasia
  • It is the most common type of breast carcinoma to present as an occult primary
  • Pathogenesis: Mutation in CDH-1 gene which encodes for cadherin. Loss of E-cadherin leads to small, monomorphic discohesive cells arranged one after another. This arrangement is called an Indian file/ Single file appearance.
  • Desmoplasia is minimal or absent
  • They are Luminal-A type
  • Excellent prognosis

Note: Mutation in CDH-1 also pose a high risk for gastric signet ring cell carcinoma. 

 

Option D: Colloidal carcinoma is an invasive breast carcinoma, which shows intra and extracellular mucin deposition. Extracellular type shows tumor cells with faint nuclei arranged in clusters floating in pools/lakes of mucin on histopathological examination. In intracellular type, nuclei are pushed to the peripherally to form signet ring appearance.

Almost all breast malignancies are adenocarcinomas and based on the expression of estrogen receptor and HER2 can be divided into three major biologic subgroups:

  • ER-positive HER2-negative tumors (50% to 65% of tumors) – range from well-differentiated cancers with low proliferative rates and few chromosomal changes to poorly differentiated cancers with high proliferative rates and large numbers of chromosomal rearrangements. All of these cancers express ER.
  • HER2-positive cancers - 10% to 20% of tumors, which may either be ER-positive or ER-negative.
  • ER-negative, HER2-negative carcinomas (triple-negative or basal-like)- are characterized by genomic instability, a high proliferative rate, and expression of many proteins typical of myoepithelial cells (e.g., basal keratins).

questions.text: You are a medical officer evaluating the community health meal programs in your area. One of the program's objectives is to attract more children to maintain attendance in school. Which one of the following statements about this meal program is correct?

choices.text: Provides 1/3rd of daily energy requirement and 1/2 of daily protein requirement
It should be a substitute to the home diet
The menu should not be changed to maintain consistency
The meal should not be prepared in schools

questions.solution:
It provides 1/3rd of daily energy requirement and 1/2 of daily protein requirement is the correct statement about the mid-day meal program

The mid-day meal program (MDMP)/ school lunch program is catered to provide meals for school children. It is offered to school children in an effort to persuade more children to enroll in schools thereby improving children's literacy. It aims to maintain attendance in schools. Currently, it functions under the broad coverage of the minimum needs program. It is run by the ministry of education.

The meal provided under the MDMP should only be a supplement and not a substitute for home diets. It must cover at least 1/2 of the total daily protein requirement and 1/3rd of the total daily energy requirement for children in schools. The cost of meals should be reasonably low. The meal should be easy to cook in schools. Locally available foods must be used whenever possible. The menu should be regularly changed to avoid monotony.

The mid-day meal scheme functions under the ministry of human resources development as a centrally sponsored scheme. Under this, a cooked mid-day meal with at least 300 calories and 8-12 grams of protein is provided to all children of classes I-V.

questions.text:
Match the following morphology of vegetations with the conditions in which they are found.
  1. Rheumatic heart disease (RHD)
  2. Infective endocarditis (IE)
  3. Nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis
  4. Libman-Sacks endocarditis
questions.solution:
The rightly matched vegetations with the conditions that they are seen are as follows: 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B

Rheumatic heart disease often presents with rheumatic fever phase where small, warty 1- 2 mm vegetations, also called veruccae, extend along the lines of closure of the valve leaflets. The cardinal anatomical changes of the mitral valve in chronic RHD are:

  • Leaflet thickening
  • Commissural fusion and shortening
  • Thickening and fusion of the tendinous chords

Infective endocarditis has large, irregular, friable masses on the valve cusps that can extend onto the chordae. These vegetations can be single or multiple and may involve one or more valves. They are potentially destructive lesions and contain fibrin, inflammatory cells, bacteria or other organisms. They can erode into the underlying myocardium and produce a ring abscess. They are prone to embolisations, resulting in abscess formation wherever they lodge due to the presence of virulent organisms. Thus, it may lead to sequelae like septic infarcts or mycotic aneurysms.

Subacute infective endocarditis contains less destructive vegetations. They contain granulation tissue at their bases indicative of healing. Fibrosis, calcification and a chronic inflammatory infiltrate can develop over the time.

Nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis is characterised by one or more small, 1-5 mm, sterile vegetations which are usually attached at the line of closure. They are seen associated with hypercoagulable states like chronic DIC or malignancy. They are loosely attached to the underlying valve and are non-destructive in nature. They do not cause any inflammatory reaction but they can be a source of systemic embolisation.

Libman-Sack's endocarditis has small- or medium-sized, 1- 4 mm, sterile vegetations associated with systemic lupus erythematosus. They may be present on one or both the sides of the leaflets, on the valve surface, chordae or anywhere on the endocardium. These vegetations develop due to immune complex deposition and complement activation. They cause intense valvulitis resulting in fibrinoid necrosis of the valve substance. Persistent injury to the valves can result in scarring and leaflet fusion.

questions.text:
A patient of a road traffic accident needs blood transfusion. The doctor administers the blood brought by the nurse without verifying the blood group. The patient dies of transfusion reaction due to blood group incompatibility. The punishment for this act is described under which section of the BNS (IPC)?

BNS- Bharatiya Nayaya Sanhita; IPC - Indian Penal Code
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the doctor fails to verify the blood group of the blood to be administered. This amounts to causing death by rash or negligent act which is defined under BNS Sec 106 (304A IPC). This act can lead to a punishment of imprisonment of up to 2 years and a fine.
