questions.text: A 50-year-old woman was diagnosed with Hashimoto's thyroiditis and was started on levothyroxine 2 weeks ago. She now presents to your clinic with abdominal pain and dizziness. The left and right images below show her current appearance and her appearance last month, respectively. Which of the following is not a feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given image showing skin hyperpigmentation in a patient with severe dizziness and a history of autoimmune thyroiditis points to a diagnosis of Addison’s disease. Hyperglycemia is not a feature of this condition. Hypocortisolism leads to hypoglycemia in these patients.

Addison’s disease is primary adrenal insufficiency characterized by the disruption of glucocorticoid, mineralocorticoid, and androgen secretion. Primary adrenal insufficiency is most commonly caused by autoimmune adrenalitis and coincident autoimmune disease occurring in these patients most frequently includes thyroid autoimmune disease, vitiligo, and premature ovarian failure.

Clinical features of Addison’s disease:

Hormone

Clinical features
Hypoaldosteronism

Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, salt craving
Dizziness, postural hypotension
AKI due to volume depletion
Hyponatremia
Hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis
Hypocortisolism Anorexia, weight loss, fatigue, myalgia, arthralgia
Fever (increased IL-1)
Depression
Postural hypotension
Hypoglycemia
Hyponatremia (loss of feedback inhibition of ADH)
Slightly increased TSH (loss of feedback inhibition)
Hypoandrogenism Loss of libido
  Loss of pubic and axillary hair
Elevated ACTH Hyperpigmentation

Levothyroxine can precipitate adrenal insufficiency or crisis in undiagnosed patients. In patients with concurrent adrenal insufficiency and hypothyroidism, a course of steroids must be given before giving thyroid replacement.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old girl presented with cyanosis that did not improve with oxygen administration. On further probing, she revealed that she has been using large amounts of a 'numbing cream' called EMLA. What will be the appropriate management for this patient?

EMLA: Eutectic mixture of local anesthetics
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette depicts a scenario of cyanosis due to methemoglobinemia induced by the application of a large amount of EMLA cream. The most appropriate management, in this case, would be the administration of IV methylene blue.

EMLA is a eutectic mixture of local anesthetics containing a mixture of 2.5% lidocaine and 2.5% prilocaine. Methemoglobinemia is a serious side effect of the application of large amounts of prilocaine. Prilocaine is metabolized to O-toluidine, which converts hemoglobin (Fe2+) to methemoglobin (Fe3+) producing methemoglobinemia. This side effect is dose-dependent. 

Pulse oximetry in methemoglobinemia falsely shows 80-85% irrespective of higher arterial oxygen saturation. 

Treatment of methemoglobinemia includes reduction of methemoglobin to hemoglobin by intravenous methylene blue (1–2 mg/kg of a 1% solution over 5 min).

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with a history of lymph node enlargement in his neck and axillae for the past 3 weeks. Investigations revealed mild anemia, with a leukocytosis of 40,000/mm3. The peripheral blood smear is shown in the image below. What is the origin of the malignant cell?

choices.text: Naive B cells in Interfollicular zones

questions.solution:
The clinical features and peripheral smear are suggestive of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL). In CLL, B cells originate from naive B cell or Pre/Post Germinal Centre memory B cell. CLL arises in the lymph node.

Chronic Lymphocytic Leukaemia (CLL)/ Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma (SLL):

The CLL and SLL differ only in the degree of peripheral blood lymphocytes. CLL is the most common leukemia of adults in the western world. The median age of diagnosis is 60 years. The most common genetic anomalies seen are deletions of 13q14.3, 11q, and 17p and trisomy 12q. Loss of tumor suppressor genes in chromosome 13 results in overexpression of the anti-apoptotic protein BCL2.

The growth of CLL/SLL cells is confined to the proliferation centers (pathognomonic for CLL/SLL), where the tumor cells receive critical factors from the surrounding environments, such as NF-κB for cell survival, MYC for cell growth, Bruton Tyrosine Kinase (BTK) signaling pathway, etc.,

The tumor cells express CD19, CD20, CD23, and CD5. Smudge cells are also characteristic of CLL. Clinical features include easy fatiguability, weight loss, anorexia, generalized lymphadenopathy, hepatomegaly, hemolytic anemia, etc. CLL/SLL has a tendency to transform to a more aggressive diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL)  - this is called Richter syndrome.

The peripheral smear in CLL shows, small round lymphocytes (indicated by arrow) with condensed chromatin, and scant cytoplasm. Some of these cells may get disrupted while preparing the smears, producing so-called smudge cells (indicated by arrowhead).

Factors with a bad prognosis include:

  1. Presence of deletions of 11q and 17p.
  2. Lack of somatic hypermutation.
  3. Expression of ZAP-70 augmenting signals produced by the Ig receptor.
  4. Presence of NOTCH1 mutations.

BTK inhibitors and BCL2 inhibitors are highly active targeted therapy for CLL/SLL.

Other options:

Option A - Centrocytes are the origin of malignancy in follicular lymphoma.
Option B - Diffuse large B cell lymphoma can arise from nodal as well as extranodal mature B cells.
Option D - Bone marrow progenitors are the origin of CML and AML.

questions.text: The given chemical structure is of
questions.solution:
The given chemical structure is of keratan sulfate. 

Keratan sulfate is a mucopolysaccharide that does not contain uronic acid. It is constituted by repeating disaccharide units of N-acetyl glucosamine and galactose.

Keratan sulfate is present between the collagen fibrils in the cornea and plays a major role in corneal transparency.

 2 types of keratan sulfate are seen:

  • Keratan sulfate I is present in the cornea.
  • Keratan sulfate II is mainly present in the cartilage.

Keratin sulfate I and II differ in their linkage to the core proteins. Keratan sulfate I links to a core protein L-asparagine via N-acetylglucosamine and Keratan sulfate II to  L-Serine (or L-Threonine) via N-acetyl galactosamine.

Other options:

Option B: In chondroitin sulfate, the repeating disaccharide units are glucuronic acid and N-acetyl galactosamine. 

Option C: In heparin, each repeating disaccharide contains glucosamine and either d-glucuronic or L-iduronic acid.

Option D: In dermatan sulfate, the repeating disaccharide units are L-iduronic acid and N-acetyl galactosamine.

questions.text: A physician uses the following instrument to measure temperature in one of his patients and he wants to disinfect it before using it on another patient. It can be best disinfected by _______
questions.solution:
The given instrument is a clinical thermometer, and it is best disinfected using Savlon.

Savlon is a quaternary ammonia compound (QAC) that contains Cetavlon (cetrimide) and Hibitane (chlorhexidine). Plastic items can be disinfected by keeping them in normal strength Savlon for 20 minutes. Clinical thermometers can be disinfected in savlon in just under 3 minutes.

Other options: 

Option A - Cresol is a coal-tar disinfectant that is best used in 5-10% strength for disinfection of feces and urine.

Option B - Chloroxylenol (Dettol) is an antiseptic that is active against streptococci. A 5% solution is suitable for disinfection of instruments and plastic equipment, with minimum contact of 15 minutes required for disinfection.

Option D - Lysol is a "saponified cresol" where cresol is emulsified with soap. It contains 50- 60 percent cresol and is a powerful disinfectant. A 2 percent solution of Lysol may be used for the disinfection of feces.

questions.text: A 57-year-old male patient presented with anasarca, nephrotic range proteinuria and mild hepatomegaly. Suspecting amyloidosis, a renal biopsy was taken, which seen under polarised light shows the following appearance. What is the most likely stain used here?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of renal amyloidosis in which the biopsy specimen shows apple-green birefringence under polarized light with congo-red staining.

Amyloidosis is a condition caused due to the deposition of abnormal fibrillar proteins in extracellular spaces. Abnormal fibrils are produced by the aggregation of misfolded proteins. The fibrillar deposits bind a wide variety of proteoglycans and glycosaminoglycans, including heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate, and plasma proteins, notably serum amyloid P component (SAP). Amyloid appears as an amorphous, eosinophilic, hyaline, extracellular substance.

Based on the involvement of organ systems it may be classified as systemic or localized. Hereditary amyloidosis is a separate group of heterogeneous disorders with many distinctive patterns of organ involvement. 

Microscopically, all types of amyloid deposits are made up of continuous, nonbranching fibrils. A characteristic cross-β-pleated sheet conformation is visualized on X-ray crystallography and infrared spectroscopy. 

On light microscopy (with hematoxylin and eosin stain): Amyloid appears as an amorphous, eosinophilic, hyaline substance in extracellular space.

Congo red stain, which is used to observe amyloid deposits is shown in the image below: 

  1. Under ordinary light, it imparts a pink or red color to amorphous extracellular material, as seen by the focal positive staining.
  2. Under the polarizing microscope, it imparts apple-green birefringence to amyloid deposits.
 The next best step is to determine the type of precursor protein by immunohistochemistry, immunoelectron microscopy, or extraction and biochemical analysis employing mass spectrometry.

Other options: 

Perl's Prussian blue stain is used in Hemochromatosis to stain liver tissue which shows hepatocellular iron, which is stained blue with this stain.


Amyloid deposits and Paget cells observed in Paget disease are stained by Alcian blue. 


The given slide shows the GI mucosa, which has been stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain, demonstrating the bacilli Helicobacter pylori.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is alirocumab approved for use?

choices.text: Cystic fibrosis patients >12 years of age

questions.solution:
Alirocumab is a PCSK9 inhibitor that is approved for use in familial hypercholesterolemia.

PCSK9 inhibitors are a new class of lipid-lowering medications that are administered as monthly or bimonthly subcutaneous injections. PCSK9 is a binding protein that is expressed in hepatocytes and on secretion, binds to the LDL receptors, and promotes their degradation. By blocking PCSK9, these drugs increase the availability of LDL receptors leading to better removal of LDL cholesterol from circulation. Another approved PCSK-9 inhibitor is evolocumab.

Other options: 

Option B: Fremanezumab and galcanezumab are anti-CGRP monoclonal antibodies approved by the FDA in 2018 for the preventive treatment of migraine in adults.

Option C: Tezacaftor/Ivacaftor is FDA approved for cystic fibrosis patients >12 years of age. It facilitates the opening of chloride channels.

Option D: Plecanatide is FDA-approved for the treatment of chronic idiopathic constipation. It activates guanylate cyclase-C on endothelial cells in the GI tract and thus draws water into the lumen, leading to stool softening.

questions.text: You are an intern posted in anesthesia. Your senior resident is performing a procedure which lasts less than 20 minutes. She asks you to load an intermediate-acting non-depolarising neuromuscular blocker. Which of the following agents will you prefer for the procedure?
questions.solution:
Vecuronium is an intermediate-acting, non-depolarising neuromuscular blocker. Thus, the first sign of recovery after vecuronium administration would be seen about 20-50 minutes from administering this agent.

Vecuronium is an N-demethylated derivative of pancuronium. The molecular modification results in the following:

  • Increased potency 
  • Reduced vagolytic properties and devoid of significant cardiovascular effects. It is the most cardiostable muscle relaxant, making it the muscle relaxant of choice in cardiac patients.
  • Molecular instability when in solution
  • Increased lipid solubility, leading to greater biliary elimination 

Sugammadex can be used to reverse the neuromuscular blockade action of vecuronium like rocuronium.

Other options:

Option B: Succinylcholine is a depolarising neuromuscular blocker.

Options C & D: Pancuronium is a long-acting agent (>50 mins) and Gantacurium is an ultra-short-acting agent (<10 mins).

Related Pearl: Types of muscle relaxants

There are 2 types of muscle relaxants: depolarizing and non-depolarizing.

Depolarizing Muscle Relaxant- Succinylcholine

Non-Depolarizing Muscle Relaxants:

  • Ultra short-acting (<10 minutes) - Gantacurium
  • Short-acting (10-20 minutes) - Mivacurium
  • Intermediate-acting (20-50 minutes)
    • Atracurium
    • Cisatracurium
    • Vecuronium
    • Rocuronium
  • Long-acting (>50 minutes)
    • Pancuronium
    • Doxacurium
    • Pipecuronium

Related Pearl: High yield in muscle relaxants

  • Shortest acting non-depolarizing muscle relaxant:
    • Gantacurium (Not FDA approved)
    • Mivacurium: 12-20 minutes. (FDA approved)
  • Shortest acting depolarizing muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine (3-6 minutes)
  • Muscle relaxant having the maximum duration of action: Doxacurium (benzylisoquinoline) > Pancuronium (Aminosteroid)
  • Muscle relaxant causing pain on IV injection site: Rocuronium
  • Muscle relaxant which crosses placenta: Gallamine
  • Muscle relaxant acting directly on muscle: Dantrolene
  • Muscle relaxants with central action: benzodiazepine, mephenesin, baclofen, carisoprodol, metaxalone
  • Muscle relaxant and mode of clearance:
    • Hepatic clearance: Pancuronium, rapacuronium and vecuronium
    • Biliary clearance: Vecuronium and rocuronium
    • Renal clearance: Doxacurium, pancuronium, vecuronium, and pipecuronium
  • Muscle relaxant with sympathetic stimulation:
    • Gallamine
    • Pancuronium
  • Muscle relaxant with vagolytic activity:
    • Gallamine
    • Pancuronium

questions.text: A 25-year-old man exercises at a high altitude. Which of the following changes would occur in him?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, there will be a rise in urinary bicarbonate levels if a person is observed exercising at a high altitude.

Adaptation at High Altitudes:

  • The work capacity is reduced at high altitudes and this reduction is in direct proportion to the decrease in O2 uptake.
  • Immediate exposure to low PO2 at higher altitudes stimulates the arterial chemoreceptors, and this stimulation increases alveolar ventilation.
  • This immediate increase in pulmonary ventilation upon rising to a high altitude blows off large quantities of CO2, reducing the PCO2 and increasing the pH of the body fluids causing respiratory alkalosis (not metabolic - option A). This raised pH inhibits the brainstem respiratory center and opposes the increased ventilation. So, respiratory alkalosis will hinder maximal exercise effort.
  • To compensate for this respiratory alkalosis, kidneys reduce hydrogen ion secretion and increase bicarbonate excretion. This reduces plasma and cerebrospinal fluid bicarbonate concentration and brings the pH toward normal. It removes the inhibitory effect of alkalosis on respiration. Hence fall in blood bicarbonate facilitates the exercise effort.
  • Lactic acid levels increase which causes extreme fatigue. When there is insufficient oxygen (at high altitudes), most of the pyruvic acid is converted into lactic acid, which diffuses out of the muscle cells into the interstitial fluid and blood.

Related Pearl: Acclimatization to high altitude

questions.text: The given system of classification for carcinoma of the maxillary sinus depicts which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ledermann’s classification is used to classify maxillary carcinoma in this case.

It uses two horizontal lines of Sebileau; one passing through the floors of orbits and the other through floors of antra dividing the area into 

  • Suprastructure - ethmoid, sphenoid, frontal sinuses, and olfactory area of the nose 
  • Mesostructure - maxillary and respiratory part of the nose 
  • Infrastructure - alveolar process

 

Other options:

Option A: Ohngren’s classification - An imaginary plane is drawn, extending between the medial canthus of the eye and the angle of the mandible.

Ohngren's line (below image):

Growths situated above this plane (suprastructural) have a poorer prognosis than those below it (infrastructural).

Option C: AJCC (American Joint Committee on Cancer) is only for squamous cell carcinoma. It is classified based on the extent of differentiation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old HIV patient who presented with dry, non-productive cough and dyspnea is diagnosed to have Pneumocystis jirovecii infection. Which of the following statements is false about this organism?

choices.text: Cyst wall stains black with methenamine silver stain
It grows readily on Sabouraud agar
Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is used for prophylaxis in HIV patients

questions.solution:
Among the following statements, the false statement is that "Pneumocystis jirovecii grows readily on Sabouraud agar".

P. jirovecii is an extracellular pathogen that primarily resides in the lung's surfactant layer, impairing oxygen exchange and leading to symptoms like cyanosis. Diagnosis involves examining specimens from bronchoalveolar lavage, lung biopsies, or induced sputum for trophozoites and cysts using specialized stains and fluorescent microscopy. Culture methods are ineffective for diagnosis, and serological tests mainly determine infection prevalence rather than aiding clinical diagnosis. Detection of a specific surface glycoprotein in serum is indicative of acute infection.

P. jirovecii has three morphological forms:

  • Trophozoite - thin-walled, irregularly shaped
  • Precyst - an intermediate stage of the sexual phase
  • Cyst - thick-walled, spherical in shape. It contains intracystic bodies

Trophozoites can be demonstrated by Giemsa, toluidine blue, methenamine silver, and calcofluor white stains. The cyst wall stains black with methenamine silver stain.

P. jirovecii causes pneumonia primarily in immunocompromised patients. It is commonly found in animals like rats and mice without causing disease unless the host's immune system is weakened. In humans, it historically affected malnourished infants and those undergoing immunosuppressive therapies, becoming a major cause of mortality in AIDS patients before effective preventive treatments. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMZ) and pentamidine isothionate are the drugs of choice for the treatment of acute cases. TMP-SMZ is also used for prophylaxis in HIV patients.

The silver stain of P. jirovecii cysts in tissue is given below.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

Related Pearl: Opportunistic Infections/HIV related conditions and ART initiation

Clinical scenario Action 
Any undiagnosed active infection with fever Diagnose and treat first; start Anti-Retroviral Therapy (ART) when stable
Tuberculosis (TB) Start TB treatment first; start ART as soon as possible after 2 weeks and before 2 months. For those with CD4 less than 50/cmm, start ART within 2 weeks Caution is needed for PLHIV with TB meningitis, since immediate ART is associated with more severe adverse events than initiating ART 2 months after the start of TB treatment

Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP)

 Treat PCP first; start ART when PCP treatment is completed
Invasive fungal diseases: Oesophageal candidiasis, penicilliosis, histoplasmosis Start treatment for oesophageal candidiasis first; start ART as soon as the patient can swallow comfortably. Treat penicilliosis, and histoplasmosis first; start ART when the patient is stabilized or opportunistic infection treatment is completed.
Cryptococcal meningitis Treat cryptococcal meningitis. ART initiation should be deferred until there is evidence of sustained clinical response to anti-fungal therapy and after 4 weeks of induction and consolidation treatment with amphotericin B containing regimen.
Bacterial pneumonia Treat pneumonia first; start ART when treatment is completed
Malaria Treat malaria first; start ART when treatment is completed
Acute diarrhoea which may reduce absorption of ART Diagnose the cause and treat diarrhoea first; start ART when diarrhoea is stabilized or controlled
Non-severe anaemia (Hb< 9 g/dl) Start ART if no other causes for anaemia are found (HIV is often the cause of anaemia) 
Skin conditions such as PPE and seborrhoeic dermatitis, psoriasis, HIV-related exfoliative dermatitis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems) 
Suspected Mycobacterium Avium Complex (MAC), Cryptosporidiosis and Microsporidiosis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems)
Cytomegalovirus retinitis Start treatment for CMV urgently and start ART after 2 weeks of CMV treatment 
Toxoplasmosis Treat toxoplasmosis; start ART after 6 weeks of treatment and when the patient is stabilized

questions.text:
A medical officer working at a PHC refers complicated cases to a secondary or tertiary hospital. This way of development of referral services was established by which committee?

PHC: Primary health center
questions.solution:
The development of referral services from the PHC to the secondary or tertiary hospitals was established by the Shrivastav committee. 

The Shrivastav committee was started by the ministry of health and family planning. Its goals were to provide training to health assistants that can be the link between the medical practitioners and multipurpose workers to form an effective health care team. It also suggested steps to improve the medical educational process based on the national requirements. 

The committee recommended that at least one male and female health care worker should be available for every 5000 population. For every two male and two female health care workers, one male and one female health assistant should be available at the sub-centre level.

As part of this committee, bands of para-professional and semi-professional health workers were formed. These individuals were part of the community already as postmasters and school teachers. They were trained to provide simple preventive and curative services to the community.  

Other options: 

Option A: The Chadah committee outlined the responsibility of block-level PHCs in the national malaria eradication program. They recommended one basic health worker for every 10,000 population. 

Option C: The Jungalwalla committee recommended the integration of health services from the highest to the lowest level and the elimination of private practice by government doctors. 

Option D: The Mudaliar committee recommended that district hospitals be strengthened by adding specialist services. They also added regional deputy and assistant directors to supervise district medical and health officers. They limited the population served by each primary health centre to 40,000.

questions.text: In the below-given project, which pathway if delayed causes a delay in the entire project?

choices.text: Start-->task A--> task D--> task E--> Finish
Start--> task B--> task C--> Finish

questions.solution:
Here the longest pathway is option C as it consists of (5+6)11 days, and so is the critical path.

The critical path is the longest path in the network analysis. Any delay in the critical path will delay the entire project. The critical path method is a type of network technique. 

The other common type of network technique is the program evaluation and review technique. An arrow diagram that depicts the logical sequence of events that must take place is constructed. The time duration that can be allotted to each activity is easily calculated. This helps to minimize any delays in the implementation of the plan.

Other options:

Option A: It is only 2 days, so it cannot be the critical pathway.

Option B: It adds up to 10 days and therefore is not the critical pathway.

Option D: Although task D is the longest activity, it is not the longest pathway.

Related Pearl: Network Analysis in Health Management

A network is a graphic plan of all events and activities to be completed in order to reach an end objective.

Two types of network analysis: PERT and CPM

1. Programme Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT)

  • An arrow diagram of all events in logical sequence is drawn.
  • Time to finish each activity can be calculated and critical activities can be identified.
  • It aids in planning, scheduling and monitoring of the project.

2. Critical Path Method (CPM)

  • The longest path of the network is called the critical path.
  • A delay in the critical path will cause a delay in the entire project.

questions.text: A young, female patient who recently underwent abdominal surgery presented to the OPD with the finding as shown in the image below. Which of the following statements is incorrect about her condition?

choices.text: It extends beyond the boundary of the original incision
It is associated with elevated growth factor
It occurs in people with light pigmentation of skin
They most commonly occur in the sternal area

questions.solution:
The given history of abdominal surgery and the image is suggestive of keloid and the incorrect statement about keloid is it occurs in people with light pigmentation of the skin. Keloids have increased incidence in individuals with darker pigmentation.

A keloid is defined as excessive scar tissue that occurs after traumatic mechanisms like cuts, lacerations, or burns. They extend beyond the boundaries of the inciting injury. The keloid is glossy in appearance and rubbery in texture. They are composed of thick bundles of collagen. 

Treatment of keloids usually involves intralesional injections of triamcinolone. Multiple doses are required at intervals over several weeks and may result in flattening but rarely does the wound narrow. 

Other options: 

Option A - Keloids extend beyond the boundary of the original incision due to the chronic inflammation that occurs during the wound-healing phase. 

Option B - Keloids are associated with elevated growth factors. Histologically, keloids appear as nodular myofibroblasts and whorl-like arrangement of thick hyalinized collagen. 

Option D - Keloids most commonly occur in the sternal area in the triangle formed by the tips of the shoulders and the xiphisternum. The other areas involved are the neck, ears, extremities, and trunk.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman presented with complaints of pelvic and abdominal pain, and significant weight loss. A CT scan of the pelvis showed bilateral ovarian tumors and a CT scan of the chest showed pleural effusion. Pleural fluid analysis showed positive cytology for ovarian tumor cells. What FIGO stage does this belong to?
questions.solution:
According to the FIGO staging of carcinoma of the ovary, fallopian tube, and primary peritoneal carcinoma, the presence of pleural effusion with positive cytology is classified as stage IV-A.

Other options:

Option A: Stage III-A1 is defined as a tumor involving one or both ovaries with positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes only.

Option B: Stage III-B is defined as a tumor involving one or both ovaries with macroscopic, extrapelvic, and peritoneal metastasis ≤2cm ± positive retroperitoneal nodes with extension to the capsule of the liver or spleen.

Option D: Stage IV-B is defined as hepatic and/or splenic parenchymal metastasis, metastasis to extra-abdominal organs including inguinal lymph nodes and lymph nodes outside of the abdominal cavity.

Related Pearl: Staging of Ovarian cancer

    • B: Bilateral ovary

      • C2: pre-operative capsule rupture
      • C3: malignant ascites
  • Stage II:
    • A: Extension to fallopian tubes/ uterus.
    • B: Extension to other pelvic intraperitoneal tissues
  • Stage III:
    • A1:Positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes(para-aortic)
    • A2:microscopic extrapelvic peritoneal deposits
    • B: Macroscopic peritoneal deposits <2cm ± positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes. Includes extension to capsule of liver/spleen.  
    • C: Macroscopic peritoneal deposits >2cm ± positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes. Includes extension to capsule of liver/spleen.
  • Stage 4:
    • A: Malignant pleural effusion
    • B: Extra-abdominal spread/Inguinal lymph node involvement

questions.text: A 26-year-old male patient presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of intermittent rectal bleeding, tenesmus, and mucous discharge. He passes 4-5 stools a day. Laboratory reports show that erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein are elevated. He has no history of fever. He is diagnosed with ulcerative colitis. Which of the following features is consistent with his disease?
questions.solution:
The presence of crypt abscesses is consistent with ulcerative colitis.

Ulcerative colitis often has to be differentiated from Crohn's disease. Both are inflammatory bowel diseases. Ulcerative colitis is characterized by the involvement of the rectum and colon. Patients usually present with rectal bleeding, tenesmus, and mucous discharge per rectum. Generally, in most cases, the condition is confined to the rectal area but may spread proximally. 

Ulcerative colitis is graded based on the frequency of bowel movements and systemic involvement. 

  • Mild disease - < 4 stools per day without rectal bleeding
  • Moderate disease - > 4 stools per day with few systemic signs of illness; inflammatory markers are elevated
  • Severe disease - > 6 blood stools per day with fever, tachycardia, anemia, and inflammatory markers
  • Fulminant disease - > 10 stools per day with severe anemia requiring blood transfusion and progressive colonic dilation (toxic megacolon)

Stricture Rare Common
Microscopic    
Layers involved Mucosa/Submucosa Full-thickness
Granulomas No Common

Other options: 

Perianal disease manifestations (Option B), fistula formation (Option C), and the presence of granulomas (Option D) are seen in Crohn's Disease.

Erythema nodosum

Pyoderma gangrenosum- MC in UC

Primary sclerosing cholangitis- MC in UC

Renal Calculi- MC in CD

questions.text: Endolymphatic sac surgery is performed on a patient who has Ménière disease with intractable vertigo. Which of the following is the surgical landmark to identify the sac?
questions.solution:
Donaldson’s line is the surgical landmark to locate the endolymphatic sac.

It is an imaginary line drawn from the horizontal semicircular canal, which bisects the posterior semicircular canal. The endolymphatic sac lies just below it. 

Image showing Donaldson’s line:

ELS: Endolymphatic sac; HSCC: Horizontal semicircular canal, PSCC: Posterior semicircular canal; PF dura: Posterior fossa dura.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old male patient presented with short trunk dwarfism. Findings of ocular examination are shown in the given image. The child was assessed and was found to be of normal intelligence, and a provisional diagnosis of MPS IV was made. Which of the following is least likely to be seen in this child?

MPS IV - Mucopolysaccharidosis IV
questions.solution:
The given image shows corneal clouding, which is a feature seen in mucopolysaccharidosis (MPS) IV. Impaired hearing is not seen in MPS IV. 

MPS-IV, also known as Morquio disease, is caused by a deficiency of N-acetylgalactosamine-6-sulfatase (MPS-IVA) or of β-galactosidase (MPS IVB). Deficiency of either of these enzymes results in defective degradation of keratan sulfate. MPS-IVA is usually more severe than MPS-IVB, with the adult height being <125 cm in MPS-IVA and >150 cm in MPS-IVB.

MPS IV is characterized by short trunk dwarfism and normal intelligence. 

Early symptoms of MPS-IV:

  • Genu valgus
  • Kyphosis
  • Growth retardation with short trunk and neck
  • Waddling gait
  • Tendency to fall.

Impaired hearing is seen in all MPS except MPS IV. Visceromegaly and leukocyte inclusions are characteristically absent in MPS-IV.

Extra-skeletal manifestations include corneal clouding, small teeth with abnormally thin enamel, frequent caries formation, and occasionally cardiac valvular lesions. Life-threatening atlantoaxial instability due to instability of the odontoid process and ligamentous laxity are characteristic.

Management is by enzyme replacement therapy. A recombinant human GALNS enzyme replacement therapy elosulfase alfa is approved for the treatment of MPS IVA. Treatment has been shown to improve ambulatory mobility and decrease pain, but no effect on growth or skeletal dysplasia. There is no current specific treatment for MPS IVB.

Corneal clouding is absent in Hunter (MPS-II) and Sanfilippo (MPS-III) syndromes.

Note: As a general rule, the impaired degradation of heparan sulfate is more closely associated with mental deficiency and deficiency of dermatan, chondroitin, and keratan sulfate with mesenchymal abnormalities.

questions.text: A patient developed the following lesions after 10 days of initiation of chemotherapy. The patient also complains of similar lesions over soles and they are sensitive to touch. Which is the most likely agent to cause this adverse effect?
questions.solution:
The given image depicts classical findings of hand-foot syndrome and capecitabine is commonly associated with this prominent side effect.

Hand foot syndrome or palmar-plantar erythrodysesthesia consists of erythema, desquamation, pain and sensitivity to touch of the palms and soles. 

Drugs commonly implicated are:

  • Capecitabine
  • 5-Fluorouracil
  • Cytarabine
  • Pemetrexed
  • Doxorubicin

questions.text:
A young adult male presented with chronic fatigue and gallstones. His father had a similar illness for which splenectomy was done. Investigations were done and shown below. Which of the following protein defects is not seen in this condition?

Hemoglobin- decreased
Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration- increased
Mean corpuscular volume - decreased
Red cell distribution width - increased
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, lab investigations and peripheral smear showing numerous spherocytes are suggestive of Hereditary spherocytosis (HS). Laminin is not involved in the pathogenesis of hereditary spherocytosis. 

Laminins form part of the basement membrane which binds to both hemidesmosomes and anchoring filaments. Mutations in laminin and laminin alpha 2 (merosin) result in the blistering phenotype of junctional epidermolysis bullosa (JEB) and congenital muscular dystrophy (CMD) respectively.  

Hereditary spherocytosis is a type of hemolytic anaemia that is most commonly inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. Mutations in α-spectrin, β-spectrin, ankyrin, band 4.2, and band 3 weaken the association of the membrane skeleton with the overlying plasma membrane, making them spheroid and less deformable. This causes red cells to shed membrane vesicles and transform into spherocytes. The non-deformable spherocytes get trapped in the splenic cords and phagocytosed by macrophages.

The ankyrin gene mutation is the most likely genetic mutation seen in autosomal-dominant hereditary spherocytosis. Mutations in the spectrin gene result in the most severe form of HS.

 

Patients usually present with anemia, fatigue, splenomegaly, and jaundice and the age of presentation varies with the severity of the disease. The unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia predisposes the patient to develop gallstones.

An aplastic crisis might occur when red cell production is halted due to parvovirus infection. This lasts 1 to 2 weeks, usually the time required for the immune system to clear the virus. Blood transfusions may be needed during this period.

Based on family history, peripheral smear findings, and laboratory investigations an adequate diagnosis is made. Increased osmotic fragility is seen in the majority of the cases. They show normocytic normochromic anemia, an increased MCHC (mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration) due to cellular dehydration, raised RDW(red cell distribution width) and normal or reduced MCV (mean corpuscular volume).

The most common peripheral smear finding is spherocytosis, which presents as small, dark-staining (hyperchromic) red cells without the central zone of pallor. This is, however, a non-specific finding. Other features seen are reticulocytosis, Howell-Jolly bodies (dense basophilic nuclear remnants in the RBCs), marrow erythroid hyperplasia and hemosiderosis.

Splenectomy is the current treatment of choice in HS.

Related Pearl: Features of Peripheral Blood Smear in Different Anemias

Diagnosis

Megaloblastic anemia

Hemolysis

Related Pearl: Classification of Hemolytic Anemias

Hemolytic anemias can be classified in 2 ways:

1. Based on the type of defect:

Type  Intracorpuscular Defects Extracorpuscular Factors

2. Based on the sites of hemolysis:

  • Mechanical injury
    • Trauma caused by cardiac valves 
    • Microangiopathic hemolytic anaemias (hemolytic uremic syndrome, disseminated intravascular coagulation, thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura) 
    • Repetitive physical trauma
  • Complement fixation (antibody-mediated destruction)
    • Hemolytic disease of the newborn- ABO incompatibility
    • Transfusion reaction  
    • Drug-induced 
  • Infections of red blood cells 
    • Malaria
    • Babesiosis
  • Exogenous toxic factors - clostridial sepsis

Extravascular hemolysis:

  • Hereditary spherocytosis
  • Thalassemia
  • Sickle cell anemia
  • Hemolytic disease of the newborn- Rh incompatibility

Both intravascular and extravascular hemolysis:

  • G6PD deficiency
  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia

questions.text:
A female with 8 weeks of gestation was found to be positive for falciparum malaria. You would treat her with:

ACT- Artemisinin-based combination treatment
questions.solution:
Falciparum malaria during the first trimester of pregnancy should be treated with quinine.

Treatment of falciparum malaria during pregnancy:

  • 1st trimester: Quinine
  • 2nd and 3rd trimester: ACT-AL (ACT in the form of Artemether (20 mg) and Lumefantrine) in northeastern states and ACT-SP (ACT in the form of Sulfadoxine-Pyrimethamine) in other states.

Other options:

Option C- Chloroquine is used for the treatment of vivax malaria during pregnancy.

Option D- Primaquine is contraindicated in pregnant women.

questions.text: An elderly female patient comes with complaints of difficulty in climbing stairs for the past 7 months. She also says that she has difficulty lifting her arms while brushing her hair and getting up from a chair. On examination, lilac-colored discoloration of the upper eyelids and dusky red patches over the knuckles, elbows, and knees are seen. Muscle biopsy shows the following image. Which antibody is most likely seen in this case?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, an elderly woman is presenting with a history of proximal muscle weakness along with the heliotrope rash and Gottron papules, and muscle biopsy showing perifascicular atrophy is suggestive of dermatomyositis. The antibody strongly associated with these prominent signs is anti-Mi2 antibodies.

Dermatomyositis involves skin and muscle. It is an immunologic disease in which damage to small blood vessels contributes to muscle injury. It is characterized by proximal muscle weakness along with erythematous rash.

Clinical Features:

  • Symmetric muscle weakness - slow in onset, proximal first.
  • Myalgias
  • Impaired fine movements controlled by distal muscles (late-stage)
  • Elevated serum creatine kinase levels
  • Heliotrope rash - Lilac-colored discoloration of the upper eyelids associated with periorbital edema
  • Gottron papules - Scaling erythematous eruption or dusky red patches over the knuckles, elbows, and knees
  • Dysphagia 
  • Interstitial lung disease (10% of cases)
  • Cardiac involvement is common but rarely leads to cardiac failure.

Histopathology:

  • Muscle biopsies of affected patients show infiltrate of mononuclear inflammatory cells that tend to be most pronounced in the perimysial connective tissue and around blood vessels.
  • Sometimes there is a distinctive pattern in which myofiber atrophy is accentuated at the edges of the fascicles known as perifascicular atrophy.

 Antibodies:

  • Anti-Mi2 antibodies - This is directed against a helicase implicated in the nucleosome remodeling and shows a strong association with prominent Gottron papules and heliotrope rash.
  • Anti-Jo1 antibodies - This antibody is directed against the enzyme histidyl t-RNA synthetase and is detected when the condition is associated with interstitial lung disease, non-erosive arthritis, and “mechanic’s hands" which is a non‐inflammatory hyperkeratosis occurring on the hands or feet, usually over the radial surfaces of the fingers and the outer border of the feet.
  • Anti-P155/P140 antibodies - They are directed against several transcriptional regulators and are associated with paraneoplastic and juvenile cases of dermatomyositis.

 The following image shows Gottron papules:

The following image shows a heliotrope rash

Related Pearl: Inflammatory myopathy

  Dermatomyositis Polymyositis Inclusion Body Myositis
Age of onset Adulthood and childhood >18 years >50 years  
Familial Association No No Yes
Skin Manifestation Yes No No
Muscle involvement

Symmetric

Symmetric

Asymmetric
Histopathological Findings

Perimysial CD4+ cellular infiltrates

Perivascular infiltrates and perifascicular atrophy

Endomysial CD8+ cellular infiltrates 

Perivascular infiltrates  

Endomysial CD8+ cellular infiltrates

Perivascular infiltrates with amyloid inclusion bodies and rimmed vacuoles   
Association with connective tissue disease Scleroderma and mixed connective tissue only Yes Yes
Association with other autoimmune diseases Infrequent Frequent  Infrequent
Association with malignancy Yes (breast, ovarian, lung) and ILD  Yes (incidence much lesser than dermatomyositis)  No
Immunotherapy  Responsive  Responsive  Resistant

Related Pearl: Antibodies in Dermatomyositis

  • Anti-Mi2 antibodies (directed against a helicase implicated in nucleosome remodeling) show a strong association with prominent Gottron papules and heliotrope rash.
  • Anti-Jo1 antibodies (directed against the enzyme histidyl t-RNA synthetase) are associated with interstitial lung disease, nonerosive arthritis, and a skin rash described as “mechanic’s hands.”
  • Anti-P155/P140 antibodies (directed against several transcriptional regulators) are associated with paraneoplastic and juvenile cases of dermatomyositis.

questions.text: A patient is posted for surgery of a distal forearm fracture. Regional anesthesia was planned. The drug is injected intravenously into a tourniquet occluded limb. Which of the following is not true for the type of anesthesia being used here?

choices.text: Providing a bloodless field is difficult
Prilocaine is commonly used in this type of block
Exsanguination is done prior to tourniquet inflation
Bupivacaine is the drug of choice in this method

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the block being done is intravenous regional anesthesia (IVRA) or the Bier's block. Bupivacaine is not the drug of choice in IVRA due to its severe local anesthetic side effects.

Bier's block is used to provide regional anesthesia for short surgical procedures (<60 minutes) of the limbs. It involves the intravenous administration of a local anesthetic into a tourniquet–occluded limb. Anesthesia sets in within 5 minutes. 

The limb is first raised above the heart level to drain venous blood. Then exsanguination is done by applying an Esmarch bandage, following which a tourniquet is applied proximally to the site of the operative procedure. The solution is injected and usually left in place for at least 25 minutes, after which the tourniquet is released incrementally. Drugs commonly used are lidocaine and prilocaine.

The patient is observed for any signs or symptoms of local anesthetic toxicity. The local anesthetic diffuses from the peripheral vascular bed to nonvascular tissue such as axons and nerve endings. The safety and efficacy of this procedure depend on the interruption of blood flow to the involved limb and the gradual release of the tourniquet. 

Complications following Bier's block are postoperative pain, difficulty in providing bloodless field, and in rare cases may lead to compartment syndrome due to increased pressure applied. Premature deflation of the tourniquet or increased dose of local anesthesia may lead to systemic toxicity.

Related Pearl: High Yield Points in Local Anaesthetics

Cocaine: 

  • Naturally occurring
  • Vasoconstrictor
  • 1st local anesthetic

Chloroprocaine: Intradural injections are contraindicated and may cause paraplegia

Prilocaine: 

  • Safest
  • Causes maximum methemoglobinemia
  • Suitable for Bier’s IV block
  • EMLA is a eutectic mixture of LA containing 2.5% lidocaine & 2.5% prilocaine

Bupivacaine

  • Long-acting
  • Most cardiotoxic
  • Contraindicated in regional IV anesthesia
  • Toxicity is treated with amiodarone, bretylium(for VT), vasopressors (for circulatory collapse), isoproterenol and benzodiazepines (sedative)

Procaine

  • LA of choice in malignant hyperthermia
  • 1st synthetic LA
  • Metabolized to PABA, which have been associated with rare anaphylactic reactions

questions.text: What will be the site of erythropoiesis in a healthy 30-year-old man?
questions.solution:
The site of RBC production (erythropoiesis) in a healthy 30-year-old man would be the sternum.

The marrow of the long bones, except for the proximal portions of the humerus and tibia, becomes quite fatty and produces no more red blood cells after about the age of 20 years. As the man is above 20 years of age, the membranous bones would be the principal site of hematopoiesis, which in this case, is the sternum.

Hematopoiesis refers to the production of the different types of blood cells from multipotent hematopoietic stem cells in the marrow. This includes the production of red blood cells, by a process called erythropoiesis.

The sites of erythropoiesis vary at different stages of life as shown below:

Age Site of erythropoiesis
Early embryonic life Yolk sac
Middle trimester of gestation Liver (main)
Spleen and lymph (to a smaller extent)
From the last month of gestation and at birth to 20 years of age Bone marrow of the axial skeleton and long bones like the femur
Beyond 20 years of age Membranous bones such as the vertebrae, sternum, ribs, and iliac.

questions.text: A patient presents with the following rash. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows collarette scales, which are a characteristic feature of pityriasis rosea.

Collarette refers to a scale with an adherent outer border and detachable inner border. It appears like a rim around the lesion as seen below.

Related Pearl: Types of scales associated with dermatological conditions

Types of Scales and Associated Diseases

Type of Scale

Associated Disease

Collarette scale

It is a fine, peripherally attached, and centrally detached scale at the edge of an inflammatory lesion. It is seen in pityriasis rosea.

Fish-like scales

They are seen in ichthyosis vulgaris (ichthyos - fish). Ichthyotic scales are large and polygonal.

Silvery scales

They are characteristic of processes involving parakeratosis, especially psoriasis. The silvery color is due to the reflection of light at several air–keratin interfaces.

Mica-like scales

They are seen in Pityriasis lichenoides. The lesions are polymorphic with some showing hemorrhagic crusting and adherent scales.

Yellow / greasy scales

Seborrheic dermatitis

Leaf-like scales

Pemphigus foliaceous

Powdery, branny, fine scales

Pityriasis versicolor

questions.text: A 2-month-old previously healthy baby was brought to the casualty when the parents found that the baby was not breathing while asleep. Following resuscitative measures, the baby was still apnoeic, pulseless, and asystolic. You suspected sudden infant death syndrome in this child. Which of the following is not a risk factor of this condition?

choices.text: Sharing a bed with a family member
Sleeping in prone position or on the side

questions.solution:
Sleeping on hard/ firm surfaces is not associated with sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS). 

Crowded sleeping areas with many pillows, blankets, and stuffed toys, or old, soft mattresses are associated with an increased risk of SIDS. 

SIDS is also known as a 'cot' or 'crib' death. Usually, the parent finds the infant expired in the crib after putting them to sleep. It is an unexpected death in a healthy infant, whose autopsy may not reveal a cause of death. 

70% of cases of SIDS are found at autopsy to have intrathoracic petechiae in the pleura, epicardium, and thymus. However, this feature is considered to be an agonal phenomenon. The presence of this feature alone should not raise concern for manual suffocation. 

Most cases of SIDS occur between 1-7 months of age but can occur up to 2 years. The risk increases with male infants, multiple births, colder climates, and lower socioeconomic status families.

Ways to reduce the risk of SIDS include:

  • Avoiding sharing a bed with the infant 
  • Abstinence from smoking
  • Using hard/firm bedding and keeping the sleeping area clear
  • Ensuring the infant sleeps supine
  • Keeping the room temperature comfortable
  • Breastfeeding

Option A: Sharing a bed with a family member is associated with SIDS. The risk is augmented if the parent has consumed alcohol or sedative medications. 

Option C: Sleeping prone or on the side is strongly associated with SIDS. The risk of regurgitation and choking is high in infants who sleep prone. These positions are associated with instability. 

Option D: Overheating while sleeping can occur if the baby has a fever or has been placed in excessive clothing or in a warm room. Overheating has been associated with SIDS.

questions.text: A chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) patient requires a step-up in therapy due to symptom persistence.  Which PDE-4 inhibitor can you prescribe as an add-on drug to his treatment regimen?
questions.solution:
Roflumilast is a PDE-4 selective inhibitor approved for use in COPD. 

PDE-4 is the major isoform present in inflammatory cells and its inhibition results in higher anti-inflammatory effects. 

Option A: Seratrodast is a thromboxane receptor antagonist used in the prophylaxis of asthma. It decreases the bronchial hypersensitivity caused by thromboxane. 

Option C: Zileuton is a lipoxygenase inhibitor that can be used in the treatment of asthma.

Option D: Nedocromil is a mast cell stabilizer indicated in the prophylaxis of asthma.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy was brought with the finding as shown in the image below. Further evaluation revealed a chalky white, grey retinal mass with vitreous and subretinal seeding measuring 2mm. Which of the following regimen is commonly used​ in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in a 7-year-old child with a whitish pupillary reflex with the presence of a chalky white, grey retinal mass on fundus examination is retinoblastoma. As the disease falls under group C (vitreous and subretinal seeding <3 mm), it is treated with the commonly used three-drug CVE regimen consisting of vincristine, carboplatin, and etoposide.

Retinoblastoma is a malignant proliferation of immature retinal neural cells and is the most common intraocular malignancy in children. It is associated with mutations in the RB1 gene at chromosome 13q14. It is a tumor of a group called small round blue cell tumors because the immature retinal neural cells are seen as small round cells with large nuclei.

White pupillary reflex or leukocoria is the most common presenting feature, followed by a squint which is usually convergent. Rarely, the child may present with nystagmus and defective vision.

Image showing leukocoria of left eye. 

Histopathology of the tumor shows small round cells with large nuclei. Microscopic features of a well-differentiated tumor include Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (highly specific to retinoblastoma), Homer-Wright rosettes, pseudorosettes, and fleurettes formation. Areas of necrosis and calcification can also be seen.

The histopathological image of retinoblastoma is shown below.

 
Treatment for group A to D diseases typically involves chemotherapy plus focal therapy. The commonly used three-drug regimen is the CVE regimen consisting of vincristine, carboplatin, and etoposide. Focal therapy includes cryotherapy, laser photocoagulation, thermotherapy, plaque radiotherapy, and external beam radiotherapy. Enucleation is the treatment of choice in group E disease. It is done when
  • The tumor involves more than half of the retina
  • The optic nerve is involved
  • Glaucoma is present and the anterior chamber is involved

In the stage of extraocular extension, the globe bursts through the sclera, usually near the limbus or the optic disc. This is followed by rapid fungation and involvement of extraocular tissues resulting in marked proptosis. Distant metastasis occurs through the lymphatic spread and the direct extension by continuity to the optic nerve and brain.

Related Pearl: Reese Ellsworth classification for retinoblastoma

Group Prognosis for maintenance of sight Features
1 Very favourable
  • Solitary tumor, <4DD, at or behind equator
  • Multiple tumors, all <4DD, all at or behind the equator
2 Favourable
  • Solitary tumor, 4–10 DD, at or behind the equator
  • Multiple tumors, all 4–10DD all behind the equator
3 Possible
  • Any lesion anterior to equator
  • Solitary tumor, >10DD behind equator
4 Unfavorable
  • Multiple tumors, some >10 DD
  • Any lesion extending anteriorly to ora serrata
5 Highly unfavorable
  • Massive tumors involving more than one half of retina
  • Vitreous seeding

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman with 16 weeks of gestation presents with cramping abdominal pain followed by the passage of fleshy mass per vaginum but the pain subsided following the expulsion. On examination, the uterus appears smaller, os is closed and the bleeding was found to be stopped. Ultrasound reveals an empty uterine cavity. This is a case of ____________ miscarriage.
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of complete miscarriage.

Expulsion of products of conception, en masse, is called a complete miscarriage.

Features:

  • Subsidence of abdominal pain
  • Decreased or absent vaginal bleeding
  • Uterus is smaller
  • The cervical os is closed
  • Examination of the expelled fleshy mass is found complete.
  • USG - empty uterine cavity

Abortion is the expulsion or extraction from the mother of an embryo or fetus weighing 500 g or less when it is not capable of independent survival.

Classification of abortion:

 

In threatened miscarriage, the process of miscarriage has started but has not progressed to a state from which recovery is impossible. 

Features:

  • Bleeding which is usually slight and may be brownish or bright red in color
  • Usually painless but pain appears following hemorrhage
  • Closed external os
  • Uterine size corresponds to the period of amenorrhea
  • Uterus and cervix feel soft
  • Well-formed gestation ring
  • Fetal cardiac motion
  • Blighted ovum

In inevitable miscarriage, the changes have progressed to a state from where continuation of pregnancy is impossible.

Features:

  • Increased vaginal bleeding
  • Aggravation of pain in the lower abdomen which may be colicky in nature
  • Dilated internal os
  • Rupture of the membranes

In incomplete miscarriage, entire products of conception are not expelled, instead, a part of it is left inside the uterine cavity

  • Pain in the lower abdomen
  • Vaginal bleeding
  • Uterus smaller than the period of amenorrhea
  • Patulous cervical os
  • Echogenic material (products of conception) within the cavity

In missed miscarriage, the fetus is dead and retained inside the uterus for a variable period

Features: The patient usually presents with features of threatened miscarriage followed by

  • Persistence of brownish vaginal discharge
  • Subsidence of pregnancy symptoms
  • Retrogression of breast changes
  • Cessation of uterine growth
  • Nonaudibility of the fetal heart sound
  • Cervix feels firm
  • Negative immunological test for pregnancy
  • Empty sac

In septic abortion, there will be clinical evidence of infection of the uterus and its contents

Features:

  • Rise of the temperature of at least 100.4 F for 24 hours or more
  • Offensive or purulent vaginal discharge
  • Other evidence of pelvic infection such as lower abdominal pain and tenderness.

Related Pearl: Clinical classification of Spontaneous Abortion

Clinical type Description/ Clinical picture USG/ Investigations
Threatened 

Bloody vaginal discharge or bleeding

Closed cervical os

Gestational sac/ pseudo-gestational sac present

Fetal cardiac activity present
Inevitable 

Gush of vaginal fluid or bleeding

Cramping or fever

Dilated cervical os

Gross rupture of membranes

Low lying sac

Oligohydramnios
Incomplete 

Vaginal bleeding

Partial or complete placental separation

Dilated cervical os

Retained products of conception
Complete 

Heavy vaginal bleeding with cramps

Complete placental separation with the passage of tissue or a fetus 

Closed cervical os

Minimally thickened endometrium

Gestational sac absent
Missed /early pregnancy failure or loss

Dead products of conception that were retained for days, weeks or months in the uterus

Closed cervical os

Large anechoic sac consistent with an anembryonic gestation

Serial β-hCG assays
