questions.text: A 24-year-old woman commits suicide by jumping into the village lake. Which of the following is not associated with the death of this woman?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario shows a case of freshwater drowning where death is rapid, occurring within four to five minutes. Hence, the statement that death occurs within 8-10 minutes is incorrect.

When a person drowns in freshwater, 2.5 L or more may be inhaled in 3 minutes, increasing blood volume by 50%. It leads to hypervolemia and hemodilution. Hemodilution leads to hemolysis, myocardial hypoxia, hemoglobinuria, marked hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia. Freshwater denatures the protective surfactant that lines the alveolar wall.

Pulmonary surfactant (lipoprotein) gets inactivated, and, alveoli collapse, lung compliance decreases, which results in a severe ventilation-perfusion mismatch. If the person survives, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) may result. Severe hypotension may occur during and after the initial resuscitation period. 

In freshwater drowning, the following are seen which results in death in 3-5 minutes:

  • anoxia
  • a disturbed sodium-potassium ratio producing arrhythmias
  • ventricular tachycardia 
  • fibrillation.
In cases of seawater drowning, hypernatremia and myocardial anoxia are seen. Seawater being hypertonic to plasma causes a fluid shift from the blood to alveoli causing pulmonary oedema. A net decrease in blood volume causes hemoconcentration and a fall in blood pressure. This hemoconcentration in seawater drowning causes increased viscosity of blood and myocardial anoxia leading to heart failure. Hyperkalemia is not seen in seawater drowning because RBCs get shrunken in contrast to freshwater drowning. Death occurs after about 8 to 10 minutes in the case of seawater drowning. 

Related Pearl: Difference between freshwater and seawater drowning.

  Freshwater drowning Seawater drowning
Mechanism of death Disruption of surfactant - causes surfactant denaturation Disruption of surfactant - causes dilution of surfactant
Fluid and electrolyte changes

Hypervolemia

Hyponatremia

Hyperkalemia

Hypovolemia

Hypernatremia
Time to death

Lesser (4-5 minutes)

More (8-12 minutes)

questions.text: A young male patient is brought to the casualty following a road traffic accident. The X-ray of the patient is given below. Which of the following is ideal for the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The X-ray shows a transverse fracture of the patella, and the ideal management for this is tension-band wiring.

The patient presents with pain and swelling over the affected knee. Patellar tenderness and bruise over the front of the joint can be present. Crepitus may be felt in comminuted fractures. The patient cannot lift his leg in full extension(extension lag) due to the disruption of the extensor apparatus. Hemarthrosis can be associated.

Patellar fractures can be transverse, longitudinal, polar, or comminuted.

The radiological examination includes AP and lateral views. A skyline view of the patella is required in some cases of undisplaced fractures.

Management of patellar fractures: 

Undisplaced fractures: It is treated with a plaster cast extending from the groin to just above the malleoli, with the knee in full extension. This is called a cylinder cast (option A) and is usually left in place for a period of at least 3 weeks.

A transverse fracture is treated by a surgical procedure consisting of the reduction of the fragments known as tension-band wiring and K- wire fixation. This is followed by the repair of the extensor retinacula and physiotherapy.

Comminuted fractures are treated by open reduction and fixation. Patellectomy (option C) is the preferred option in this case as restoration of a smooth articular surface is difficult in this condition. Patella-saving operations are recently more performed with advancements in fixation techniques.

Longitudinal fractures usually have intact extensor apparatus. They can be treated with a cylinder cast or extension brace initially, followed by a range of motion.

Complications are knee stiffness, extensor weakness, and osteoarthritis.

questions.text: Which of the following modes of activation is most commonly found in RAS proto-oncogenes?
questions.solution:
Point mutations of the RAS gene family constitute the most common type of abnormality involving proto-oncogenes in human tumors.

RAS proto-oncogene:

  • The 3 RAS genes in humans (HRAS, KRAS, and NRAS) are the most common oncogenes in human cancer.
  • RAS oncogenes code for a family of proteins called GTP-binding (G) proteins, which are involved in transmitting signals within cells (cellular signal transduction).
  • When RAS is 'switched on' by incoming signals, it subsequently switches on other proteins, which ultimately turn on genes involved in cell growth, differentiation, and survival.
  • Mutations in RAS genes can lead to the production of permanently activated RAS proteins. As a result, this can cause unintended and overactive signaling inside the cell, even in the absence of incoming signals. Because these signals result in cell growth and division, overactive RAS signaling can ultimately lead to cancer.

 

Related Pearl: Cancers associated with important oncogenes

Oncogenes

 Associated cancers

c-MYC

Burkitt’s lymphoma

Adenocarcinomas of the breast, lung, and colon

N-MYC

Neuroblastoma

L-MYC

Small-cell carcinoma of the lung
K-RAS Colon, lung, and pancreatic tumors
N-RAS

Melanoma

AML
H-RAS Bladder and kidney tumors

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of marking B?

choices.text: Swelling of the soft tissues of the scalp
Appears only several hours after birth

questions.solution:
The area marked B represents a cephalohematoma. It is not a swelling of the soft tissues of the scalp.

Cephalohematoma is a subperiosteal hemorrhage that is always limited to the surface of 1 cranial bone and does not cross suture lines. The swelling appears only several hours after birth. There is no discoloration of the overlying scalp.

Most cephalohematomas are resorbed within 2 weeks to 3 months, depending on their size. Cephalohematomas require no treatment, although phototherapy may be necessary to treat the associated hyperbilirubinemia (resorption of blood takes place by the breakdown of RBCs).

 

 

Other markings-

A- Caput succedaneum. It is a diffuse ecchymotic or edematous collection in the soft tissues of the scalp with vertex presentation. It can extend across skull sutures and disappears with the first week of life.

C- Sub-galeal hemorrhage. This a collection of blood under the aponeurosis of the scalp. It is a large potential space, thus bleeding can be extensive. It occurs as a result of ventouse deliveries due to tears of the emissary veins which connect to the dural venous sinuses. It can also occur in hereditary coagulopathies and in association with skull fractures.

D- Epidural hemorrhage. Usually traumatic in origin, these are associated with cephalo-pelvic disproportion, prolonged labor, breech, precipitous labors, or as a result of mechanical assistance in labor. Majority resolve with no intervention.

Related Pearl: Caput succedaneum and Cephalohematoma

Indicators Caput Succedaneum Cephalhematoma
Location Presenting part of the head The periosteum of skull bone and bone
Time of appearance  Immediately after birth Several hours after birth
Cause Prolonged labor, causing venous stasis and edema  Instrumental delivery, causes rupture of emissary veins in skull
Extent of movement Both hemispheres; crosses the suture line Individual bones; do not cross the suture lines
Period of absorption 2-4 days 2 weeks to 3 months
Treatment None

Supportive.

It can cause neonatal jaundice

questions.text: A 23-year-old college student sustained a knee injury during a basketball match in the sports fest. The orthopedic resident examines his knee which is positive for the sag sign. Identify the ligament affected.
questions.solution:
A positive sag sign is suggestive of injury to the posterior cruciate ligament, which is marked as '2' in the image shown.

1- Menisci

3- Anterior cruciate ligament

4- Fibular collateral ligament

The posterior cruciate ligament is attached to the lateral surface of the medial femoral condyle and extends up to the anterior part of the roof of the intercondylar fossa. Its fibres are adjacent to the articular surface. They have two bundles - Anterolateral and posteromedial bundles, which are named according to their femoral attachments.

There are two tests that can be used to diagnose anterior or posterior cruciate ligament laxity. 

Sag sign: Both the knees should be flexed to 90 degrees with the feet flat on the couch. In this position, inspect the upper part of the tibia from the side. If it has dropped back or can be gently pushed back, it is suggestive of a posterior cruciate ligament tear.

Drawer test: In the same position, anchor the foot by sitting on it. Grasp the upper end of the tibia with both hands and rock it backward and forwards to see if there is excessive movement in either direction. Excessive anterior movement is suggestive of anterior cruciate laxity while excessive posterior movement is suggestive of posterior cruciate laxity. 

The following image shows structures of the knee joint in the anterior view:

Related Pearl: Mechanism of injury and tests for knee injuries

Structures Mechanism of injury Tests
Menisci Rotational force

McMurray test

Apley's grinding test

Squat test

Thessaly test
Medial collateral ligament Valgus force Valgus stress test
Lateral collateral ligament Varus force Varus stress test
Anterior cruciate ligament Anterior tibial displacement

Anterior drawer test 

Lachman test

Pivot shift test
Posterior cruciate ligament Posterior tibial displacement

Posterior drawer test

Sag sign

questions.text: In a 65-year-old female patient with carcinoma of the breast, overexpression of which of the following miRNAs will be linked with her condition?
questions.solution:
Overexpression of miR-21 is linked with cancers of the lung and breast. Other options are tumor suppressor miRNAs, whose underexpression may lead to cancer.

microRNAs (miRs):

  • Small non-coding, single-stranded RNAs, approximately 22 nucleotides in length
  • Mediate inhibition of messenger RNA (mRNA) translation through the action of the RNA-induced silencing complex (RISC).
  • Control normal cell growth, differentiation, and cell survival
  • miRNA can be of 2 types:
    • Tumor-suppressive miRNAs: Increased expression of certain miRs decreases the translation of oncogenic mRNAs.
    • Oncogenic-miRNAs: Overexpression of some miRs represses tumor-suppressor genes, promoting tumor development.

They are frequently found altered in various cancers. Oncogenic-miRNAs are overexpressed while tumor suppressor miRNAs are found to be underexpressed. They might serve as potential targets of chemotherapy, where oligonucleotides are used to enhance the expression of tumor suppressor miRNAs or antisense oligonucleotides are used to counter onco-miRNAs. They might also serve as biomarkers for diagnosis, classification and prognostication of various cancers.

List of oncogenic-miRNAs:

  • miR -17-92: ca lung, breast, pancreas, colon
  • miR -21: ca lung, breast
  • miR 155: ca lung and lymphoma

List of tumor suppressor miRNAs:

  • miR -15 and miR -16: CLL
  • let7: ovarian and lung cancer
  • miR - 34: various cancers

Other noncoding RNAs:

  • piwi-interacting RNAs (piRNAs): the most common type of small noncoding RNAs; involved in post-transcriptional gene silencing.
  • sncRNAs: maturation of rRNA and the assembly of ribosomes and long, intervening, non-coding RNAs.
  • lncRNAs: regulate the activity of chromatin “writers,” which modify histones and thus control gene expression.

Related Pearl: Types of RNA

Protein coding RNA

Non Protein coding RNA

mRNA

Ribosomal RNAs (rRNA)

Long noncoding RNAs (lncRNAs)

Transfer RNAs (tRNA)

Small nuclear RNAs (snRNAs)

Micro and silencing RNAs (miRNAs and siRNAs)

questions.text: An anxious pregnant woman came to you for a second opinion with the report of her biochemical screening tests. An increased level of  human chorionic gonadotropin(hCG), as compared to normal pregnancy hCG levels, can be seen in all of the following conditions except:
questions.solution:
The levels of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) are decreased in ectopic pregnancy when compared to the level of hCG in normal intrauterine pregnancy. 

In comparison to hCG levels in normal pregnancy, increased levels of hCG are found in:

  • Hydatidiform mole or choriocarcinoma
  • Trisomy 21 fetus
  • Multiple pregnancies

Decreased levels of hCG as compared to normal pregnancy hCG levels are found in:

  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Spontaneous abortion

Human chorionic gonadotropin is a glycoprotein. It can be detected in the maternal serum or urine as early as 8–9 days postfertilization. Maximum levels in blood and urine are found between 60 - 70 days of pregnancy. It disappears from the circulation within 2 weeks following delivery.

hCG is chemically and functionally similar to the pituitary luteinizing hormone (LH). The α subunit is biochemically similar to LH, FSH (follicular stimulating hormone), and TSH (thyroid-stimulating hormone) whereas the β subunit is relatively unique to hCG.

Functions of hCG are:

  • It stimulates the secretion of progesterone by the corpus luteum during pregnancy
  • Rescue and maintenance of corpus luteum till 6 weeks of pregnancy
  • It stimulates Leydig cells of the male fetus to produce testosterone in conjunction with fetal pituitary gonadotropins
  • It inhibits the maternal processes of immune rejection of the fetus as a homograft.
  • Stimulates both adrenal and placental steroidogenesis.
  • Stimulates maternal thyroid because of its thyrotropic activity.
  • Promotes secretion of relaxin from the corpus luteum.

Related Pearl: Beta hCG in pregnancy

The pattern of beta hCG :

First detectable in plasma 7 to 9 days post-LH surge
          ⇓
Doubles every 2 days
          ⇓
Peaks at 8 to 10 weeks of gestation(~100 IU/mL)
          ⇓
Begins to decline at 10 to 12 weeks
          ⇓
Plateau at 16 weeks till term
 
  • Higher maternal plasma hCG levels- Multifetal pregnancy, erythroblastosis fetalis, gestational trophoblastic disease, Down syndrome.
  • Lower hCG plasma levels -early pregnancy wastage and ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text: A 40-year-old farmer presented to the clinic with fever, malaise, and headache. On examination, a lesion is seen over his right arm as shown in the below image. Later the patient developed sepsis. On Gram staining from cultures, bamboo stick appearance was seen. Which of the following reactions is characteristic of this bacilli?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing a necrotic ulcer with a characteristic black eschar are suggestive of cutaneous anthrax with septicemia signs caused by Bacillus anthracis. The characteristic reaction shown by these bacilli is M'Fadyean’s reaction.

When blood films containing anthrax bacilli are stained with polychrome methylene blue for a few seconds and examined under the microscope, amorphous purplish material is noticed around the bacilli which shows the capsular material. This is called M'Fadyean’s reaction.

Cutaneous anthrax is usually acquired by the entry of spores through injured skin. The lesion starts as a papule and becomes vesicular. Several satellite lesions are seen around a central necrotic lesion which is covered by a black eschar. This lesion is called a malignant pustule. Cutaneous anthrax generally resolves spontaneously.

On microscopy, they appear as gram-positive rods. Bacilli are arranged end to end in long chains. The ends of the bacilli are truncated or often concave and somewhat swollen so that a chain of bacilli presents a bamboo stick appearance.

The organisms produce nonhemolytic grey-to-white, tenacious colonies with a rough texture and a ground-glass appearance in blood agar. Comma-shaped outgrowths (Medusa head, curled hair) may project from the colony.

Other options:

Option A - Naegler's reaction is a useful test for the rapid detection of Clostridium perfringens.

Option B - The reverse CAMP test is used to identify Clostridium perfringens.

Option D - Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon is demonstrated by sporotrichosis, pityrosporum folliculitis, zygomycosis, candidiasis, aspergillosis, and blastomycosis. It is also seen in bacterial infections such as botryomycosis, nocardiosis, and actinomycosis, and parasitic conditions include orbital pythiosis, strongyloidiasis, schistosomiasis, and cutaneous larva migrans.

questions.text: An epidemiologist describes the epidemiologic data received from field investigations and surveillance by using the chart given below. Which of the following examples best represents the chart shown in the image?

choices.text: Gonorrhea outbreak from a sex worker

questions.solution:
The chart in the image shows an epidemic curve that rises and falls rapidly with no secondary waves. This is indicative of a point-source epidemic. Among the given options, an epidemic of food poisoning is the best example of a point-source epidemic.

Point-source epidemics are also called single-exposure epidemics and belong to the common source type of epidemics. The exposure to the disease agent is brief, and all cases develop within one incubation period. Single-exposure outbreaks are explosive, with clustering of cases within a narrow interval of time. Infectious agents, environmental pollution, and food contamination are common causes of point-source epidemics.

Common-source, single-exposure epidemics are differentiated from common-source, multiple-exposure epidemics as follows:

  Common-source, single-exposure epidemic Common-source, multiple-exposure epidemic
Nature of exposure Single, brief exposure Multiple, continuous, or intermittent exposures for a prolonged time
Nature of epidemic Explosive with clustering of cases within a short interval of time Less chance of clustering of cases within a short interval of time
Duration of epidemic Falls within one incubation period of a particular disease Extends beyond one incubation period of a particular disease
Example An epidemic of food poisoning  Outbreak of cholera

 

The below image depicts the various epidemic curves.

Other options:

Options B and C - Outbreak of Legionnaire's disease and a gonorrhea outbreak from a sex worker are examples of a common-source, multiple-exposure epidemic. The exposure from the same source may be prolonged—continuous, repeated, or intermittent—and not at the same time or place. There is no single explosive increase in the number of cases.

Option D - Epidemic of yellow fever (arthropod vector) is an example of propagated epidemics that result from the transmission of the infectious agent over a prolonged duration of time. Cases occur over more than one incubation period.

Related Pearl: Epidemics and its Types

An epidemic is an occurrence in a community or region of cases of an illness that is clearly in excess of normal expectancy. Its types include:

Common source epidemics

  • Single exposure or 'point source' epidemics
  • Multiple or continuous exposure epidemics

Propagated or progressive epidemics

  • Person to person
  • Arthropod vector
  • Animal reservoir

Slow or modern epidemics

  • Non-communicable diseases

questions.text: A 31-year-old male patient with a history of recurrent nephrolithiasis undergoes a CT abdomen and pelvis as shown below. All the following are true about his likely condition except.

choices.text: They are associated with multiple cysts
They are prone to reflux and obstruction
They are associated with Turner's syndrome

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the CT image are suggestive of a horseshoe kidney. It is not associated with multiple cysts. 

Multiple cysts are seen in polycystic kidney disease, a genetic condition that can be autosomal dominant or recessive. 

Horseshoe kidneys are a type of renal fusion anomaly. They are formed when the lower poles of the two kidneys fuse during organogenesis to form an isthmus. They are typically low lying as the inferior mesenteric artery interferes with its ascent due to its size and presence of an isthmus. 

It has a 2:1 male preponderance. Horseshoe kidneys are present in 30% of individuals with Turner's syndrome.

Individuals with horseshoe kidneys are prone to reflux, obstruction, and stone formation.

The CT image below depicts the fused poles in the horseshoe kidney.

Related Pearl: IVU signs and associated conditions

Medullary sponge kidney 

  • Bouquet of flowers/ paintbrush appearance
  • It refers to the cystic dilatation of the distal collecting tubules

Duplex kidney

  • Drooping lily sign
  • It refers to the inferolateral displacement of the lower pole due to an obstructed upper pole in a duplicated collecting system

Horseshoe kidney

  • Handshake sign - due to the position of the lower poles closer to the spine, and the lower calyces closer to each other
  • Flower vase sign - due to medially rotated calyces

Retroperitoneal fibrosis

  • Maiden waist deformity 
  • It refers to the medially drawn ureters caused by fibrosis at the lumbosacral junction

Retrocaval ureter 

  • Fish hook / Reverse J deformity 
  • Right ureter hooks behind the IVC as it passes posterior to it

Ureterocele

  • Cobra/ Adder head appearance
  • It refers to the dilation of the distal ureter

Transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter

  • Goblet sign
  • It is due to the focal dilation of the ureter by an intraluminal mass

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient who is diagnosed with schizophrenia is brought by his wife to the hospital. His wife says that he talks about suicidal ideas and has attempted suicide once. The psychiatrist changes the medication to clozapine. During the follow-up after a month, the patient says that his pillow is completely soaked with saliva in the mornings. What is the mechanism by which clozapine causes soaking of the pillow?
questions.solution:
M4 agonism is the mechanism by which clozapine causes soaking of the pillow. This is called 'wet pillow syndrome' in which there is hypersalivation. Pirenzepine, an M4 antagonist alleviates sialorrhea.

Clozapine, an atypical antipsychotic, is an antagonist of 5HT2A, D1, D3, D4, and α-receptors. Clozapine is used in treatment-resistant schizophrenia, suicidal patients with schizophrenia, severe psychotic depression, and Huntington's disease.  

Adverse effects of clozapine are:

  • Sedation and weight gain- H1 antagonism
  • Syncope, tachycardia, hypotension- α1 antagonism
  • Hypersalivation/sialorrhea- M4 agonism
  • Seizures- dose-dependant
  • Agranulocytosis- dose-independent

The patient who is on clozapine should undergo regular hematological monitoring for the risk of agranulocytosis. Avoid combining clozapine with other agranulocytosis-causing drugs like carbamazepine, phenytoin, propylthiouracil, sulfonamides.

Clozapine reduces the seizure threshold thus increasing the risk of seizures.

Related Pearl: Antipsychotic drugs and their potential to cause side effects

Aripiprazole, Ziprasidone
Metabolic syndrome, Diabetes
Clozapine, Olanzapine
Aripiprazole, Ziprasidone
Weight gain

Hyperprolactinemia
Amisulpride, Haloperidol, Risperidone

questions.text: A male patient presents with complaints of a sudden loss of taste and hearing loss. He also says he is unable to close one eye and tears do not stop flowing. On examination, there are lesions In the ear as shown in the image given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of loss of taste, sudden hearing loss, inability to close one eye, and epiphora along with vesicular eruptions in the external auditory canal and tympanic membrane is suggestive of Ramsay Hunt syndrome (herpes zoster oticus).

Ramsay Hunt syndrome is caused by the reactivation of Herpes zoster in the geniculate ganglion. In most patients, there is an involvement of the trunk of the facial nerve, which results in severe facial palsy.

Clinically, the patients present with all symptoms of facial palsy along with vesicular rash in the external auditory canal and pinna. The involvement of chorda tympani results in a loss of taste. 

The illustration given below shows the clinical features seen in Ramsay Hunt syndrome.

It may also be associated with hearing loss and vertigo due to the involvement of the 8th cranial nerve. There may also be anesthesia of the face due to the involvement of the 5th cranial nerve.

The treatment of Ramsay Hunt syndrome involves antiviral medications like acyclovir or famciclovir, as well as corticosteroids like prednisone.

Other options:

Option A: Bell's palsy is an idiopathic, peripheral facial paralysis or paresis of acute onset due to a lower motor neuron lesion of the facial nerve.

The image given below shows the clinical features seen in Bell's palsy.

 

Option C: Moebius syndrome is a congenital unilateral/ bilateral lower motor neuron facial nerve paralysis with abducens palsy causing abnormal ocular abduction.

Option D: Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome is an idiopathic disorder consisting of a triad of:

  1. Facial paralysis
  2. Swelling of lips
  3. Fissured tongue

The image given below shows the clinical features seen in Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome.

questions.text: A 21-year-old girl who presented with multiple beefy-red painless ulcers over the vulval region is diagnosed with granuloma inguinale. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The causative organism of granuloma inguinale is Klebsiella granulomatis, a gram-negative bacillus.

Granuloma inguinale begins as a painless nodule that later ulcerates to form multiple beefy red painless ulcers. These ulcers tend to coalesce. There will be minimal adenopathy and progressive destruction of the vulva.

Microscopic examination of smears from the lesion/biopsy specimens reveals pathognomonic intracytoplasmic Donovan bodies and clusters of bacteria with a bipolar (safety-pin) appearance.

The microscopic image below shows the pathognomonic intracytoplasmic Donovan bodies. It also shows clusters of gram-negative bacteria with a bipolar/safety-pin appearance.

Management:

Treatment recommended by the CDC (2015) is azithromycin 1 g once weekly for at least 3 weeks until lesions are completely healed. Alternative regimens include doxycycline, ciprofloxacin, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, or erythromycin base.

Other options:

Option A - Chlamydia trachomatis causes lymphogranuloma venereum.

Option C - Haemophilus ducreyi causes chancroid.

Option D - Herpes simplex virus causes genital herpes.

Related Pearl: Comparison of Genital Ulcers

  Genital herpes  Syphilitic chancre (Hard chancre) Donovanosis/ granuloma inguinale Chancroid (soft chancre) LGV
Incubation period 2-7 days

10-90 days 

Average: 21days

Causative agent HSV-2>HSV-1 Treponema pallidum Klebsiella granulomatis Hemophilus ducreyi

Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1,L2,L3

Cluster of vesicles on erythematous base.

Single painless ulcer with a clean base and a firm raised border.

Painless lymphadenopathy

Painless papule or nodule erodes into beefy red granulomatous ulcer with rolled edges.

No lymphadenopathy, pseudobubos are seen

Painful ulcer (ducreyi makes you cry).

Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy

Painless genital ulcer.

Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy
Diagnosis  Tzanck preparation shows multinucleated giant cells, PCR Clinical diagnosis Donovan bodies on biopsy Clinical diagnosis Nucleic acid amplification tests
Treatment Acyclovir/famcyclovir or valacyclovir Penicillin/Ceftriaxone

Azithromycin/Doxycycline

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is diagnosed with rhabdomyosarcoma. Among the following, what is the most common site affected?
questions.solution:
Rhabdomyosarcoma, a tumor of striated skeletal muscle, most commonly occurs in the head and neck. Other chief sites are the genitourinary tract and extremities. 

Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common pediatric soft tissue sarcoma. The presentation is as follows

  • Orbital - Proptosis or swelling of the eyelid. The major histologic subtype is embryonal.
  • Genitourinary - Pelvic mass, vaginal mass, bladder, and prostate enlargement. The major histologic subtype is alveolar.

Metastasis is commonly seen in the lung, bone marrow, and bone. 

Treatment - A combination of medical, surgical, and radiotherapy ensures a 5-year survival in over 70 % of the patients with rhabdomyosarcoma. The chemotherapeutic agents used are vincristine, doxorubicin, cyclophosphamide, and actinomycin.

questions.text: A 62-year-old presented with diminished vision 1 year after cataract surgery. The findings are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Diminished vision 1 year after cataract surgery, supported with the image of vacoulated clusters seen behind IOL is suggestive of Elschnig’s pearls. It is a type of after cataract.

After cataract, or secondary cataract or posterior capsular opacification, is a late postoperative complication that follows extracapsular extraction of the lens. It is the most common late postoperative complication. It may be caused by residual opaque lens matter or proliferation of left out anterior epithelial cells. Different types of after cataract include:

  • Elschnig’s pearls: The subcapsular epithelial cells proliferate and develop into vacuolated soap bubble like clusters along the posterior capsule.
  • Soemmering’s ring: A peripheral dense ring is formed behind the iris and is enclosed between layers of the capsule.
  • Dense membranous after-cataract: It is formed in the pupillary area impairing the vision.
  • Thin membranous after-cataract: It is thickened posterior capsule.

Treatment of after cataract is by Nd-YAG laser capsulotomy of the posterior capsule, which works on the principle of photodisruption, or surgical posterior capsulotomy. 

Option B: Irvine–Gass syndrome is cystoid macular edema (CME) that develops in post-cataract surgery patients. Though it is mostly clinically insignificant, some cases can present with blurring of vision, one to three months after surgery. In CME, on fundoscopy a honeycomb appearance and on fundus fluorescein angiography(FFA) flower petal pattern can be seen. The below image depicts the flower petal pattern seen on FFA.

Option C: Post operative endophthalmitis presents as ocular pain, diminished vision and hypopyon within months to years after the surgery. Fungal endophthalmitis can rarely occur with puff ball exudates in the vitreous cavity.

Option D: UGH syndrome is where uveitis, glaucoma and hyphema occurs simultaneously. It is seen commonly with rigid anterior chamber intraocular lens (IOL) implantation.

Related Pearl: Complications of cataract surgery

Early postoperative complications

Occurs within the first few days to 4 weeks.

  • Endophthalmitis
  • Retained lens matter
  • Corneal edema
  • Wound leak and dehiscence
  • Toxic anterior segment syndrome

Late postoperative complications

Occurs within months to years.

  • Posterior capsule opacification (most common)
  • Cystoid macular edema
  • Secondary glaucoma
  • Retinal detachment
  • Intraocular lens malpositions:
    • Windshield wiper syndrome— intraocular lens haptic rubs on the endothelium
    • Sunset syndrome—inferior subluxation
    • Sunrise syndrome—superior subluxation
    • Complete dislocation of the intraocular lens.

questions.text: An alcoholic male patient presents with complaints of acute onset of epigastric pain radiating to the back. Serum amylase and lipase were elevated. Examination revealed the finding shown below. All of the following are the radiological findings associated with this condition, except ______.
questions.solution:
Cullen sign is not a radiological finding associated with this condition. It is a clinical sign seen on abdominal examination.

The clinical presentation of acute onset of epigastric pain radiating to the back, elevated serum amylase and lipase, and the image showing the Grey-Turner sign is suggestive of acute pancreatitis.

Abdominal examination findings in acute pancreatitis:

  • Grey Turner sign: bleeding into the fascial planes leading to bluish discoloration of the flanks
  • Cullen’s sign: bleeding into the fascial planes leading to the bluish discoloration around the umbilicus (image shown below)

 

Radiological x-ray findings in acute pancreatitis:

Sentinel loop sign - It refers to the generalized or localized ileus of the intestine adjacent to the pancreas. A sentinel loop refers to a short segment of adynamic ileus adjacent to an intra-abdominal inflammatory process.

Colon cut-off sign - It occurs as a result of colonic spasm at the splenic flexure. This would result in gaseous distension of the proximal colon with the abrupt termination of the gas at the level of splenic flexure and decompression of the more distal part of the colon.

Renal halo sign - It is produced by the apparent enhancement of the perirenal fat by an adjacent retroperitoneal exudate in the pararenal space.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in Acute Pancreatitis

Radiographic findings of acute pancreatitis are non-specific.

The sentinel loop is seen in an X-ray. It is a focal area of adynamic ileus close to an intra-abdominal inflammatory process. A sentinel loop in the upper abdomen indicates pancreatitis.

The sentinel loop sign may aid in localizing the source of inflammation. For example, a sentinel loop in the upper abdomen may indicate pancreatitis, while one in the right lower quadrant may be due to appendicitis.

Colon cut-off sign: Functional spasm at the splenic flexure due to the extension of inflammation to phrenicocolic ligament via transverse mesocolon.

The X-ray given below shows sentinel loop sign (marked as '1') and colon cut-off sign (marked as '2') in a patient with acute pancreatitis:

 

Renal halo sign: Edema around the kidney due to the involvement of paranephric fat resulting in:

  • Obliteration of psoas shadow
  • Localised ground-glass appearance

Related Pearl: Computed Tomography Severity Index (CTSI)/Balthazar Scoring for Acute Pancreatitis

Balthazar Score
Balthazar Grade Appearance on CT CT Grade Points
Grade A Normal CT 0 Points
Grade B Focal or diffuse enlargement of the pancreas 1 Point
Grade C Pancreatic gland abnormalities and peripancreatic inflammation  2 Points
Grade D  Fluid collection in a single location 3 Points
Grade E Two or more sites of fluid collection and/ or gas bubbles in, or adjacent to, the pancreas 4 Points

 

Necrosis Score  
Necrosis Percentage CT grade points
No necrosis 0 points
0 to 30% necrosis 2 points
30 to 50% necrosis 4 points
Over 50% necrosis 6 points

The numerical Computed Tomography Severity Index (CTSI) has a maximum of 10 points, and it is the sum of the Balthazar grade points and pancreatic necrosis grade points. 

CTSI score 0-3: Mild pancreatitis

CTSI score 4-6: Moderate pancreatitis

CTSI score 7-10: Severe pancreatitis

 

Related Pearl: Ranson Prognostic Criteria for Acute Pancreatitis

Ranson's prognostic criteria at presentation
Parameter Non-gallstone pancreatitis Gallstone pancreatitis
Age >55 years >70 years
Blood glucose level >200 mg/dL >220 mg/dL
White blood cell count >16,000 cells/mm3 >18,000 cells/mm3
Serum LDH level >350 IU/L  >400 IU/L
Serum Aspartate aminotransferase level  >250 IU/L  >250 IU/L

 

Ranson's prognostic criteria after 48 hours of admission
Parameter Non-gallstone pancreatitis Gallstone pancreatitis 
Hematocrit fall
 >10% >10%
Serum calcium level <8 mg/dL <8 mg/dL
Base deficit >4 mEq/L >5 mEq/L
Blood urea nitrogen level increase 

≥5 mg/dL despite IV fluid hydration

 ≥2 mg/dL despite IV fluid hydration
Fluid sequestration
  >6 L  >4 L
PaO2  <60 mm Hg  Not available

Ranson score ≥3 defines severe pancreatitis.

Score Interpretation

  • 0 to 2 points: 0% to 3% mortality
  • 3 to 4 points: 15% mortality
  • 5 to 6 points: 40% mortality
  • 7 to 11: nearly 100% mortality

questions.text:
Match the following skull radiology findings and the associated conditions.
1) Salt and pepper appearance A) Hurler's syndrome
2) J-shaped sella B) Paget's disease
3) Punched-out lesions C) Hyperparathyroidism
4) Cotton wool appearance D) Multiple myeloma
questions.solution:
The correct option is 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B.

  • Salt and pepper appearance - Hyperparathyroidism 
  • J-shaped sella - Hurler's syndrome
  • Punched-out lesions - Multiple myeloma
  • Cotton wool appearance - Paget's disease

Salt and pepper appearance of the skull: It is also known as pepper pot skull and is seen in hyperparathyroidism. It is characterized by multiple tiny well-defined lucencies in the skull that occur due to resorption of the trabecular bone.

Other radiological findings in hyperparathyroidism:

  • Sub-periosteal resorption - Classical and pathognomonic feature of hyperparathyroidism
  • Loss of lamina dura 
  • Expansile lytic lesion, otherwise known as brown tumor, generally affecting maxilla/ mandible

Image showing salt and pepper appearance of the skull:

 

J-shaped sella - It is a skull radiographic finding in Hurler's syndrome.

Other radiological findings in Hurler's syndrome:

  • Macrocephaly
  • Thickened calvaria (skull cap)
  • Oar-shaped ribs
  • Hook-shaped vertebral bodies

Note:

J-shaped sella can also be seen in other conditions like optic chiasm glioma, hydrocephalus, neurofibromatosis, as a normal anatomic variant, etc.

Image showing J-shaped sella:

 

Punched-out lesions - It is frequently associated with multiple myeloma. 

Other important causes for punched-out skull lesions include metastatic lesions, tuberculosis, sarcoidosis, epidermoid tumor, fibrous dysplasia, etc.

Image showing punched-out lesions of the skull:

 

Cotton wool appearance - It is seen in Paget's disease of the bone. It refers to the mixed lytic and sclerotic lesions of the skull.

Other skull radiological findings in Paget's disease:

  • Osteoporosis circumscripta - Large well-defined lytic lesions involving the inner part of the outer table of the skull with an intact inner table
  • Diploic widening
  • Tam o' Shanter sign

questions.text: A 56-year-old female patient with a history of hypertension for 2 years came with complaints of easy fatiguability and shortness of breath. On examination, her sclera was yellow. Hemoglobin was reduced to 6 g/dL. On peripheral smear, spherocytes were seen. Further, a positive Coombs test was obtained. Which of the following antihypertensive drugs is the most likely cause of the symptoms in this patient?
questions.solution:
The antihypertensive that is the most likely cause of the symptoms in this patient is methyldopa. All the above options are examples of centrally-acting sympatholytic drugs.

Some patients who are on methyldopa for prolonged periods break tolerance in some unknown manner and lead to the production of antibodies against red cell antigens, particularly Rh antigens. These antibodies give a positive Coombs test and sometimes result in significant hemolytic anemia. The onset is often abrupt and leads to a sudden drop in hemoglobin levels. This excessive hemolysis will result in jaundice and hemoglobinuria. The blood picture shows spherocytes and fragmented RBCs.

Methyldopa, a prodrug (an analog of DOPA) gets metabolized to α-methylnorepinephrine (the active metabolite). α-Methylnorepinephrine inhibits the adrenergic neuronal outflow from the brainstem via acting as an agonist at α2 adrenergic receptors in the presynaptic membrane in the brainstem. This attenuates the release of norepinephrine, thereby reducing the sympathetic output from the brainstem resulting in the reduction of blood pressure.

Therapeutic uses: usually used in hypertension in pregnancy.

Adverse effects:

  • Dry mouth, sedation
  • Gynecomastia
  • Positive Coombs test- if the patient is symptomatic, then stop the drug
  • Rare adverse effects- red cell aplasia, thrombocytopenia, lupus-like syndrome, etc

Other options:

Option A) Clonidine: It is an imidazoline derivative and acts as an agonist at α2 receptors. The mechanism of action is the same as that of methyldopa.

Therapeutic uses:

  • Hypertension
  • Diarrhea in diabetic patients
  • Opioid, tobacco, alcohol withdrawal
  • Menopausal hot flushes

Adverse effects: 

  • Dry mouth, sedation
  • Depression
  • Sexual dysfunction
  • Clonidine withdrawal reaction

Option C) Moxonidine: It is a mixed α2 receptor and imidazole, I1 receptor agonist. It reduces the sympathetic outflow from the central nervous system thereby reducing blood pressure.

Therapeutic uses: Hypertension, neuropathic pain

Option D) Guanfacine: It is a more selective α2 agonist. It reduces the sympathetic outflow from the central nervous system thereby reducing blood pressure.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented with long-standing complaints of dysphagia which was getting worse for the past 4 months. A barium swallow was performed and it showed the following finding. Which of the following is the definitive treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient likely has achalasia cardia and the definitive treatment is Heller's myotomy. Surgical management is the first-line treatment modality. 

Achalasia or 'failure to relax' in Greek occurs due to the lack of ganglion cells in the myenteric plexus (Auerbach's). The lower esophageal sphincter (LES) fails to relax leading to dysphagia, regurgitation of food, and progressive dilation of the esophagus proximal to the constriction. 

Barium radiology shows hold-up in the distal esophagus, abnormal contractions in the oesophageal body, and a tapering stricture in the distal esophagus often described as a ‘bird’s beak’.

Laparoscopic Heller's myotomy is the procedure of choice. Here, the muscles of the lower esophagus and cardia are cut. However, this can cause iatrogenic gastroesophageal reflux (GERD) due to damage to the lower esophageal sphincter (LES). Thus, newer techniques involve a partial fundoplication like Dor's procedure to reinforce the sphincter and reduce GERD symptoms. 

Endoscopic myotomy is a newer, alternate procedure. Here, a submucosal tunnel is formed in the mid esophagus region that allows a long myotomy. 

Option A: Calcium channel blockers can be given in the initial stages of the disease. They relieve the chest pressure that occurs around mealtimes. However, they are not permanent treatments and can be used while waiting for surgery.  

Option B: Botulinum toxin injection can be used as a treatment in patients who may not be candidates for surgery or dilatation. Limitations to botulinum toxin injections are that the effect is short-lived (6-12 months) and patients often require multiple treatments.

Option C: Pneumatic dilatation of the LES has is successful in 75% of patients. It involves using a balloon to stretch the LES and improve competence. It requires multiple sessions and has a low risk of esophageal perforation.

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia cardia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

  • Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.
  • Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease.

Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • Regurgitation
  • Chest pain
  • Weight loss
  • Bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation, Heller myotomy

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Antisynthetase syndrome?
questions.solution:
Erosive arthritis is not a feature of Antisynthetase syndrome.

Antisynthetase syndrome is common in females with a predilection for proximal muscles. It is characterized by:

  • Myositis
  • Non-erosive arthritis
  • Interstitial lung disease (ILD)
  • Raynaud phenomenon
  • Mechanic hands
  • Fever
  • Anti-Jo1 antibodies against aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase.

Spiral chest CT scans demonstrate the honeycomb pattern of ILD. The most common aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase antibody is anti-Jo-1. Creatine kinase is usually elevated. 

Muscle biopsy reveals perimysial fragmentation, perimysial staining with alkaline phosphatase, and deposition of membrane attack complex on sarcolemma and capillaries. Perifascicular muscle necrosis is common in antisynthetase syndrome whereas perifascicular atrophy is common in dermatomyositis. There is no associated risk of malignancy. 

 

Related Pearl: Inflammatory myopathy

  Dermatomyositis Polymyositis Inclusion Body Myositis
Age of onset Adulthood and childhood >18 years >50 years  
Familial Association No No Yes
Skin Manifestation Yes No No
Muscle involvement

Symmetric

Symmetric

Asymmetric
Histopathological Findings

Perimysial CD4+ cellular infiltrates

Perivascular infiltrates and perifascicular atrophy

Endomysial CD8+ cellular infiltrates 

Perivascular infiltrates  

Endomysial CD8+ cellular infiltrates

Perivascular infiltrates with amyloid inclusion bodies and rimmed vacuoles   
Association with connective tissue disease Scleroderma and mixed connective tissue only Yes Yes
Association with other autoimmune diseases Infrequent Frequent  Infrequent
Association with malignancy Yes (breast, ovarian, lung) and ILD  Yes (incidence much lesser than dermatomyositis)  No
Immunotherapy  Responsive  Responsive  Resistant

Related Pearl: Antibodies in Dermatomyositis

  • Anti-Mi2 antibodies (directed against a helicase implicated in nucleosome remodeling) show a strong association with prominent Gottron papules and heliotrope rash.
  • Anti-Jo1 antibodies (directed against the enzyme histidyl t-RNA synthetase) are associated with interstitial lung disease, nonerosive arthritis, and a skin rash described as “mechanic’s hands.”
  • Anti-P155/P140 antibodies (directed against several transcriptional regulators) are associated with paraneoplastic and juvenile cases of dermatomyositis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient presented with painless axillary lymphadenopathy. A lymph-node biopsy was done and histopathology revealed the following. Immunophenotyping revealed CD20+, BCL6+ ,CD15-  and CD30-. The findings are suggestive of which of the following subtypes of Hodgkin's lymphoma?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with immunophenotype positive for CD20 & BCL6 and negative for CD15 and CD30, and the histopathology picture showing lymphohistiocytic variants of Reed Steenberg cell, also called popcorn cell, is characteristic of nodular lymphocyte-predominant subtype of Hodgkin's lymphoma (NLPHL).

The nodular Lymphocyte predominance subtype is a non-classical Hodgkin's lymphoma commonly seen in young males <35 years of age. Common presentations include cervical or axillary lymphadenopathy.

It is characterized by lymphohistiocytic variants with multilobed nuclei. They resemble popcorn kernels and are are positive for CD20 and BCL6 while negative for CD15 and CD30. 

The below histopathology image shows popcorn cells of NLPHL.

Hodgkin's lymphomas are a group of lymphoid neoplasms arising from a single or group of lymph nodes and can spread to anatomically contiguous lymphoid tissues. It usually presents as painless lymphadenopathy. The distinctive feature of Hodgkin's lymphoma is the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells.

Reed-Stenberg cells are neoplastic cells derived from the germinal center or post–germinal center B cells. They appear as large cells with multiple nuclei or a single nucleus with multiple nuclear lobes. Each cell contains a large inclusion-like nucleolus and abundant cytoplasm.

WHO classifies Hodgkin's lymphoma into 5 subtypes:

  • Nodular sclerosis: Frequent lacunar cells
  • Mixed cellularity
  • Lymphocyte-rich
  • Lymphocyte depletion
  • Nodular lymphocyte predominance

The first 4 subtypes are considered classical Hodgkin's lymphoma. The RS cells are CD 15+ and CD30+. The lymphocyte predominant type is considered non-classical Hodgkin's lymphoma with CD15-, CD30-, CD20+, and EB -. 

Other options: 

Option A: Nodular sclerosis is the most common subtype equally affecting young males and females. Histology shows frequent lacunar cells and occasional diagnostic RS cells with the background infiltrate composed of T lymphocytes, eosinophils, macrophages, plasma cells, and fibrous bands. The RS cells are positive for CD15 and CD30.

Option B: Lymphocyte-rich is an uncommon subtype seen in older-aged adults with increased occurrence in males. Frequent mononuclear and diagnostic RS cells and background infiltrates rich in T lymphocytes are seen. The RS cells are positive for CD15 and CD30.

Option C: Lymphocyte depletion is an uncommon subtype seen in older men. A reticular variant is observed in this subtype with frequent diagnostic RS cells and a small amount of background reactive cells. The RS cells are positive for CD15 and CD30.

Related Pearl: Important Features of the Different Types of Hodgkin's Lymphoma (HL)

Classic subtypes

  • Nodular sclerosis 
  • Mixed cellularity 
  • Lymphocyte-rich
  • Lymphocyte depletion

Non-Classical subtype

  • Lymphocyte predominant

Note: Mixed cellularity is most commonly associated with HIV due to its high incidence.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is suffering from HIV-AIDS. He presents with complaints of numbness and painful tingling sensation in his hands, feet, and legs. A provisional diagnosis of HIV-associated peripheral neuropathy was made. Which of the following is the most common type of neuropathy seen?
questions.solution:
The most common type of HIV-associated peripheral neuropathy is distal symmetric polyneuropathy. 

Individuals suffering from HIV-AIDS can develop neuropathies as a consequence of the disease itself, or due to associated antiviral medication and concomitant infections.

HIV-associated peripheral neuropathy can present as the following:

  1. Distal symmetric polyneuropathy
  2. Sensory ganglionopathy
  3. Multiple mononeuropathies
  4. Progressive polyradiculopathy
  5. Inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy(both acute and chronic types)
  6. Autonomic neuropathy 

Distal symmetric polyneuropathy is the most common type of peripheral neuropathy seen in individuals suffering from AIDS. It is a small fiber neuropathy characterized by symmetrical numbness and painful paresthesias involving the distal extremities. 

Other options:

Option B: Sensory ganglionopathy is a rare presentation of HIV-AIDS. It presents as disproportionate sensory ataxia without weakness. This pattern is more commonly seen in Sjogren's syndrome and as a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with small-cell cancer of the lung.

Option C: Multiple mononeuropathies in HIV-AIDS with weakness, numbness, paresthesias, and pain occur in the distribution of affected nerves. Nerve biopsies reveal axonal degeneration with necrotizing vasculitis or perivascular inflammation when associated with HIV-AIDS. This pattern is more commonly seen in carpal tunnel syndrome, cubital tunnel syndrome, etc.

Option D: Progressive polyradiculopathy in HIV- AIDS presents usually as lumbosacral polyradiculoneuropathy secondary to CMV infection. Patients present with severe radicular pain, numbness, and weakness in the legs, which is usually asymmetric. This pattern is seen more commonly in a herniated disc, degenerative joint disease, rheumatoid arthritis, and trauma.

questions.text: The dissection of the inguinal canal reveals the structure marked A. Which of the following is the content of the structure marked A?
questions.solution:
The structure marked A represents the spermatic cord. The genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve is the content of the spermatic cord.


The spermatic cord is a structure that passes through the inguinal canal in males. The inguinal canal is a natural passageway between the muscle layers of the anterior abdominal wall in the region of the groin. It transmits the spermatic cord in males, the round ligament of the uterus in females, and the ilioinguinal nerve in both sexes.

The contents of the spermatic cord include:

  • Cremaster muscle fibers
  • Testicular artery and accompanying veins
  • Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve
  • Vas deferens
  • Cremasteric vessels
  • Lymphatics
  • Processus vaginalis

Coverings of the spermatic cord from inside to outside are:

  • Internal spermatic fascia from fascia transversalis
  • Cremasteric fascia
  • External spermatic fascia from external oblique aponeurosis 

An injury to the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve results in loss of sensation in the skin of the scrotum of males, and loss of sensation of the mons pubis and labia majora in females.

Other options:

Option A: Iliohypogastric nerve is not the content of the spermatic cord/inguinal canal. It carries the sensory supply from the suprapubic area.

Option B: Ilioinguinal nerve is not the content of the spermatic cord but it is the content of the inguinal canal. It supplies somatic sensation to the skin of the upper and medial thigh. In males, it also innervates the root of the penis and upper scrotum. In females, it innervates the mons pubis and labia majora.

Option C: Femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve is a content of the femoral canal. It carries sensory supply to the anterior thigh below the inguinal ligament.

The image given below shows nerves related to the inguinal region.

Related Pearl: Inguinal canal and spermatic cord contents

Inguinal canal contents:

Male Female
  • Spermatic cord  (with genital branch of genitofemoral nerve)
  • Ilioinguinal nerve
  • Round ligament of the uterus 
  • Genital branch of genitofemoral nerve
  • Ilioinguinal nerve

Spermatic cord contents:

  • Three arteries:
    • Testicular artery
    • Deferential artery
    • Cremasteric artery
  • Two nerves:
    • Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve
    • Sympathetic nerve fibers
  • Three other structures:
    • Ductus deferens
    • Pampiniform plexus of veins
    • Lymphatic vessels

questions.text: A 16-year-old patient visits the OPD with progressive deformity in the left lower limb. The x-ray of the patient is given below. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and the x-ray showing Shepherd's crook deformity are both suggestive of fibrous dysplasia of the proximal femur. 

Fibrous dysplasia is a condition that affects bone development and is characterized by the replacement of the bone with fibrous tissue. It is commonly monostotic (involves a single bone), but in 20% of cases, it can be polyostotic.

Clinical features:

The patient presents with a progressive limb deformity or a fracture through a previously asymptomatic lesion. Presentation is often in the second decade. Other symptoms include nonspecific bone pain, tenderness, and swelling in the affected area. The commonly involved sites are the proximal femur, tibia, pelvis, and foot.

McCune-Albright syndrome: It is characterized by polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, precocious puberty, and cafe-au-lait spots with irregular borders.

Radiological findings:

  • Well-defined, expansile intramedullary lesions
  • Hazy, ground-glass appearance is seen in the majority of cases
  • Shepherd's crook deformity - Expansion with marked varus in the proximal femur

Treatment:

Bisphosphonates are used to manage bone pain. Surgical stabilization and realignment are done when there is a progressive deformity or pathological fracture. 

Other options: 

Option A: Osteoid osteoma is a benign tumor formed of osteoid and woven bone surrounded by a halo of reactive bone. It is most commonly seen in the diaphysis of the proximal femur. They most often present with pain that is classically worse at night and relieved by non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). Plain X-ray demonstrates an area of dense sclerosis with a small rounded area of osteolysis. The preferred treatment is CT-guided radiofrequency ablation.

Option C: Chondrosarcoma is the second most common primary malignant bone tumor after osteosarcoma. It can present between the 3rd and 8th decades of life. They are slow-growing tumors that produce deep pain with an enlarging mass and arise in any bone derived from enchondral ossification. Radiographically, they appear as large, intraosseous, osteolytic tumors with irregular, granular calcifications, giving a honeycomb or popcorn appearance. CT and MRI are useful in the diagnosis. Chondrosarcoma is resistant to both chemotherapy and radiation. Surgical excision is the only treatment.

Option D: Ewing sarcoma is related to neuroectodermal tumors and arises from the mesenchymal stem cells from the bone marrow. The characteristic translocation involved is t(11:22). The tumor usually develops between 10 and 20 years of age and is usually located in the diaphysis of the long bones (femur-most common). Pain is followed by swelling and a low-grade fever. On radiography, a periosteal reaction with an 'onion peel' appearance is seen. Treatment includes preoperative chemotherapy, wide excision, and radiotherapy, if required.

Related Pearl: Classical Radiological Appearance of Bone Tumors

RADIOLOGICAL APPEARANCE 

TUMORS

Sunray appearance / Codman’s triangle

Osteosarcoma (but can be seen in any malignant lesion)

Onion peel appearance 

Ewing’s sarcoma (but can be seen in any malignant lesion or chronic osteomyelitis)

Soap bubble appearance 

Giant cell tumor, adamantinoma 

Ground glass appearance / Shepherd's

crook deformity 

Fibrous dysplasia 

Patchy calcification 

Chondrogenic tumors (chondrosarcoma and chondroblastoma)

Popcorn, punctate or comma-shaped calcification

Chondrosarcoma 

Stippled or Punctate calcification

Chondroblastoma 

Homogeneous calcification 

Osteogenic tumors (osteosarcoma)

Fallen fragment / Trap door sign

Simple bone cyst

Double-density fluid levels and intra-lesional septation

Aneurysmal bone cyst

Winking owl sign

Vertebral metastasis 

Polka dot sign / Corduroy / Jailhouse sign

Vertebral hemangioma

Moth eaten bone

Multiple myeloma

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient who is a known case of diabetes mellitus presents with skin findings as shown in the image below.  On examination, he complained of pain in the calf on dorsiflexion of the foot. On further questioning, the patient revealed that he was started on antidepressants recently. What could be the probable diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario history of diabetes mellitus, antidepressant intake, with pain in the calf on dorsiflexion of the foot(Positive Homan's sign indicating deep vein thrombosis), and the image showing necrolytic migratory rash is suggestive of glucagonoma.

Glucagonoma is a pancreatic islet cell tumor. It is a rare syndrome, with a classic presentation of the “4 D’s”: diabetes, dermatitis, deep vein thrombosis (DVT), and depression. It is a state of severe catabolism. Patients present with loss of weight, depletion of protein and fat stores, and vitamin deficiency.  The characteristic skin lesion seen in this condition is the necrolytic migratory erythema which occurs due to severe amino acid deficiency. Providing parental amino acids may help in the disappearance of skin lesions. 

Diagnosis of this condition is made by measuring fasting glucagon levels. A level of more than 1000pg/ml is diagnostic. (Normal - 100pg/ml) Management involves the correction of nutritional deficiencies with enteral nutrition. Octreotide can help reverse the catabolic state. DVT prophylaxis should be provided as soon as possible. Surgery can be done if the mass is resectable. 

Other options: 

Option A - Gastrinomas are islet cell tumors that produce large amounts of gastrin. This gastrin does not respond to the normal feedback mechanism and is not suppressed by high luminal pH. Patients with gastrinomas present with abdominal pain and diarrhea. 

Option B - Insulinomas are the most common pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors. They are characterized by symptoms of hypoglycemia, low plasma glucose at the time of symptoms, and relief of symptoms on glucose consumption. This is known as the Whipple's triad.

Option D - VIPoma is a neuroendocrine tumor that arises from the pancreatic D2 islet cells. It is characterized by watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria. It is also referred to as pancreatic cholera. 

Related Pearl: Clinical features of glucaganoma: 4Ds

  • Diabetes – usually mild and not associated with ketoacidosis
  • Dermatitis – Necrolytic erythema migrans
  • Deep vein thrombosis
  • Depression

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient complains of bloody anal discharge, rectal pain, and tenesmus. On examination, there is ulcerative proctitis. The patient reveals that he had unprotected anal intercourse 3 weeks ago. This was followed by painful lesions in the genital area that healed without scarring. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of hemorrhagic proctitis with a history of anal intercourse and lesions in the genital area that healed without scarring is suggestive of lymphogranuloma venerum.

Lymphogranuloma venerum is a sexually transmitted disease caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. The organism spreads from the site of the initial lesion to the regional lymph nodes, causing lymphangitis. There are three stages of the disease: 

Primary: The incubation period is 3–30 days. The genital lesions may be painful or painless. The patient usually presents with symptoms of hemorrhagic proctitis. The condition is common among homosexuals. 

Secondary: It may take days to weeks for the disease to manifest. It is characterized by tender unilateral or bilateral inguinal or femoral lymphadenopathy (groove sign). The lymph nodes coalesce to form painful buboes which rupture and form fistulae and sinus tracts. 

Tertiary: Genito-anorectal syndrome is seen occurring years after an untreated primary infection. There is lymphatic obstruction due to chronic inflammation and fibrosis. This results in genital lymphoedema and inflammation, which cause ulceration and chronic granulomatous fibrosis, resulting in esthiomene in women and elephantiasis in men.

The given image shows esthiomene, a feature of lymphogranuloma venereum:

Other options: 

Option B: HSV-2 infection presents with macular or papular vesicles that progress to vesicles and pustules lasting for up to 3 weeks. It is associated with painful lymphadenopathy.

Option C: The incubation period for chancroid is 3–10 days. The patient presents with painful deep ulcers and tender lymphadenopathy. The primary lesion begins as a painful papule that undergoes central necrosis to form painful, non-indurated ulcers with undermined edges. Kissing ulcers due to autoinoculation may also be present.

Option D: Granuloma inguinale, or donovanosis presents with a painless papule that forms a beefy red ulcer with no lymphadenopathy. The incubation period is 8–80 days.

questions.text: All of the following increases during normal pregnancy except:
questions.solution:
Clotting factors XI and XIII are slightly decreased during normal pregnancy.

Pregnancy is a hypercoagulable state. Clotting factors X, IX, VIII, VII, and I increase in pregnancy whereas levels of II, V, and XII are either unchanged or mildly increased. Clotting factors XI and XIII are slightly decreased.

During normal pregnancy, blood volume, plasma volume, red cell volume, total hemoglobin, total plasma protein, globulin, ESR, fibrinogen, clotting factors X, IX, VIII, VII, I, II, V, and XII are increased.

Hematocrit, plasma protein concentration, the viscosity of blood, albumin,  albumin:globulin ratio, platelets, fibrinolytic activity, clotting factors XI and XIII are decreased.

questions.text: Pepsinogen is activated by _________
questions.solution:
Pepsinogen is activated to pepsin by hydrochloric acid.

When pepsinogen is secreted, it has no digestive activity. When it comes in contact with hydrochloric acid, it is activated to form active pepsin. Pepsin is an active proteolytic enzyme at an optimum pH of 1.8-3.5 and is inactivated when it mixes with alkaline intestinal secretions.

It is an active proteolytic enzyme in a highly acidic medium optimum pH 1.8 to 3.5, but above a pH of about 5, it has almost no proteolytic activity and becomes completely inactivated in a short time.

Related Pearl: Classification of proteases

questions.text: A patient presents with symptoms of increased lacrimation, salivation, sweating, and urinary incontinence. Which of the following is likely to be responsible for the above symptoms?
questions.solution:
In the clinical scenario, the patient presents with increased lacrimation, salivation, sweating, and urinary incontinence which are muscarinic symptoms, likely due to pesticide(organophosphorus compounds) poisoning. 

Organophosphorus compounds are constituents of pesticides. They block the acetylcholinesterase thereby causing persistent parasympathetic muscarinic and nicotinic receptors activation resulting in the symptoms. They can be absorbed through the skin, mucosa, or gastrointestinal tract.

Four clinical syndromes are identified with respect to organophosphate exposure. They include: 

  • Acute poisoning - This results in CNS, muscarinic, nicotinic, and somatic motor manifestations.
  • Intermediate syndrome -  Usually observed 1-5 days after organophosphate exposure. It is characterized by paralysis of neck flexors, muscles innervated by cranial nerves, proximal limb muscles, and respiratory muscles.
  • Chronic toxicity - It is seen primarily in agricultural workers with daily exposure. It manifests as symmetrical sensorimotor axonopathy.
  • Organophosphate-induced delayed neuropathy - Characterized by cognitive dysfunction, extrapyramidal symptoms, and peripheral neuropathy. It can lead to flaccid paralysis and muscle wasting

A diagnosis can be made by measuring the pseudocholinesterase levels in RBC, which if less than 50%, confirms the diagnosis. Treatment involves the administration of atropine.  

Postmortem appearances - Congestion and frothy hemorrhagic exudate is seen in respiratory passages. Stomach contents smell of kerosene.

Other options: 

Option A: Arsenic clinical features can be divided into fulminant type, gastrointestinal type, or narcotic form. The fulminant type is characterized by death due to shock and peripheral vascular failure. The gastrointestinal type is a common form and is similar to food poisoning, akin to cholera. The narcotic form is characterized by giddiness, muscle tenderness, coma, and death.

Option B: Strychnine(spinal poison) consumption is responsible for opisthotonus, emprosthotonus, and pleurosthotonus. These symptoms occur due to convulsions and muscle rigidity caused by action on the spinal reflex centres. Risus sardonicus, where the jaws and facial muscles are contracted and drawn back, may also occur. 

Option D: Aconite(cardiac poison), if swallowed, causes tingling and numbness of the mouth, tongue, and pharynx. Salivation, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhoea then follow, and subsequently, the patient would develop dry mouth, thirst, and dysphagia. Paresthesia, ataxia, slurred speech, and muscle twitching. Hypotension and cardiac arrhythmia with AV block occur.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman whose mother is a known case of breast cancer undergoes a mammography every six months. The time advantage the woman achieves by doing so if diagnosed with breast cancer is represented by which of the following intervals in the given image?
questions.solution:
The advantage gained by screening is the lead time which is represented by the time period between 1 to 3.

Screening is the search for unrecognized diseases or defects in apparently healthy individuals by means of rapidly applicable tests or procedures. It must be done in conditions where there is a considerable time lag between the onset of the disease and the usual time of diagnosis (point 3 in the image). This ensures the success of any treatment in reversing the disease process. 

The time difference between the first possible point of diagnosis and the critical point of diagnosis is called screening time which is represented by the time interval 1 to 2 in the above image. 

The final critical point (point 2 in the image) is the stage beyond which treatment would be unsuccessful or there would be permanent damage.

Related Pearl: Lead Time in Screening

Lead time is the period between the first possible time of detection and the usual time of diagnosis.

Lead time is the advantage gained by screening. It helps in the early diagnosis and treatment of disease. Early treatment reduces the severity by reversing the disease process.

questions.text:
A patient who sustained a tibial fracture was managed conservatively with a plaster cast. A few days later, he presents with complaints of pain and paresthesia in the affected limb. On examination, severe pain was elicited on passive stretching. Which of the following statements is/are true regarding this condition?
  1. Fasciotomy is done if the differential pressure is less than 30 mmHg
  2. The earliest symptom to develop is paresthesia
  3. The fractures of the elbow and forearm are at high risk
  4. Paralysis of the muscle group is a late sign
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation is suggestive of acute compartment syndrome and the true statements regarding this condition are 1, 3, and 4. Statement 2 is false because the earliest symptom to develop is pain and not paresthesia. 

Acute compartment syndrome can be defined as the elevation of intra-compartmental pressure that will cause tissue ischemia and necrosis without decompression. This occurs because increased pressure within a closed space in the body leads to a critical reduction of blood flow to the tissues.

The classic features of acute compartment syndrome include the 5 P's:

  • Pain is the first symptom of acute compartment syndrome. It can be elicited on passive stretching of the muscles.
  • Paresthesia occurs due to the compression of nerves in the compartment and indicates nerve ischemia.
  • Pallor occurs due to ischemia.
  • Paralysis of muscle groups in the compartment is a late sign.
  • Pulselessness is usually not seen in the early stages unless there is a major arterial injury. If pulses are absent, arteriography is indicated. 

The injuries that are at high risk of developing acute compartment syndrome are the fractures of the elbow, forearm, proximal third of the tibia, and multiple fractures of the hand and foot. Other high-risk injuries are crush injuries and circumferential burns.

The intra-compartmental pressure (ICP) is measured using a split catheter introduced into the compartment. Earlier, the ICP values alone were used to determine the critical threshold for compartment syndrome. However, it was noted that different individuals had different levels of tolerance for raised ICP. Therefore, differential pressure is used now to determine the need for decompression.

Differential pressure (ΔP) is the difference between diastolic pressure and compartment pressure. When the ΔP is less than 30 mm Hg, the perfusion from blood vessels to the tissues is impaired. Hence, immediate compartment decompression/ fasciotomy is indicated.

All the dressings, bandages, and cast on the affected limb are removed and the limb is nursed flat. 

Fasciotomy wounds are left open. After 2 days, if there is necrosis, debridement is done. If the wounds are healthy, they can be sutured without tension. Alternatively, skin grafting can be done.

Related Pearl: Acute Compartment and Crush Syndromes

1. Acute Compartment Syndrome

Acute compartment syndrome is an elevation of the intracompartmental pressure (ICP) which increases the risk for tissue ischemia and necrosis.

Causes: Fractures (70%) and severe soft tissue injuries (30%). Common fractures causing compartment syndrome include tibial diaphyseal (most common), distal radius, and forearm fractures. 

Pathology: Increased pressure in one of the osseofascial compartments due to bleeding, oedema or inflammation. A vicious cycle of ischemia → edema→ ischemia leading to necrosis of the muscles and nerves within the compartment in 6 hours or less. 

Clinical features: Five Ps: Pain, Paraesthesia, Pallor, Paralysis and Pulselessness. 

Management: Fasciotomy to decompress the threatened compartment if the differential pressure (ΔP) goes less than or equal to 30 mmHg. 

 

2. Crush Syndrome 

Crush syndrome is the systemic manifestation of muscle necrosis. It is commonly caused due to prolonged external compression of an extremity. 

Causes: Crush injuries sustained during motor vehicle accidents, earthquakes, mining and other occupational accidents.

Pathology: Underperfusion of muscle causes myonecrosis. When the limb is freed, there is a release of toxic metabolites causing reperfusion injury. Reactive oxygen metabolites create further tissue injury. Free myoglobin can get precipitated in the renal glomeruli. 

Clinical features: The affected limb is pulseless, red, swollen and blistered. Sensation and muscle power may be lost. There can be signs of impaired renal function, metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia and hypocalcaemia.

Management: Encouraging high urine output, alkalization of the urine, hemofiltration, radical excision of dead muscles, fasciotomy if there is compartment syndrome.

questions.text: A female patient presents with multiple itchy hypopigmented skin lesions. Examination findings are shown in the image given below. What is the most likely causative agent of the suspected condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the image showing multiple hypopigmented macules and patches on the chest strongly suggest tinea versicolor or pityriasis versicolor. The most likely causative agent are the Malassezia species.  

Malassezia species that are commonly involved in Tinea versicolor:

  • Malassezia globosa
  • Malassezia sympodialis
  • Malassezia furfur

Malassezia species are lipophilic fungi. They cause the degradation of lipid-producing acids like azelaic acid that inhibit tyrosinase, resulting in hypopigmented patches. 

Clinically, tinea versicolor presents with hypopigmented patches or hyperpigmented or reddish patches due to inflammation. It commonly affects the upper trunk, upper arms, neck, and abdomen. They may be mildly itchy and have fine scales. 

Lesions fluoresce under Wood’s lamp. On potassium hydroxide (KOH) mount and microscopy the Malassezia species appear as short unbranched, non-pigmented hyphae and spherical cells. This is also called the spaghetti and meatballs or bananas and grapes appearance. 

Treatment involves selenium sulfide, topical or oral azoles. 

Other options:

Option A: Piedraia hortae is a non-pathogenic opportunist that infects human hair causing black piedra. It is characterized by dark, hardened nodules firmly attached to the hair.

Option B: Exophiala werneckii/ Hortaea werneckii/ Phaeoannellomyces werneckii/ Cladosporium werneckii cause tinea nigra–gray to black non-inflammatory, non-scaling, well-demarcated macular lesions usually on the palm.

Option D: Microsporum causes dermatophytosis/ tinea/ ringworm.

questions.text: All the given statements about phenytoin are true except:

choices.text: Avoid phenytoin in females on oral contraceptives
Phenytoin is useful in absence seizures
Vitamin K and D are used to treat osteomalacia of phenytoin

questions.solution:
Phenytoin is effective in all types of focal and generalized tonic-clonic seizures but is not useful in absence seizures. 

Pharmacokinetics: Phenytoin is available in oral, intramuscular, and intravenous formulations. It follows mixed order/saturation kinetics i.e., at low serum concentration, it follows first-order kinetics and as serum concentration increases, it changes to zero-order kinetics.

Phenytoin is a CYP enzyme inducer that leads to increased degradation of drugs such as oral contraceptive pills and leads to unplanned pregnancies.

Mechanism of action: Phenytoin slows the recovery of Na+ channels from inactivation thus decreasing the conduction of action potential.

The therapeutic concentration of phenytoin- 10-20 μgm/ml.

Therapeutic uses:

  • Focal seizures
  • Generalized tonic-clonic seizures
  • Status epilepticus
  • Digoxin induced ventricular arrhythmia
  • Trigeminal neuralgia

It is not useful in absence seizures, myoclonic epilepsy, and Dravet syndrome.

Side effects of phenytoin include:

  • Hirsutism
  • Gingival hyperplasia
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Hypersensitivity reactions
  • Osteomalacia (requires both Vitamin D and K for treatment)
  • Megaloblastic anemia
  • Fetal hydantoin syndrome (hypoplastic phalanges, cleft palate, hare lip, microcephaly)
  • Purple glove syndrome

Dose-related toxicity of phenytoin causes ataxia, vertigo, diplopia, and nystagmus.

Phenytoin increases the metabolism of vitamin K and decreases the vitamin-k dependant proteins required for the normal Ca2+ metabolism of bone. Hence vitamin K is required along with vitamin D for the treatment of osteomalacia.

A better alternative for IV phenytoin:

Instead of phenytoin, IV fosphenytoin is preferred in the management of status epilepticus. It is a pro-drug and is rapidly converted to phenytoin. Fosphenytoin decreases the incidence of purple glove syndrome.

Purple glove syndrome

The flowchart shown below summarizes the management of status epilepticus. 

Related Pearl: Important Adverse Effects of Anti-epileptic Drugs

Antiepileptic drugs

Phenytoin Gum hyperplasia, hirsutism, osteomalacia, ataxia
