questions.text: A child was weaned off of breastmilk by 3 months of age which caused severe malnutrition and recurrent infections. This falls under which ecological factor of malnutrition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario showing early curtailment of breastfeeding causing malnutrition is one example of child-rearing practices that leads to malnutrition.

Ecology of Malnutrition :

The ecological factors related to malnutrition as follows 

  1. Conditioning influences: A conditioning factor that plays a huge role in malnutrition is infectious diseases which causes a vicious cycle where infections cause malnutrition which in turn causes minor childhood ailments. Diarrhoeal diseases, intestinal parasites, measles, whooping cough, malaria, tuberculosis contributes significantly to malnutrition. The occurrence of infections are largely based on the environmental conditions that the child is exposed to.
  2. Cultural influences: Poor diets as a result of cultural and regional influences also play a role in malnutrition. They are as follows with an example for each:
    • Food habits, traditions, customs, beliefs and attitudes: Rice and wheat are largely staple in India. Papaya is avoided as it is thought to cause abortion.
    • Religion: Hindus do not eat beef and Muslims do not eat pork.
    • Food fads: Personal likes and dislikes to a certain group of foods.
    • Cooking practices: Prolonged boiling of cereals in open pans which leads to a loss of nutritive value
    • Child-rearing practices: Premature curtailment of breastfeeding
  3. Socio-economic factors: Poverty plays a huge role in causing malnutrition. This is usually a result of ignorance, insufficient education, lack of knowledge regarding the nutritive value of foods, inadequate sanitary environment, large family size, etc. which affects the quality of life.
  4. Food production: The amount of food produced is directly proportional to the amount of food consumed. Developed countries have 5.8 hectares of arable land compared to the 0.6 hectares of land per Indian. Even distribution of food among all sectors of society is also a factor.
  5. Health and other services: Remedial actions that can be taken by the health sector to reduce malnutrition are as follows - 
    • Nutritional surveillance - Continuous monitoring of factors that affect nutrition; groups affected are identified.
    • Nutritional rehabilitation - Urgent care for individuals suffering from severe malnutrition.
    • Nutrition supplementation - Supplementary feeds for mothers and children
    • Health education - Health education programmes to increase awareness about malnutrition and nutrition value of food.

questions.text: A young woman comes to the Suraksha clinic of the local primary health center. She is examined and the yellow kit is prescribed to her as treatment. Which of the following symptoms did she most likely present with?
questions.solution:
Lower abdominal pain is the most likely presenting symptom in the patient. 

The National AIDS Control Organisation (NACO) has started the Suraksha clinic to deal with sexually transmitted infections (STI) and reproductive tract infections (RTI). Pre-packed STI/RTI color-coded kits are supplied through STI/RTI clinics free of cost. The kits are obtained centrally and then supplied to all state AIDS control societies.

Kit 1
(Grey)

Urethral discharge

Cervical discharge

Painful scrotal swelling
Kit 2 (Green) Vaginal discharge / Vaginitis
Kit 3 (White) Non-herpetic genital ulcers

Kit 4
(Blue)

Non-herpetic genital ulcers if allergic to penicillin

Kit 5
(Red)

 Herpetic genital ulcers
Kit 6 (Yellow) Lower abdominal pain

Kit 7
(Black)

 Inguinal bubo

Kit 8

(Brown)

 Anorectal discharge syndrome

Other symptoms seen in the patients prescribed with the yellow kit are: 

  • Fever
  • Vaginal Discharge
  • Menstrual irregularities (heavy, irregular vaginal bleeding)
  • Dysmenorrhoea, dyspareunia, dysuria and tenesmus
  • Lower backache
  • Cervical motion tenderness

The kit contains cefixime 400 mg tablet to have immediately, metronidazole 400 mg tablet, and doxycycline 100 mg tablet to have twice a day for 14 days. Along with this, the male partner should be treated with kit 1. 

Lower abdominal pain should be followed up on the 3rd, 7rd, and 14th day and a referral should be made if symptoms persist.

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man comes to the OPD and tells you that the lesion (image given below) in his scalp has increased in size in the last few days and the appearance of small bleeding points on scratching. He gives a history of excessive smoking owing to emotional stress. He is a known hypertensive on atenolol. He has been having severe URTI for which he was prescribed amoxicillin 4 days ago. Which among the following factors does not contribute to the exacerbation of the condition?

URTI: Upper respiratory tract infection
questions.solution:
Amoxicillin (Option D) does not contribute to the exacerbation of the condition shown in the image ie. psoriasis. The other options - emotional stress, smoking, and atenolol are indicated in exacerbation of the condition. 

Psoriasis is a common, chronic, immune-mediated inflammatory condition in which multiple genetic and environmental factors may lead to the formation of erythematous plaques with silvery-white scales. Various factors contribute to the exacerbation of psoriasis.

Drugs inducing/exacerbating psoriasis:

  • Beta-blockers
  • Synthetic antimalarials
  • NSAIDS
  • Lithium
  • ACE inhibitors & angiotensin receptor blockers
  • Interferon alpha
  • Tetracycline
  • Terbinafine
  • Gemfibrozil

Amoxicillin and levothyroxine do not induce psoriasis. 

Other environmental and immunological factors that may trigger psoriasis are:

  • Infections- beta-hemolytic streptococci can trigger guttate psoriasis
  • Alcohol misuse and smoking
  • Emotional stress
  • Trauma - Koebner phenomenon
  • Winter 
  • Sunlight

questions.text: A child born with a rare genetic disorder presented with failure to thrive and susceptibility to recurrent pyogenic, viral, and fungal infections. His blood reports showed lymphopenia and a diagnosis of SCID was suspected. He was advised to stay in a protective 'bubble' as shown in the image below. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the disease in question?

choices.text: The X-linked form is due to the deficiency of  adenosine deaminase
Defective humoral and cell-mediated immune responses

questions.solution:
X-linked SCID is the most common form where there is a mutation in the common γ-chain (γc) subunit of cytokine receptors. The given clinical scenario and the image of a child in a protective bubble (Bubble boy disease) are suggestive of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). 

 Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) is characterized by:

  • Defects in both humoral and cell-mediated immune responses.
  • Persons with SCID are extremely susceptible to recurrent, severe infections by a wide range of pathogens, including Candida albicans, Pneumocystis jirovecii, Pseudomonas species, cytomegalovirus, varicella, and a host of other bacteria.
  • Genes involved are JAK3, RAG1, and IL-7R.

Types of SCID:

X-linked SCID

  • The most common form, accounting for 50% to 60% of cases, is X-linked, and hence, SCID is more common in boys than in girls.
  • The genetic defect in the X-linked form is a mutation in the common γ-chain (γc) subunit of cytokine receptors.
  • The thymus contains lobules of undifferentiated epithelial cells resembling fetal thymus.

Autosomal recessive

  • The most common cause of autosomal-recessive SCID is a deficiency of adenosine deaminase (ADA) enzyme.
  • In SCID caused by ADA deficiency, remnants of Hassall’s corpuscles can be found.

It can be associated with a defective non-homologous end-joining (NHEJ). NHEJ is a predominant pathway for DNA double-stranded break repair. NHEJ deficiency confers (severe) combined immunodeficiency due to a failure to carry out V(D)J recombination efficiently. NHEJ also functions in class switch recombination, another step enhancing T and B cell diversity.

Note:

The deficiency of adenosine deaminase enzyme was the first pathophysiologic condition to be treated by gene therapy. In1990, Dr. William French Anderson introduced a new copy of this gene, which was carried on a retroviral vector, into a 4-year-old girl suffering from severe combined immunodeficiency (bubble boy disease).

questions.text: A 33-year-old male patient presents with severe malnutrition and diarrhea. His medical history states that he has undergone massive small bowel resection and has only 45 cm of his small bowel remaining. Parenteral nutrition is started but he is soon diagnosed with refeeding syndrome. Which of the following electrolyte abnormalities are expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes refeeding syndrome and the electrolyte abnormalities seen are hypophosphatemia, hypomagnesemia, hypocalcemia, hypernatremia, and hypokalemia.

Refeeding syndrome is a potentially fatal condition that may occur due to rapid and excessive feeding of patients with severe underlying malnutrition due to starvation, alcoholism, delayed nutritional support, anorexia nervosa, or massive weight loss in obese patients. It can occur with either enteral or parenteral nutrition but is more common with the latter.

With refeeding, a shift in metabolism from fat to carbohydrate substrate stimulates insulin release, which results in the cellular uptake of electrolytes, particularly phosphate, magnesium, potassium, and calcium. The electrolyte disturbances seen in refeeding syndrome include:

  • Hypophosphatemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hypernatremia
  • Hypokalemia

However, severe hyperglycemia may result from blunted basal insulin secretion.

These electrolyte disorders can result in altered myocardial function, arrhythmias, deteriorating respiratory function, liver dysfunction, seizures, confusion, coma, tetany, and death.

Prevention of refeeding involves correction of fluid and electrolyte imbalance, administering thiamine and increasing calorie intake gradually.

questions.text: Identify the drug which causes this adverse effect ________
questions.solution:
Ergotamine causes occlusion of peripheral blood vessels in susceptible persons. It acts as a partial agonist and antagonist at α adrenoreceptors and all subtypes of 5HT1 and 5HT2 serotonin receptors.

The numbness progressing to bluish discoloration of the fingers are the initial signs of occlusion. It can lead to gangrene if left untreated eventually leading to amputation. Nausea and vomiting, as well as tingling and numbness (paresthesia), are common adverse effects of ergotamine.

Contraindications for ergotamine: 

  • Peripheral vascular disease
  • Coronary artery disease
  • Uncontrolled hypertension
  • Fever and/or sepsis
  • Pregnancy
  • Within 24 hours of using triptans

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman who has completed her family wants to undergo a permanent method of sterilization. She wants to know about the Essure device which is the latest method of hysteroscopic sterilisation.  What is the mechanism of action of this form of sterilization?

choices.text: Local growth of fibrous tissue occluding the fallopian tube
Local spermicidal action of titanium alloy

questions.solution:
The Essure permanent device is the latest method of hysteroscopic sterilization. The mechanism of action is the local growth of fibrous tissue responsible for the occlusion of the fallopian tube. This is an irreversible and permanent technique. 

Essure is done through the hysteroscopic method and so the abdominal scar is avoided. It involves a dynamically expanding micro-inserter consisting of two coils – an inner coil made of flexible stainless steel and an outer coil made of nickel-titanium alloy (nitinol). The inner coil contains polyethylene terephthalate (PET) fibers, which stimulate the growth of harmless local fibrous tissue, leading to the blockage of the fallopian tube. A guidewire helps to guide the device into the fallopian tube. After three months, a hysterosalpingography is conducted to confirm the blockage of the fallopian tube.

Disadvantages:

  • Hysteroscopy is required
  • Cost and expertise required
  • Permanent method
  • HSG to confirm blockage
  • Bilateral insertion is difficult due to spasms in 15% of cases
  • Tuboplasty for reversal is not possible
  • Perforation of the tube

Advantage:

No abdominal scar and can be done under local anesthesia.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man has been diagnosed with oropharyngeal carcinoma. Which of the following group of lymph nodes does the sentinel  node belong to?
questions.solution:
The jugulodigastric node is the sentinel lymph node and belongs to the level 2 group of lymph nodes.

This is the node enlarged in both tonsillitis and base of tongue carcinoma as lymphatics from the oropharynx drain into the upper jugular chain.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient with adenocarcinoma of the esophagus has finished his second round of chemotherapy. He was having severe bouts of vomiting after the first round of chemotherapy which was not controlled by any drug. What is the mechanism of the drug to be prescribed for refractory chemotherapy-induced vomiting?
questions.solution:
The drugs prescribed in refractory chemotherapy-induced vomiting (CINV) are cannabinoid-1 receptor agonists. Dronabinol and nabilone are examples of these drugs.

Cannabinoid-1 (CB1) receptor agonists act on the CB1 receptors on neurons and around the emetic center. Dronabinol or delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol is a natural cannabinoid obtained from the marijuana plant and nabilone is a synthetic cannabinoid. Dronabinol can also be used to stimulate appetite in AIDS-associated anorexia.

Refractory CINV refers to vomiting that occurs with subsequent chemotherapy cycles when prophylactic antiemetics were ineffective in previous cycles.

Acute CINV is the occurrence of nausea and vomiting within a few minutes to several hours after chemotherapy administration and typically resolves within 24 hours.

Delayed CINV is the occurrence of nausea and vomiting after 24 hours of chemotherapy administration and may last for 6-7 days.

Other options:

Option B: 5HT3 antagonists are the most effective for acute CINV and post-operative nausea and vomiting. The drugs used are ondansetron, granisetron, dolasetron, and palonosetron. Palonosetron is the long-acting drug in this group. These drugs are effective in acute CINV. However, palonosetron when combined with neurokinase-1 antagonist netupitant is effective in late CINV as well. These drugs are available as tablets, oral solutions and,  intravenous formulations. Granisetron is available as a transdermal patch.

Option C: Neurokinase-1 receptor (neuropeptide substance-P receptor) antagonists are effective in delayed CINV. the drugs in this group are aprepitant, fosaprepitant, rolapitant and netupitant.

Option D: Dopamine-2 receptor antagonists act at D-2 receptors in the chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ), reducing the excitatory neurotransmitter release. Metoclopramide (effective in delayed emesis) and promethazine (not effective in CINV) are examples. The main adverse effects of these drugs are extrapyramidal reactions like dystonia, drug-induced Parkinson's disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is a life-threatening complication that should be monitored in the first 24 hours in a patient who underwent thyroidectomy?
questions.solution:
The life-threatening complication that should be monitored in the first 24 hours after surgery is hematoma formation.

Hematoma formation in the neck postoperatively is most commonly seen in the first 6 hours and in 20 percent of individuals between 6-24 hours. The risk factors for this are male sex, increasing age, bilateral surgery, Grave's disease, and anticoagulation.

The manifestations are due to compression on the trachea leading to airway compromise. It includes pain, oozing from the incision, ecchymosis, swelling, and, stridor. 

Avoiding tight closure of strap muscles will allow the hematoma to drain into the surrounding tissue. 

If a hematoma occurs:

  • The incision holding the three layers of the thyroidectomy bed (skin, platysma, and strap muscles) must be opened to allow for maximal decompression.
  • Endotracheal intubation is performed to maintain airway patency. 

Other options: 

Option A: Unilateral superior laryngeal nerve can occur as a complication of thyroid surgery. This will lead to a change in voice power and range. It is not life-threatening. 

Option B: Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve can also be injured in thyroid surgery. They are asymptomatic but in a few may cause hoarseness of voice and don't need any treatment.

Option D: Parathyroid insufficiency occurs due to the removal of the parathyroids or infarction due to damage to the parathyroid end arteries. Patients usually present 2-5 days after the surgery with hypocalcemia. 

Note: Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy can also occur postoperatively. It causes dyspnoea and stridor but the voice is good. These cases required emergency tracheostomy.

Related Pearl: Positions of the Vocal Cord

questions.text: Which layer of the epidermis do keratinocytes originate from?
questions.solution:
Keratinocytes are derived from stem cells present in the stratum basale, which is marked as layer "4" in the given image.

The epidermis consists of two types of cells: keratinocytes (predominant) and non-keratinocytes (melanocytes, dendritic cells of Langerhans, Merkel cells).

The image shows the histological appearance of the epidermis of the skin. The structures marked are as follows:

  • 1 - Stratum corneum
  • 2 - Stratum granulosum
  • 3 - Stratum spinosum
  • 4 - Stratum basale

The above 4 layers are present in the thin hairy skin. 

The thick glabrous skin over the palms and the soles alone contains a clear homogenous 5th layer between the stratum corneum and stratum granulosum, called the stratum lucidum. 

The epidermis of the skin is made of stratified squamous keratinized epithelium and consists of the following layers. 

  • Stratum basale - It is the deepest layer of the epidermis and is made of a single layer of columnar cells that rest on a basal lamina. It contains stem cells that undergo mitosis to give rise to keratinocytes and is also called stratum germinativum. 
  • Stratum spinosum - Contains several layers of polygonal keratinocytes. These cells are connected to each other with the help of desmosomes. This is also called as prickle cell layer or Malpighian layer.
  • Stratum granulosum - These are made up of flattened cells that have deeply staining granules in their cytoplasm. They are characterized by the presence of deeply staining keratohyalin granules in the cytoplasm. The cells of this layer have Golgi-derived lamellar granules that undergo exocytosis and form a lipid-rich impermeable layer around the cells. This material plays a major role in the skin barrier against water loss.
  • Stratum lucidum - It lies superficial to the stratum granulosum. The cell boundaries are indistinct and this layer appears homogenous.
  • Stratum corneum - It is the most superficial layer of the epidermis. This layer is acellular. It is made up of flattened scale-like elements (squames) containing keratin filaments within a protein. The squames are held together by a glue-like material that contains lipids and carbohydrates. This layer is highly resistant to permeation by water due to its high water content.

The following image shows the layers of the epidermis.

Related Pearl: Cells of the epidermis

Cells of the epidermis Origin and location Characteristic features
Keratino-cytes

Present in- All Layers of Epidermis (90-95% of all epidermal cells)

Derived from-Ectoderm

Differentiated in situ

 Rich in the intermediate filaments called keratin that provides mechanical strength to the cell. The keratinocytes in basal layer divide and generate the upper layers. 
Melano-cytes

Present in- Stratum basale

Derived from-Neural Crest

Migrate to the epidermis

 Synthesize melanin in granules called melanosomes that is transferred to keratinocytes of epidermis through elongated processes called dendrites. Each melanocyte transfers melanosomes to 36 keratinocytes. This is called as Epidermal melanin unit (36K:1M)   

Merkel   cells

Present in-Stratum basale (RETE RIDGES)

Derived from-Ectoderm/ Neural Crest

Differentiates in-situ

 Also known as Touch cells or Haascheiban cells. They are Type 1 slow adapting touch receptors.  
Langerhans cells

Present in-Stratum spinosum

Derived from- Bone Marrow

Migrate to Epidermis

 They are dendritic Antigen Presenting Cells (APCs).   Characterized by presence of rod shaped or Tennis Racket shaped granules called Birbeck granules which are seen on electron microscopy.   Immunohistochemical Markers are CD1a, CD207(Langerin) and S100.

questions.text: An ENT surgeon is performing mastoid surgery on a patient through an endaural approach. The surgeon would cut through which of the following parts of pinna for this procedure?
questions.solution:
The area between the tragus and crux of the helix is called the incisura terminalis (marked 2). The mastoid is endaurally approached through this structure as it is devoid of cartilage. 

The parts of the pinna are depicted in the image below. 

 

The ear can be surgically approached in three ways - endomeatal, endaural, and postaural approaches.

The mastoid is endaurally approached through Lempert's incision. 

Lempert I - It is a semicircular incision made from the 12 o'clock to 6 o'clock position in the posterior meatal wall at the bony-cartilaginous junction.

Lempert II - Starts from the first incision at 12 o'clock and passes through the incisura terminalis and does not cut the cartilage. 

It is used for :

  • Excision of osteomas or exostosis of the ear canal
  • Large tympanic membrane perforations
  • Attic cholesteatomas
  • Modified radical mastoidectomy

 

In endomeatal or transcanal approach Rosen’s incision is used. It is used for stapedectomy, exploratory tympanotomy to find the cause of conductive hearing loss, inlay myringoplasty, and ossicular reconstruction.

It consists of two parts:

  • A small vertical incision at 12 o’clock position near the annulus.
  • A curvilinear incision starting at 6 o’clock position to meet the first incision in the posterosuperior region of the canals, 5–7 mm away from the annulus.

 

Wilde’s incision is used in postaural approach.

  • It starts at the highest attachment of the pinna and follows the curve of retroauricular groove, lying 1 cm behind it. The incision ends at the mastoid tip.

questions.text: A forensics ballistics expert is examining the entrance wound of a gunshot victim. All of the following will be the traits of this firearm injury, except for _______.

choices.text: Edges are everted, puckered or torn
Burning and tattooing around the wound
Size is smaller than the diameter of the bullet

questions.solution:
All the given options are traits of an entrance wound of a firearm injury, except for everted, puckered, or torn edges which is a trait of exit wounds of firearm injuries. In an entrance wound, the edges are inverted with a small central defect.

The following table summarises the traits and comparison between entrance wound and exit wound of firearm injuries:

Traits Entrance wound Exit wound

Burning, blackening, tattooing May be seen around the wound. Absent
Bleeding Less More
Fat Does not protrude except for contact shots May protrude
Lead ring/ Metal ring May be seen around the wound by radiological examination Absent

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy presented with weakness, fatigue, excessive thirst, and urination. His blood pressure was 100/76 mmHg. His lab parameters are given below. What is the diagnosis?

Urine transtubular potassium gradient (TTKG) - 8 (increased)

Urine calcium- increased

ABG analysis - metabolic alkalosis

Serum potassium - decreased (3.2 mmol/L)

Serum magnesium - decreased (0.3 mmol/L)
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of the diagnosis of Bartter syndrome.

Bartter syndrome is characterized by hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypomagnesemia (normal - 0.5-1 mmol/kg) and hypercalciuria with normal blood pressure. The transtubular potassium gradient (TTKG) is a physiologically based clinical test to study the renal excretion of potassium. A TTKG >4 in a patient with hypokalemia suggests excessive urinary losses of K+. 

Bartter syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder occurring due to defects in various genes involved in the regulated Na+, K+, and Cl– transport by the thick ascending loop of Henle (TALH). Each genetic defect is a subtype of Bartter syndrome. Type 3 Bartter, also known as classical Bartter is due to loss of function in CLCKNB (Chloride Voltage-Gated Channel Kb).

A defect in the Na+/K+/Cl- channel impairs the transport functions of the TALH resulting in the following features:

  • Polyuria and polydipsia
  • Marked activation of RAAS leading to increased renal loss of potassium
  • Hypokalemia
  • Metabolic alkalosis due to bicarbonate retention
  • Hypomagnesemia in 20% of patients
  • Hypocalcemia and hypercalciuria
  • Normotensive

Antenal presentation of Bartter syndrome is characterized by polyhydramnios, premature birth, polyuria, and salt loss. Antenatal diagnosis can be made by elevated levels of chloride and aldosterone in the amniotic fluid. Antenatal Bartter can be managed by intravenous saline infusion to prevent dehydration and even death. Cyclooxygenase inhibitors are also useful in antenatal Bartter to reduce polyuria and salt wasting.

Other options:

Option A- Gitelman syndrome is due to a loss of function mutation in the thiazide sensitive Na+-Cl– cotransporter of the Distal convoluted tubule. It is characterized by hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypomagnesemia and hypocalciuria with normal blood pressure.

Option B: EAST syndrome is characterized by epilepsy, ataxia, sensorineural deafness, and tubulopathy. Biochemical abnormality is similar to Gitelman syndrome.

Option D: Liddle syndrome is due to direct increased activation of the epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) on the principal cells. Liddle's also causes hypokalemia, hypercalciuria but is characterized by severe hypertension.

Related Pearl: Renal Tubular Syndromes

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presented with acute dyspnea, tachypnea, and high grade fever. His SpO2 was 88%. His chest X-ray findings are shown below. Which of the following is less likely to be considered as a differential?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with the chest X-ray finding, is suggestive of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and tuberculosis is less likely to be a causative disease.

Acute respiratory distress syndrome is a clinical syndrome characterised by acute onset, severe dyspnea, tachypnea, hypoxemia, and pulmonary infiltrates leading to respiratory failure. Etiological factors can be divided into direct and indirect causes of lung injury as follows:

  • Direct lung injury-
    • Pneumonia
    • Aspiration of gastric contents
    • Near drowning
    • Toxic inhalation injury
    • Pulmonary contusion.
    • COVID-19
  • Indirect lung injury-
    • Sepsis
    • Severe trauma like burns, flail chest, pulmonary contusions, head trauma, multiple bone fractures
    • Transfusions
    • Drug overdose
    • Multiple transfusions
    • Pancreatitis
    • Drug overdose.

There are three stages in the development of ARDS:

  1. Exudative phase: Occurs for the first seven days of the illness. The alveolar-capillary endothelial cells and type I pneumocytes are injured, with a breach in the tight alveolar barrier. Proinflammatory cytokines like IL-8, IL-1, TNF-α, and LT-B4 lead to the recruitment of neutrophils and the development of a hyaline membrane in the alveoli.
  2. Proliferative phase: Occurs from day 7-21. Recovery from mechanical ventilation is seen in most patients. Some patients may develop pulmonary fibrosis in this stage. Histological recovery is seen in this phase with a shift to lymphocyte-predominant infiltrates. Type II pneumocytes proliferate and secrete surfactant with subsequent differentiation to Type I pneumocytes.
  3. Fibrotic phase: Is associated with increased mortality. Extensive alveolar duct and interstitial fibrosis are seen.

Chest X-ray features in ARDS:

Chest x-ray features usually develop 12-24 hours after initial lung insult due to proteinaceous interstitial oedema. A hyaline membrane occurs within one week due to type 1 pneumocyte damage. There are diffuse bilateral coalescent opacities consistent with pulmonary oedema. 

Severity classification of ARDS:

  • Mild: 200 mmHg < Pao2/Fio2 ≤ 300 mmHg
  • Moderate: 100 mmHg < Pao2/Fio2 ≤ 200 mmHg
  • Severe: Pao2/Fio2 ≤ 100 mmHg

Management:

  • Mechanical ventilation with low tidal volume and high PEEP.
  • Prone ventilation
  • Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation
  • Early neuromuscular blockade

Tuberculosis commonly causes respiratory failure in patients with extensive pulmonary parenchymal involvement, but it is an infrequent cause of ARDS.

questions.text: A 36-year-old female patient is in a starved state for the past 36 hours. The glycogen stores in her body have been completely exhausted, and lipolysis has begun to meet the energy requirements. Which of the following enzymes is required for the final step of beta-oxidation?
questions.solution:
Thiolase is the enzyme required for the final step of β-oxidation of fatty acids.

Thiolase (3-ketoacyl-CoA-thiolase) enzyme splits 3-ketoacyl-CoA  at the 2,3-position to form a molecule of acetyl CoA and new acyl-CoA with two carbons shorter than the original acyl-CoA molecule. The acetyl CoA so formed enters the citric acid cycle to eventually form ATP. The new acyl-CoA with two carbons shorter than the original re-enters the β-oxidation pathway.

Thiolase is also involved in ketogenesis, when two acetyl-CoA molecules produced via fatty acid breakdown, condense to form acetoacetyl-CoA by a reversal of the thiolase reaction.

Other options:

Option A -  Thiokinase catalyzes the only energy-requiring step in fatty acid oxidation. In the presence of ATP and coenzyme A, the enzyme acyl-CoA synthetase or thiokinase catalyzes the conversion of a fatty acid to acyl-CoA, the active form of fatty acid for oxidation using one high energy phosphate and forming AMP and PPi.

Option B - Thioesterase is the last enzyme in the fatty acid synthase complex. It catalyzes the final release of the newly formed fatty acid. It is not involved in fatty acid oxidation.

Option D - Thiophorase is also known as a succinyl-CoA-acetoacetate-CoA transferase. This enzyme is involved in keto-lysis in extrahepatic tissues. Acetoacetate is activated to acetoacetyl CoA by thiophorase enzyme. The CoA is transferred from succinyl-CoA to form acetoacetyl- CoA.

                                           Thiophorase
Acetoacetate+Succinyl CoA ------------------> Acetoacetyl CoA + Succinate. 

Related Pearl: Beta-oxidation of Fatty Acids

Note: Carnitine palmitoyltransferase I (CPT1) is also known as carnitine acyltransferase I,

Related Pearl: Types, Location and Properties of Fatty acid oxidation

Types of Oxidation

Location

Properties

Associated Disease

Beta oxidation

Mitochondria

A catabolic process by which two-carbons are cleaved from the fatty acid molecule and released as acetyl CoA starting from the carboxyl end.

The chain is broken between the α(2) and β(3) carbon.

1 round of beta-oxidation yield 1FADH2, 1NADH, and 1 Acetyl CoA.

  

Alpha oxidation

Peroxisome

The presence of the 3-methyl group of phytanic acid prevents degradation by beta-oxidation.

The chain is broken between the terminal carboxyl group and α(2) carbon removing that carbon as CO2. The remaining chain is activated with CoA and then undergoes β-Oxidation.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Classic Refsum's Disease

Defective enzyme- Phytanoyl Coa hydroxylase.

Clinical features include:

Ichthyosis, Retinitis pigmentosa, Decreased vision, Peripheral neuropathy, Ataxia

 

Omega oxidation

Endoplasmic Reticulum

An alternative pathway to beta-oxidation occurs in microsomes.

Involves the oxidation of the ω carbon (terminal methyl group) resulting in dicarboxylic acid.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

  

Peroxisomal Beta oxidation

Peroxisome

Very-long-chain fatty acids undergo preliminary β-oxidation in peroxisomes up to octanoyl CoA. The shortened fatty acids undergo further β-oxidation in the mitochondria.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Zellweger (cerebrohepatorenal) syndrome

A rare inherited absence of peroxisomes in all tissues.

They accumulate C26—C38 polyenoic acids in brain tissue and also exhibit a generalized loss of peroxisomal functions. The disease causes severe neurologic symptoms, and most patients die in the first year of life.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient came to the hospital with a history of headaches, seizures, memory loss, and mood changes.  The given image is obtained by doing an MRI scan. Which of the following drugs is useful in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the MRI scan finding are suggestive of glioblastoma. Temozolomide is used as a first-line agent for the management of glioblastoma. It is used for newly diagnosed cases along with radiotherapy and also used for maintenance therapy.

Temozolomide belongs to the triazene group of alkylating agents and is administered orally. The oral bioavailability of temozolomide is nearly 100%. It forms a methylating metabolite and kills cells in all phases of the cell cycle.

Glioblastoma is the most malignant astrocytic tumor - WHO grade IV. It spreads along the white matter tracts and crosses the midline via the corpus callosum, giving rise to the so-called butterfly glioma. 

Other options:

Option A- Streptozocin belongs to the nitrosourea group of alkylating agents and has a high affinity of islets of Langerhans. It is used in the treatment of pancreatic islet cell carcinoma and carcinoid tumors.

Option C- Ifosfamide belongs to the nitrogen mustard group of alkylating agents and an analog of cyclophosphamide. Ifosfamide is used in germ cell tumors of testes and sarcomas. It has maximum neurotoxicity which can be treated with methylene blue. It has a urothelial damaging capacity like cyclophosphamide which can be treated with MESNA (sodium-2-mercaptoethanol sulfonate).

Option D- Chlorambucil belongs to the nitrogen mustard group of alkylating agents and is an orally administered drug. It is almost exclusively used in the treatment of chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

Related Pearl: Classification of antineoplastic drugs

   Non-cell-cycle specific drugs

Alkylating agents

Nitrogen mustards

  • Cyclophosphamide
  • Ifosfamide

questions.text:
A patient presents to you with a 25-day history of hearing voices that ask him to jump from the 10th floor of his building. He has a labile mood. On further probing, he reveals that he had lost his mother a month back in an accident that happened before his eyes. Which of the following statements is true for his condition?
  1. The diagnosis is schizophrenia
  2. His condition is likely to be brief psychotic disorder
  3. Complete remission usually occurs
  4. Negative symptoms are part of the diagnostic criteria
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with auditory hallucinations in a patient with a history of witnessing a traumatic event is highly suggestive of the diagnosis of brief psychotic disorder.

For a diagnosis of brief psychotic disorder, the symptoms should have lasted for at least a day but less than a month. It should not be associated with a mood disorder, substance abuse disorder, or psychotic disorder due to an underlying medical condition. It may also occur following a traumatic life event. It is commonly seen in women, young people, and those with existing personality disorders. The criteria for diagnosis is the same as that for schizophrenia but without negative symptoms.

Clinical features include delusions, hallucinations, and disorganized speech. At least one of these symptoms of psychosis is required for diagnosis. Other signs like disorganized or catatonic behavior, emotional volatility, bizarre behavior, and screaming may also be seen.

Brief psychotic disorder is classified into the following subtypes:

  • After a stressor
  • Without a stressor
  • Postpartum onset

The diagnosis is usually retrospective, as the diagnosis requires complete remission of symptoms, which usually occurs in a month. There is an eventual complete return to the premorbid level of functioning.

Management includes hospitalization and psychotherapy. The involvement of the family is also recommended. Antipsychotics and benzodiazepines are also used.

Schizophrenia is a disorder characterized by delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, negative symptoms, and catatonic behavior. At least two of the first three symptoms should be present for a duration of one month. Continuous signs of disturbance should be seen for at least 6 months.

Related Pearl: Timeline in psychiatry

Condition Duration
Manic episode At least 1 week
Hypomania At least 4 consecutive days
Major depressive disorder

Lasts 6 to12 months with episodes for 2 or more weeks
Cyclothymia At least 2 years
Dysthymia At least 2 years
Maternal blues Starts 2–3 days after delivery and usually resolves within 10 days
Postpartum mood disturbances Onset within 4 weeks of delivery
Brief psychotic disorder Lasts < 1 month, usually stress-related
Schizophreniform disorder Lasts 1-6 months
Schizophrenia Lasts > 6 months
Schizoaffective disorder Lasts > 2 weeks
Delusional disorder Lasts > 1 month
Panic disorder An episode followed by 1 month of concern of additional attacks 
Specific phobia Lasts > 6 months
Generalized anxiety disorder Lasts > 6 months 
Acute stress disorder Lasts between 3 days and 1 month 
PTSD Lasts > 1 month 
Adjustment disorder

Symptoms occur within 3 months of the stressor and last < 6 months

May last > 6 months in presence of chronic stressor
Bulimia nervosa At least 3 months
Somatic symptom disorder Lasts > 6 months
Separation anxiety disorder Common onset at 7–9 years 
Tourette syndrome

Onset < age 18 years

Tics that persist for > 1 year 
ADHD Symptoms for > 6 months 

Related Pearl: Psychotic disorders

Differential diagnosis of DSM-5 psychotic disorders

Psychotic disorder

 Criteria for diagnosis
Brief psychotic disorder

Sudden onset and a full return to function

Duration: > 1 day and < 1 month
Schizophreniform disorder

Same symptoms as schizophrenia and functional decline not required

Duration: > 1 month & < 6 months
Schizophrenia

Requires functional decline

At least 6 months (includes at least 1 month of active symptoms, can include prodromal and residual periods)
Schizoaffective disorder

With concurrent mood episode. Active-phase symptoms of schizophrenia with at least a 2 weeks of lifetime history of delusions or hallucinations in absence of prominent mood symptoms
Delusional disorder

One or more delusions for > 1 month

No other psychotic symptoms and normal functioning apart from the direct impact of delusions
Shared psychotic disorder (folie a deux)

Development of delusions in a person who is in a close relationship (ex: spouse, child) with someone who has a delusional disorder (the inducer)

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with HIV was brought to the hospital with complaints of persistent diarrhoea and fever for the last month. The examination of the oral cavity was as given below. What is the most probable stage of the disease the child is suffering from?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with HIV, and persistent diarrhea and fever with oral candidiasis (as given in the image) suggests stage 3 of HIV infection. 

Features of Stage 3 of the disease include 

  • Unexplained moderate malnutrition not adequately responding to standard therapy
  • Unexplained persistent diarrhea (14 days or more)
  • Unexplained persistent fever (above 37.6 °C intermittent or constant, for longer than one month)
  • Unexplained anemia (<8 g/dL), neutropenia (<0.5 x 109/L) or chronic thrombocytopenia (<50 × 109/L)
  • Persistent oral candidiasis (after first 6-8 weeks of life)
  • Oral hairy leukoplakia
  • Acute necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis/periodontitis
  • Pulmonary TB/ Lymph node TB
  • Severe recurrent bacterial pneumonia
  • Symptomatic lymphoid interstitial pneumonitis
  • Chronic HIV-associated lung disease including bronchiectasis

Clinical features of HIV infection are highly variable. Initial signs and symptoms are non-specific like lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, recurrent diarrhea, and failure to thrive. The status of the disease may be assessed based on the clinical features and immunological response. 

The diagnosis of HIV infection in babies born to HIV-infected mothers is done by HIV proviral DNA or RNA PCR, HIV culture, or HIV p24 antigen. The national program (Early Infant Diagnosis) now uses HIV total nucleic acid (RNA + proviral DNA) PCR test on dried blood spot samples. All positive tests need to be confirmed with an HIV PCR test on another sample. According to the national AIDS control organization (NACO), an infant born to an HIV-positive mother should be breastfed exclusively or by replacement feeds exclusively for 6 months of age. If exclusive replacement feeding is done, infants should receive ARV prophylaxis with syrup nevirapine or zidovudine, even if the baby is tested negative.

Related Pearl: Clinical stages of HIV in children/ infants

Stage 1

  • Asymptomatic
  • Persistent generalized lymphadenopathy

Stage 2

General-

  • Unexplained persistent hepatosplenomegaly
  • Recurrent or chronic upper respiratory infections (otitis media, otorrhoea, sinusitis, tonsilitis)
  • Fungal nail infections

Oral-

  • Recurrent oral ulcerations
  • Unexplained persistent parotid enlargement
  • Linear gingival erythema

Skin- 

  • Papular pruritic eruptions
  • Extensive wart virus infection
  • Extensive molluscum contagiosum
  • Herpes zoster

Stage 3

General-

  • Unexplained moderate malnutrition not adequately responding to standard therapy
  • Unexplained persistent diarrhea (14 days or more)
  • Unexplained persistent fever (above 37.6 °C intermittent or constant, for longer than one month)
  • Unexplained anemia (<8 g/dL), neutropenia (<0.5 x 109/L) or chronic thrombocytopenia (<50 × 109/L)

Oral-

  • Persistent oral candidiasis (after first 6-8 weeks of life)
  • Oral hairy leukoplakia
  • Acute necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis/periodontitis

Respiratory-

  • Pulmonary TB/ Lymph node TB
  • Severe recurrent bacterial pneumonia
  • Symptomatic lymphoid interstitial pneumonitis
  • Chronic HIV-associated lung disease including bronchiectasis

Stage 4

General-

  • Unexplained severe wasting, stunting or malnutrition not responding to standard therapy
  • Chronic herpes simplex infection; (oro-labial or cutaneous of more than one month's duration or visceral at any site)
  • Extrapulmonary TB and disseminated non-tuberculosis mycobacterial infection
  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Oesophageal candidiasis (or candidiasis of trachea, bronchi or lungs)
  • Cytomegalovirus infection; retinitis or CMV infection affecting another organ, with onset at age over 1 month)
  • Disseminated endemic mycosis (extrapulmonary histoplasmosis, coccidioidomycosis)
  • Chronic cryptosporidiosis and isosporiasis
  • Symptomatic HIV-associated nephropathy or HIV-associated cardiomyopathy

Neurological-

  • Central nervous system toxoplasmosis (after one month of life)
  • HIV encephalopathy
  • Cerebral or B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma
  • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy
  • Extrapulmonary cryptococcosis (including meningitis)

Respiratory-

  • Pneumocystis pneumonia
  • Recurrent severe bacterial infections (e.g., empyema, pyomyositis, bone or joint infection, meningitis, but excluding pneumonia)

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with fatigue, dry cough, and dyspnea on exertion. On examination, his hands showed hyperextension of the proximal interphalangeal joint and flexion of the distal interphalangeal joint. Laboratory results revealed normocytic normochromic anemia and elevated anti-CCP antibodies. What is the most common interstitial lung disease associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and blood picture in the scenario suggest rheumatoid arthritis. The most common interstitial lung disease associated with this condition is usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP).

Laboratory diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis:

  • Increase in erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein.
  • Serum rheumatoid factor and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibody (anti-CCP) are positive. Anti-CCP antibodies are more specific for diagnosis and a predictor of poor prognosis.
  • The most common anemia associated is normocytic normochromic anemia.

Hyperextension of the proximal interphalangeal joint and flexion of the distal interphalangeal joint suggest swan neck deformity in rheumatoid arthritis. UIP has a poor prognosis and is generally refractive to treatment.

High-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) is the initial investigation of choice for a patient with interstitial lung disease. The most common HRCT pattern seen in a patient with ILD in rheumatoid arthritis is the UIP pattern. Nonspecific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP) can also be seen. The characteristic HRCT findings of UIP are - 

  • Bilateral, lower lobe, subpleural reticular changes
  • Traction bronchiectasis
  • Honey combing pattern

The image given below shows the CT findings of UIP:


Option B - Nonspecific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP) is characterized by bilateral, subpleural, symmetrical ground glass reticular opacities and traction bronchiectasis. In contrast to UIP, honeycombing is uncommon and has a better prognosis. This pattern is universally found in patients with systemic sclerosis. It is also seen in rheumatoid arthritis but is not as common as the UIP pattern. Management includes steroids, cyclophosphamide, mycophenolate, and rituximab with pulmonary rehabilitation.

Option C - Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP) shows patchy subpleural consolidative opacities. A characteristic peribronchiolar/ perilobar opacities with a rim of subpleural sparing called the reverse halo sign is seen. COP is commonly mistaken for pneumonia and can present secondary to polymyositis.

 The image given below shows the reversed halo sign:


Option D - Acute interstitial pneumonia (AIP) shows patchy bilateral ground-glass opacities. It is associated with high mortality.

Related Pearl: Deformities in rheumatoid arthritis

Boutonnière deformity: Flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint. 

 

Swan-neck deformity: Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint.

 

Z line deformity: Radial deviation of the wrist with ulnar deviation of digits. 

Eversion at hindfoot (subtalar joint), hallux valgus (shown below), hammertoe.

Windswept deformities of toes - Valgus deformities of toes in one foot and varus in the other foot. 

Piano-key movement of the ulnar styloid. 

Trigger finger due to flexor tendon synovitis. 

Related Pearl: HRCT Findings in Interstitial Lung Diseases

Idiopathic interstitial lung diseases

  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis / Usual interstitial pneumonia
    • Honeycombing
    • Reticular shadows
    • Traction bronchiectasis
    • Complete loss of lung architecture
    • Absence of other nonspecific findings (ground-glass opacities, nodules, cysts, consolidations)
  • Non-specific interstitial pneumonia
    • Extensive ground-glass opacities
    • Sub pleural sparing (specific, but not seen always)
  • Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP)
    • Patchy consolidation with air bronchogram
    • Reverse halo/ Atoll sign: Ground glass area surrounded by peripheral consolidation (as shown below in red arrows)
  • Lymphocytic interstitial pneumonia (LIP)
    • Thin-walled cysts (shown below in red arrows)
    • Centrilobular nodules 
    • Ground glass opacities
  •  Respiratory bronchiolitis related interstitial lung disease
    • Centrilobular ground-glass nodules
    • Bronchial wall thickening
  • Acute interstitial pneumonia
    • Diffuse patchy ground-glass opacities
  • Desquamated interstitial pneumonia
    • Patchy ground-glass opacities 

Other forms of ILDs

  • Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM)
    • Regular thin-walled cysts
  • Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP)
    • Ground-glass opacification with superimposed septal thickening, known as “crazy paving”
    • It is characteristic but not diagnostic
  • Pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis (PLCH)
    • Bilateral irregular shaped cysts with nodules, predominantly in the upper lobe.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy with a history of cystic fibrosis is treated with ciprofloxacin for infection in his lungs. Ciprofloxacin acts by inhibiting bacterial DNA gyrase. Which of the following enzymatic activities is most directly affected by this inhibition?
questions.solution:
Antibiotics such as fluoroquinolones (ciprofloxacin) inhibit bacterial DNA gyrase. The gyrase introduces negative supercoils into the DNA to counteract excessive positive supercoiling that occurs during DNA replication due to helicases. 

Normally during replication, DNA gyrase nicks double-stranded DNA and introduces negative supercoils to prevent excessive positive supercoiling of the strands. Fluoroquinolones, by inhibiting DNA gyrase (in gram-negative bacteria), result in the production of damaged DNA. This is finally digested by exonucleases, resulting in bactericidal action.

Fluoroquinolones inhibit topoisomerase IV in gram-positive bacteria.

Fluoroquinolones are used in the treatment of urinary tract infections, prostatitis, and gastrointestinal, and respiratory infections, and as a second-line drug in anti-tubercular therapy. They are avoided in children and pregnant women.

Adverse effects of fluoroquinolones are arthralgia, tendon rupture, Clostridium difficile colitis, dysglycemia, prolonged QT interval, rashes, hallucinations, delirium, and seizures.

Other options:

Option B: Synthesis of RNA primers is done by the enzyme DNA primase. Fluoroquinolones have no action on this enzyme.

Option C: ATP-driven processive unwinding of DNA is done by the enzyme helicase. Fluoroquinolones have no action on this enzyme.

Option D: Complimentary strand synthesis is done by the enzyme DNA polymerase. Removal of RNA primers and its replacement with deoxyribonucleotides is also carried out by this enzyme. Fluoroquinolones have no action on this enzyme. 

Related Pearl: Enzymes Involved in DNA Replication

Prokaryotic DNA replication enzymes and their function:

Enzyme Function
DNA Polymerase I (Pol I) Gap filling following DNA replication, repair, and recombination
DNA polymerase II (Pol II) DNA proofreading and repair
DNA polymerase III (Pol III)

Processive, leading strand synthesis, DNA proofreading
DnaG

Primase 
Helicase ATP-driven processive unwinding of DNA.
Primase Initiates synthesis of RNA primers.
Topoisomerase Relieve torsional strain that results from helicase-induced unwinding.
Single-strand binding proteins (SSBs) Prevents premature reannealing of dsDNA.
DNA ligase Seals the single strand nick between the nascent chain and Okazaki fragments on lagging strand.

 

Eukaryotic DNA polymerases:

Eukaryotic DNA Polymerases Functions Proofreading
α  Primase (initiates DNA synthesis) -
β DNA repair -

γ

 Mitochondrial DNA synthesis +
 δ  Processive, lagging strand synthesis(forms and elongates Okazaki fragments from primer) +
 ε  Processive, leading strand synthesis +

Related Pearl: Types of DNA polymerase

Prokaryotic Enzymes (eg in E.coli)

 Eukaryotic Enzymes Functions
 I   Gap filling following DNA replication, repair and recombination
II   DNA proofreading and repair
  β DNA repair
  γ Mitochondrial DNA synthesis
III ε Processive, leading strand synthesis
DnaG α Primase
  δ Processive, lagging strand synthesis

questions.text: Anti-larval measures are being taken for a pond in a village. Which of the following synthetic insecticides are not recommended for such measures?
questions.solution:
DDT (dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane) is not recommended for anti-larval measures. It is mainly used as a residual spray for the control of adult mosquitoes.

Compounds such as DDT and HCH (lindane) are organochlorine compounds. These are not recommended for larvicidal operations for the following reasons: 

  • Long residual effect 
  • Risk of water contamination
  • Risk of developing resistance in the vector mosquitoes

The most effective larvicides are malathion, fenthion, chlorpyrifos, and abate which can quickly hydrolyze in water. Malathion can be used as a low-volume spray to prevent mosquito-borne epidemics, vector-borne diseases during floods and dengue hemorrhagic fever.

Related Pearl: Insecticides

Contact poisons

  • Natural: Pyrethrum, rotenone, derris, nicotine, mineral oils
  • Synthetic:
    • Organo-chlorine compounds: DDT, methoxychlor, HCH, lindane, chlordane, heptachlor, dieldrin, aldrin, toxaphene, kepone, mirex.
    • Repellants: Benzyl benzoate, indalone, meta-diethyltoluamide, dimethyl phthalate, ethyl hexanediol.
    • Organo-phosphorus compounds: Chlorthion (aryl), diazinon (aryl), demethoate, malathion (alkyl), fenthion, parathion (aryl), trichlorfon (alkyl), runnel, abale, naled, chlorpyrifos, fenitrothion, dicapthon.
    • Carbamates: Carbaryl, dimetilan, propoxur, pyrolan.
    • Synthetic pyrethroids: Prothrin, resmethrin, bioresmethrin, permethrin, proparthin, tetramethrin
  • Stomach poisons: Paris green, sodium fluoride.
  • Fumigants: Hydrogen cyanide, methyl bromide, sulphur dioxide, carbon disulphide.
Specific Insecticides Comments
DDT (Dichloro-diphenyl-thrichloroethane) Insecticidal properties were discovered by Swiss scientist, Paul Muller. Most widely used insecticide. Attacks nerves of insects but doesn’t cause immediate death. White amorphous powder. Contains 70 – 80% of para-para isomers, which is the most active fraction of DDT. Has residual action up to 18 months. Used as a residual spray.Least toxic organo-chlorine compound.
HCH (hexachlorocyclo-hexane) Synthesized by Michael Faraday. Normal HCH contains 13 – 16% of gamma isomer. Gamma-HCH or lindane has 99% gamma isomer.Short residual action – 3 months.
Malathion Least toxicity of all organophosphorus compounds. Used as an ultra-low volume spray.
Fenthion Also called baytex. Used as a residual spray.
Pyrethrum Vegetable origin – Chrysanthemum cinerariafolium. Nerve poison and is excellent as a space spray.No residual action.Synergistic action with DDT as space spray.

Related Pearl: Mosquito Control Measures

  • Anti-larval measures
    • Environmental control
      • This is done by source reduction by eliminating breeding places through appropriate methods for the different species.
      • Intermittent irrigation is also a method of environmental control
    • Chemical control
      • Mineral oils: Oldest known larvicidal method. Oils that are used are diesel oil, kerosene, crude oil fractions. Disadvantage is that it kills fish.
      • Paris green: Copper acetoarsenite is an emerald green, micro-crystalline powder and is insoluble in water. It is a stomach poison to larvae. It is not harmful to man or animals. Very effective against Anopheles as they are surface feeders.
      • Synthetic insecticides: Organo-phosphorous compounds like fenthion, chlorpyrifos and abate are larvicidal. Abate is least toxic.
    • Biological control
      • The fish species Gambusia affinis and Lebister reticulatus (Barbados millions) feed on mosquito larvae.
      • These are used in conjunction with other methods.
  • Anti-adult measures
    • Residual sprays
      • Adult mosquitoes can be controlled by spraying with residual insecticides like DDT, Malathion, propoxur and gamma-HCH (lindane)
      • Resistance to DDT has been shown by mosquitoes
    • Space sprays
      • Space sprays are those in which insecticides are sprayed into the atmosphere in the form of a mist or fog.
      • Pyrethrum is a contact, nerve poison and is the most common insecticide used as a space spray. Its active principle is pyrethrin.
      • Ultra-low volume space spraying (ULV) is done with Malathion and fenitrothion.
    • Genetic control by sterile male technique, cytoplasmic incompatibility, sex distortion, etc.
  • Protection against bites
    • Usage of mosquito nets, building screens and repellants like diethyltoluamide (deet), indalone, dimethylphthalate, dimethyl carbate, etc.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child with measles is brought to the OPD with complaints of profuse otorrhea. Otoscopy is suggestive of acute necrotizing otitis media. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
β-hemolytic streptococcus is the most common organism causing acute necrotizing otitis media. 

Acute necrotizing otitis media is a variety of acute suppurative otitis media. This is often seen in children suffering from measles, scarlet fever, or influenza. 

It leads to the destruction of the entire tympanic membrane, middle ear mucosa, and air cells. There is profuse otorrhoea. In such cases, healing is followed by fibrosis or ingrowth of squamous epithelium from the meatus leading to a secondary acquired cholesteatoma.

Treatment is early antibiotic therapy for at least 7- 10 days.  Cortical mastoidectomy may be indicated if medical treatment fails to control or the condition gets complicated by acute mastoiditis.

questions.text: You are posted for duty at the isolation ward. After completion of duty, which of the following will you not dispose of in the red bin?
questions.solution:
The headcover of PPE, used by the healthcare worker, must be disposed of in the yellow bin.

Related Pearl: Biomedical Waste (BMW) Management -COVID 19

In addition to the current BMW Management rules, the following measures are proposed

  • To report opening/operation of COVID 19 Ward/ICU/Lab/Collection Centre to SPCB (State Pollution Control Board) and CBWTF (Common Biomedical Waste Treatment Facility) in that area
  • Dedicated sanitation workers deputed only to collect COVID 19 BMW
  • It is mandatory for all BMW bags and containers from COVID 19 areas to carry "COVID 19 WASTE" label
  • Keep separate colour coded bins with foot operated lids
  • The inner and outer surfaces of these containers must be disinfected daily with 1% sodium hypochlorite solution
  • To ensure no leaks, double layers (2 bags) are used

  • Splash-proof apron
  • Plastic coverall
  • Hazmat suit
  • Nitrile gloves
  • Used gloves

Laboratory waste

  • Pre-treated viral transport media
  • Plastic vials and cryovials
  • Vacutainers
  • Eppendorf tubes
  • Pipette tips
Yellow Bin

  • Diapers with feces of immobile COVID 19 patients

questions.text: A young woman with a previous history of dilatation and curettage for elective abortion presents with hypomenorrhea. Hysterosalpingography shows irregular, angulated filling defects. Which of the following investigations is used for the definitive diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Asherman syndrome. Hysteroscopy is used for the definitive diagnosis of Asherman syndrome.

Asherman syndrome refers to the presence of uterine synechiae, due to the destruction of the endometrium. It can occur as a result of trauma to the endometrium following vigorous curettages for elective abortion, tuberculous endometritis, and uterine surgeries.

Depending on the degree of scarring, patients may have amenorrhea, hypomenorrhea, or recurrent pregnancy loss because of inadequate placentation.

Hysterosalpingography is performed to assess the uterine cavity and tubal patency. Intrauterine adhesions are characteristically seen as irregular angulated filling defects in the uterine cavity with a classic 'moth-eaten' appearance. 

Definitive diagnosis (gold standard) and management are done by hysteroscopy. Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis is the surgical treatment of choice.

Hormonal assays also aid in the diagnosis of anatomical causes of amenorrhea such as Asherman syndrome. All women with amenorrhea in the reproductive age group are considered pregnant unless proven otherwise by negative urinary or serum β-HCG levels. Once negative for pregnancy, further testing is done by a progesterone challenge test.

This test is done by administering medroxyprogesterone acetate as a 10-mg daily oral dose for 10 days. If the woman bleeds, then she is assumed to produce estrogen and to have a developed endometrium, and the presence of a patent outflow tract is confirmed. If she does not bleed, then she is given estrogen followed by progesterone treatment in the form of combined OCPs. If she fails to bleed after completing the 21 hormone-containing pills, then an anatomic abnormality is diagnosed such as Asherman syndrome.

Given below is an algorithm for the evaluation of amenorrhea.

Other options:

Option A: Transvaginal ultrasonography is a noninvasive imaging technique using the transvaginal approach. It provides a more detailed evaluation of the pelvic organs as compared to the transabdominal approach.

Option C: Saline infusion sonography is a procedure where normal saline is injected into the uterine cavity and the uterus is imaged with transvaginal sonography. It is shown in the image below.

questions.text:
An 11-year-old boy was brought with complaints of repeatedly twitching his mouth, raising his eyebrows, and grunting since he was 6 years old. There is a new-onset habit of throat clearing multiple times a day. His mother is worried as the symptoms have increased. She mentions that he was diagnosed with ADHD as a child. Which of the following is not true for this condition?

ADHD- Attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder

MRS- Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy

choices.text: Increased N-acetyl aspartate in the frontal cortex on MRS
Waxing and waning of movements is noted
Severe disease is treated with atomoxetine
Coprolalia is unusual but may be seen

questions.solution:
The clinical features mentioned in the above scenario are suggestive of Tourette's syndrome. MRS reveals decreased levels of N-acetyl aspartate in the frontal cortex bilaterally.

Tourette's syndrome is a neurobehavioral disorder characterized by sudden, rapid, recurrent, non-rhythmic motor movements and vocalizations, called tics. Coprolalia may be seen, which refers to vocal tics that can be socially offensive, such as loud grunting, barking noises, or shouted words, which may be obscenities.

Over half of the children diagnosed with Tourette's syndrome also meet the criteria for attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder(ADHD).

The DSM-V criteria for the diagnosis of Tourette syndrome include:

  • Presence of both multiple motor and one or more vocal tics, at some time during the illness. Although both need not occur simultaneously.
  • The tics may wax and wane in frequency but have persisted for more than 1 year since the onset of the first tic.
  • Onset is before age 18 years.
  • The disorder is not attributable to the physiological effects of substance abuse (e.g. cocaine) or underlying medical condition (e.g., Huntington’s disease, postviral encephalitis).

Neurochemical findings on MRS:

  • Reduced amount of choline and N-acetyl aspartate in the left putamen and bilaterally.
  • In the frontal cortex, patients with Tourette's disorder were found to have:
    • Reduced levels of N-acetyl aspartate bilaterally.
    • Reduced levels of creatine on the right side
    • Reduced levels of myoinositol on the left side
Management:

Behavioral interventions are the first line of treatment. Pharmacotherapy must be included in severe cases. Tics require treatment when they cause social and emotional problems, depression, or isolation. 

In mild cases, where the academic performance or social life is not affected, the first line of management is to provide psychoeducation, followed by a wait and watch strategy.

For severe cases:

  • Behavioral interventions:
    • Habit reversal
    • Exposure and response prevention
  • Pharmacological treatment:
    • Antipsychotics like risperidone
    • Noradrenergic agents like atomoxetine
    • Alternative treatments such as tetrabenazine, topiramate, and tetrahydrocannabinol

questions.text: A 2-day-old neonate was brought with complaints of one episode of seizure, vomiting, and poor feeding. Investigations revealed increased levels of lactate in blood and cerebrospinal fluid. The deficiency of which of the following enzymes leads to the above condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette along with elevated levels of lactate in blood and cerebrospinal fluid suggestive of congenital lactic acidosis. The deficiency of the pyruvate dehydrogenase enzyme complex leads to this condition.

Congenital lactic acidosis is an inborn error of metabolism that often presents in infancy with lethargy, vomiting, tachypnea, and poor feeding. Other severe symptoms include hypotonia and seizures. Investigations show a high level of lactate in blood, cerebrospinal fluid, and urine (lactic acidosis).

Causes of lactic acidosis include mitochondrial disorders, deficiency of PDH enzyme/vitamin B12, mercury, and arsenite poisoning.

The pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) complex is a multienzyme complex that is associated with the inner mitochondrial membrane which catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA. It has three enzyme components that include:

  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase
  • Dihydrolipoyl transacetylase
  • Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase

The cofactors for PDH complex are:

  • Thiamine diphosphate
  • Lipoic acid
  • Coenzyme A
  • Flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD)
  • Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+)

The overall reaction is : Pyruvate + NAD+ + CoA → Acetyl-CoA + NADH + H+ + CO2

Pyruvate Dehydrogenase is regulated by end-product inhibition & covalent modification

  • PDH is inhibited by its products, acetyl-CoA, and NADH.
  • Phosphorylation of the multienzyme complex by a kinase results in decreased activity.
    • The kinase is activated by increases in the [ATP]/[ADP], [acetyl-CoA]/[CoA], and [NADH]/[NAD+] ratios.
  • Dephosphorylation, catalyzed by a phosphatase, causes an increase in the activity of PDH.

Thus, pyruvate dehydrogenase, and therefore glycolysis, is inhibited when there is adequate ATP available and when fatty acids are being oxidized. In adipose tissue, the enzyme is activated in response to insulin.

Clinical aspects:

  • Arsenite and mercuric ions react with the -SH groups of lipoic acid and inhibit pyruvate dehydrogenase.
  • Dietary thiamine deficiency inhibits PDH. Therefore, chronic alcoholics may develop potentially fatal pyruvic and lactic acidosis.
  • Patients with inherited pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency present with lactic acidosis, particularly after a glucose load, and present with neurological disturbances.

Other options:

Options B and C: Inherited aldolase A deficiency and pyruvate kinase deficiency in erythrocytes cause hemolytic anemia.

Option D: Aldolase B cleaves fructose-1-phosphate. In the deficiency of aldolase B, hereditary fructose intolerance develops which is characterized by profound hypoglycemia and vomiting after consumption of sucrose, which yields fructose in digestion. This can lead to fructose-induced hypoglycemia.

Related Pearl: Pyruvate metabolism

  Enzyme involved

Fate of pyruvate
1 Cahill cycle (Alanine aminotransferase)

Carries amino group from muscle to liver.

Converts alanine to pyruvate and vise-versa.
2 Pyruvate carboxylase Formation of oxaloacetate from pyruvate to be used in the TCA cycle
3 Pyruvate dehydrogenase Pyruvate to acetyl Co-A to be used in the TCA cycle
4 Lactic acid dehydrogenase Pyruvate to lactate(Anaerobic glycolysis)

questions.text: A patient with hyperthyroidism is planned for thyroidectomy. In order to achieve a euthyroid status preoperatively, he is started on Lugol's iodine solution. Which of the following best describes its mechanism of action?

choices.text: Inhibition of organification and synthesis of thyroid hormones

questions.solution:
Introduction of exogenous iodine in the form of lugol's iodine solution leads to transient inhibition of organification and synthesis of thyroid hormones. This is known as the wolff-chaikoff effect.

In individuals with a normal thyroid, the gland escapes from this inhibitory effect and iodide organification resumes; but the suppressive action of high iodide may persist in patients with hyperthyroidism due to underlying autoimmune thyroid disease.

Note: Jod-Basedow effect is iodine-induced hyperthyroidism, usually occurring after the use of an I-based contrast agent. It is often seen in the presence of pre-existing thyroid conditions like multinodular goitre.

questions.text: What is the origin of the muscle marked as "X" in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The anconeus is the muscle marked as "X" in the image above. The anconeus originates from the posterior surface of the lateral epicondyle of the humerus. 

The anconeus is the short triangular muscle. The anconeus is located in the posterior part of the elbow joint, part of the extensor compartment of the arm. It inserts into the lateral aspect of the olecranon and the proximal one-fourth of the posterior surface of the shaft of the ulna.

It receives its nerve supply from the radial nerve with a root value of C6, C7, and C8.

It is an extensor of the elbow. It receives its vascular supply from branches of the posterior interosseous recurrent artery.

 Extensor muscles of the forearm:

Muscles Nerve supply Action
Anconeus Radial nerve (C6, C7, C8) Abduction of the ulna in pronation; Extensor of the elbow joint
Extensor digitorum Posterior interosseous nerve (C7, C8) Extends the wrist, metacarpophalangeal, and proximal and distal
interphalangeal joints.
Extensor carpi ulnaris Posterior interosseous nerve (C7, C8) Extends and adducts the wrist
Extensor carpi radialis longus Radial nerve (C6, C7) Extends and abducts the wrist
Extensor carpi radialis brevis Deep branch of the radial nerve (C7, C8) before penetrating supinator muscle Prime dorsiflexor of the wrist.

questions.text: As a part of project work in radiology postings, you were asked to measure the biological risk of an individual i.e, the risk that a person will suffer health effects from exposure to radiation. Which of the following SI unit will be used for this purpose?
questions.solution:
The biological risk of an individual is measured by using the SI unit Sievert (Sv).

Different units of measure are used depending on what aspect of radiation is being measured

  • SI unit becquerel (Bq) or conventional unit curie is used for measuring the amount of radiation being emitted by a radioactive material.
  • SI unit gray (Gy) or conventional unit rad is used for measuring radiation dose absorbed by a person (that is, the amount of energy deposited in human tissue by radiation)
  • SI unit sievert (Sv) or conventional unit rem is used for measuring the biological risk of exposure to radiation (One Sv is equal to 100 rem).

Related Pearl: Important SI units for radiation

Quantity measured Old unit New Unit Conversion Description
Radioactivity Curie Becquerel 1 curie = 3.7 x 1010 becquerel  
Radiation exposure Roentgen Coulumb/kg 1 roentgen = 2.58 × 10-4 C/Kg Amount of radiation absorbed in air.  
Absorbed dose Rad Gray (Gy) 100 rad = 1 gray (or, 1 rad = 0.01 gray)  Amount of radioactive energy absorbed per unit gram of tissue or material.
Dose equivalent Rem Sievert (Sv) 100 rem = 1 sievert  Indicates potential danger to health.

questions.text: During an ongoing cholecystectomy surgery, the surgeon instructs the intern to retract the liver. Which of the following instruments should be used?
questions.solution:
A Deaver retractor is used to retract the liver during surgery.

It is commonly used during cholecystectomy. The liver can still be damaged while using this retractor, so care must be taken to avoid using excessive force. Some surgeons prefer to reduce the risk of liver injury by placing an abdominal pack between the liver and retractor. 

Other options:

Option B - Doyen retractor is used to retract the abdominal wall and bladder during surgery. It is frequently used in lower segment cesarean sections to allow visualization of the lower uterine segment. 

Option C - Morris retractor is a large retractor used to give maximum exposure during abdominal surgeries. Because of its size, it can be used to improve the field of visibility by retracting a large number of structures. 

Option D - Czerny retractor has two ends. One end is a blade with a lip and the other has two prongs and is used to retract the ends of an incision. It is used to retract wounds like in open appendicectomy.

Related Pearl: Identification of Surgical Retractors

questions.text: A 54-year-old man presented with abdominal pain and hematemesis. He has been taking antacids for heartburn for the last three years. He was stabilized. Endoscopy revealed a bleeding ulcer on the posterior wall of the duodenum near the pylorus. Which of the following vessels is most likely to be the source of bleeding?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of upper gastrointestinal bleeding probably due to peptic ulcer disease. The vessel most likely to be the source of bleeding is the gastroduodenal artery.

Peptic ulcers include duodenal and gastric ulcers of which duodenal ulcers are more common. 

The common sites are the first part of the duodenum and the lesser curvature of the stomach especially incisura angularis respectively.

Risk factors include H.pylori infection, NSAID intake, and cigarette smoking.

Features of a duodenal ulcer include bleeding and perforation. Ulcers located in the posterior wall can erode the mucosa and the gastroduodenal artery, leading to hematemesis and melena. Perforation is common with anterior duodenal ulcers.

Gastric ulcer also tends to bleed and perforate. They are much larger than duodenal ulcers.

questions.text: A patient presents with fatigue and a petechial rash for the past 4 weeks. Complete hemogram shows: Hb - 8 g/dL, platelet count  - 70,000/mm3, WBC - 5000/mm3. Bone marrow aspiration reveals mild hypercellularity with 3% blasts, dysplastic erythroid and megakaryocytic cells, and 10 % ringed sideroblasts(RS). What type of myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) does this patient have?

choices.text: MDS - RS with single lineage dysplasia

questions.solution:
MDS with multilineage dysplasia is seen in this patient. As both erythroid and megakaryocyte lineages are affected, it is a multilineage dysplasia.

Myelodysplastic syndromes are a group of hematogenous disorders that are characterized by cytopenia due to bone marrow failure and a high risk of transformation into acute myeloid leukemia(AML). Multilineage hematogenous abnormalities are seen as anemia, thrombocytopenia, and neutropenia. Dysmorphic and hypercellular bone marrow are reflective of ineffective hematopoiesis.
